DOC.HEAD: BBC to Make First Domestic Broadcasts in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: The British Broadcasting Corp. plans to launch a 24-hour service in Czechoslovakia this weekend, the first of its kind in Eastern Europe, a BBC official says. BBC World Service programs are rebroadcast by radio stations in several East European nations, but Czechoslovakia is the first to allocate the BBC a domestic frequency. Andrew Taussig, European controller at the BBC World Service, says Prague and Bratislava will receive the first service. Broadcasts to the city of Brno will start in the next few days, he says. ``Coming after more than 50 years, this is an historic moment for the BBC and for our listeners as we deploy for the first time on local soil a 24-hour service in English and local languages,'' said Taussig. The programs will be a mixture of BBC World Service items in Czech, Slovak and English. The World Service, financed by the government, is broadcast around the world in many languages and reaches about 120 million listeners.

DOC.HEAD: EC Environment Ministers Decide To Ban CFCs By Mid-1997
DOC.TEXT: The European Community environment ministers have decided to ban the production and use of ozone-harming chlorofluorocarbons by mid-1997, officials say. By Jan. 1, 1992, the 12-nation trade bloc will cut in half production and importation of the manmade chemical often used as an aerosol propellant. It will be outlawed by July 7, 1997, officials said Friday. Chlorofluorocarbons are believed to deplete the ozone layer, which protects the earth from ultraviolet radiation from the sun. The EC Commission is studying the possibility including a tax on chlorofluorocarbons to speed up the ban. International agreements seek to ban chlorofluorocarbons by the year 2000.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Announces Emergency Donations for Palestinian Hospitals
DOC.TEXT: The World Health Organization said about $6.4 million has been pledged to help ease worsening health conditions among Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied territories. A WHO statement Friday said the funds were aimed at providing emergency assistance to private hospitals hard hit by a drop in revenues because of the Persian Gulf Crisis. Kuwait and Saudi Arabia were traditional sources of funding for Palestinian health care. The statement said Canada pledged $575,000, Germany offered $465,000 and the European Community promised $5.4 million. The offers came in response to an appeal by WHO Director-General Dr. Hiroshi Nakajima. The Geneva-based health agency said about $9.1 million is needed by hospitals in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Some hospitals in the occupied territories have stopped buying new supplies and equipment and cut staff numbers and wages, the WHO statement said.

DOC.HEAD: Meetings on Airport Access End Without Accord
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and British government officials have suspended negotiations on efforts by United Airlines and American Airlines for landing rights at London's Heathrow airport. There was no date for resumption of the talks, which were held Thursday and Friday. Cyril Murphy, director of international operations for Chiago-based United, no progress was made in the negotiations. British law has barred new entrants from congested Heathrow since 1977 and diverted them to London's Gatwick and other British airports. Many airlines have been clamoring for access to Heathrow, which is served by the London subway system and offers more air connections to Europe and elsewhere. Fort Worth, Texas-based American seeks to buy TWA's London and other overseas routes for $445 million. United agreed in October to buy most of Pan Am's London routes for $400 million. Both airlines have said the deals won't proceed unless they gain access to Heathrow. An air services agreement allows successors to existing U.S. airlines to assume their Heathrow rights. United and American say they qualify. A spokesman for the British Department of Transport, who spoke on anonymity, said British officials offered to resume meetings next month.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Bureau Named for Minnesota
DOC.TEXT: Dave Pyle, assistant chief of bureau in Dallas for The Associated Press, has been named AP's chief of bureau in Minneapolis. AP President Louis D. Boccardi announced the appointment Friday. Pyle joined the AP in Omaha, Neb., in 1979, and was promoted to news editor two years later. In 1983 he moved to Providence, R.I., as correspondent. In 1988, he became news editor in Dallas and was promoted to assistant chief of bureau the same year. A Des Moines, Iowa, native, Pyle received his bachelor's degree from the University of Iowa. Before joining the AP he worked for The Daily Nonpareil in Council Bluffs, Iowa. He succeeds Charles Hill, who has been named chief of bureau for Michigan.

DOC.HEAD: Even Rodeo Drive Feels Recession's Pinch - Sort Of
With PM-Bell Choir, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By E. SCOTT RECKARD
DOC.TEXT: The floods of Japanese tourists have ebbed. Sales are off by a third at some of the priciest stores in the universe. Longtime merchants lament that only Cartier can afford the rent. Indeed, some storefronts sit empty at the height of the shopping season. But can the word recession ever apply on Rodeo Drive? After all, this is where they just opened a $200 million mini-mall with 100,000 hand-set cobblestones. This is where $8,000 bustiers still sll at Giorgio Armani, hostesses drop $3,000 on pillboxes for party favors and some sales clerks have six-figure incomes. ``Retail's slow right now, so you just have to work harder,'' said Amen Wardy of the store of the same name, who began markdowns at Thanksgiving to move merchandise. Sweaters originally priced at $2,050 could be had for a mere $525 on one recent day. The price of leather jackets had shrunk from $3,360 to $800. Still, Wardy continues to do a bustling business in non-sale must-haves like sparkling Judith Leiber handbags costing up to $5,000. Some of the gleaming clutches are designed like slices of watermelon or orange. Bags custom-made to resemble your dog are tagged at $2,400. ``The other evening, we sold 12 to one person,'' said saleswoman Bette Donnell. ``Or someone will come in and take 12 of the pillboxes as favors for a dinner party.'' The pillboxes, rhinestone-encrusted baubles shaped like little partridges and turbans, cost $180 to $305 each. Signals are similarly mixed up and down Rodeo this recession-struck holiday season. ``Rodeo is slower than I've ever seen it,'' said Avi Amiel, associate director at the Hanson Art Galleries, who has worked on the street for six years. He said sales are off up to 30 percent. ``This time of year the street is usually so crowded you can hardly walk out there. Now you can roller skate without hitting anyone,'' Amiel said. Next door at Giorgio, though, salesman Johnny Zavala said ``signature items'' such as the perfume, $1,000 cashmere sweat suits and $300 sweat shirts beaded with Austrian lead crystal continue to sell to tourists from around the world. And at Chanel, where a standard woman's suit runs $3,000 and some cost $18,000, regular customers continue to buy five or six a year, said Trini Abellan, who has sold clothing at the boutique for nearly six years. She says she has heard that some shops on Rodeo are hurting. But Chanel remains a classic. ``For instance, last year I sold a certain amount of millions. This year, I sold more.'' Rodeo Drive has always been expensive. But over the past decade, it's become less of a village center for locals and more a playground for the wealthiest jet-setters on every continent, and a huge attraction for tourists of every social strata. Alan Austin has run his women's clothing store just off Rodeo for 26 years. He complains that foreign tourists care only about labels, and only the top retail names in the world can afford to rent space in places like Two Rodeo Drive. That's the brand-new $200 million development. Designed to look like shops on a street in Europe, it increases the retail space on Rodeo by 60 percent. Christian Dior, Valentino and Cartier have moved in. The platinum, gold and diamond earrings in Tiffany & Co.'s window cost $123,000. Like Wardy, Austin began putting items on sale at Thanksgiving because his inventory was so high. With the dollar weak, prices have gone through the roof on his Italian and French clothing. That has caused even wealthy locals to cut back on spending, unlike during the last recession, he said.

DOC.HEAD: `Eyes-Open nconsciousness' Like Cruzan's Is Tough on Family
With PM-Right-to-Die, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The deceptively alert-looking ``eyes-open unconciousness'' that envelops Nancy Cruzan and perhaps 10,000 other Americans is difficult for families of the patients to accept. In the condition, called persistent vegetative state, the eyes move about and sometimes react to sound. Patients may grimace, smack their lips and seem to smile. They sleep and wake up. But these are simply reflexes. The patients have permanent brain damage that prevents consciousness. ``They're just as unconscious as patients in a coma,'' in which eyes are closed and the patient cannot be aroused, said Dr. Ron Cranford, an expert on persistent vegetative states. ``It looks like they're perfectly normal ... So it's very hard on the family and health care providers to accept the fact that they're not there.'' It takes months or years for a family to come to terms with that and the lack of hope for recovery, said Cranford, a neurologist at the Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis. A vegetative state is called persistent if there is no hope of recovery. A person may still recover fully after six months to a year in a vegetative state if it was caused by a head injury, especially in children, Cranford said. But if the patient suffered loss of blood or oxygen to the brain, as Cruzan did, recovery can be ruled out after one to three months, he said. Cruzan's condition has persisted since a 1983 auto accident. Last Friday, her feeding tube was removed after a lengthy court battle. Doctors said she would die from dehydration within a week or two of the tube's removal. ``She's not in pain, she's not suffering in any way,'' because the brain centers that would let her perceive pain and suffering are destroyed, said Cranford, who has examined her. In her last two to three days, she will go into a coma, and then ``she'll die a quiet, peaceful death,'' he said. If death is inevitable in such cases, why not give a lethal injection and get it over with, sparing the family a long death watch? That is homicide, notes Robert Veatch, director of the Kennedy Institute of Ethics at Georgetown University. The question of legalization will draw ``much more serious debate'' in the coming decade, he said. One argument against legalization suggests that if it is allowed for a clear-cut case, it will then be allowed later for more shaky cases so that ``all sorts of people are getting killed that shouldn't be,'' he said. That fear is ``at least worth worrying about,'' Veatch said. Another argument is the idea that it's simply wrong to kill in these situations, even if it is ethically acceptable to let somebody die, he said. Many people may have a gut feeling that there is a difference, he said, but it is not clear whether that reaction occurs because there really is a difference, or because people have been taught all their lives that there is one, he said. That question will be debated in upcoming years, but for now, ``I think the difference is worthy of very serious consideration,'' Veatch said. Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota, said he sees no ethical reason to hasten Cruzan's death for the sake of others. ``No one said that death is supposed to be easy on other people,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Completes Front Yard Christmas Display
With PM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^LaserPhoto FR1 of Dec. 21
DOC.TEXT: Bud Stanley's front yard is decorated like a desert this holiday season - the Saudi Arabian desert, to be exact. While neighbors put Santa Claus on the roof and a nativity scene or menorah in the front yard, Stanley created a Desert Shield Christmas to honor the men and women stationed in Saudi Arabia. Stanley's yard is in Tulare, about 50 miles south of Fresno in central California. It has holiday lights, reindeer and other traditional decorations. But they're scattered among sand dunes, palm trees, a camouflaged Jeep and military pup tents - even fatigues hanging on a line. And, of course, a jet. An actual A-4 jet loaned by nearby Lemoore Naval Air Station is the finishing touch on Stanley's holiday tribute to the soldiers involved in Desert Shield. Stanley has even created a realistic-looking runway, complete with blinking blue running lights. ``It turned out pretty good,'' said the 20-year-old, who has created extravagant displays every Christmas since 1986. ``But I didn't expect it to go this far, frankly.'' Stanley, who lives with his parents, helps run the family's chain of convenience stores. He said he did the display to honor soldiers taking part in Desert Shield, especially his friend, Corey Kuykendall, on active duty with a tank division in Saudi Arabia. ``It's to show the men and women out there that we love them,'' he said. ``We want them to have a good Christmas.'' Stanley began working on the display the day after Thanksgiving and put in over 150 hours before it was complete. ``Once the idea of a display in honor of the troops in Saudi Arabia was decided upon, the display took off,'' Stanley said in a telephone interview. The chief of police told him about a sergeant who wanted to loan him pup tents and other military regalia. ``He asked me if I wanted an A-4 fighter and I said `No way!','' Stanley recalled. ``It really blew my mind.'' Navy officials loaned a stripped-down fighter jet frequently used for parade floats. ``I think it was a good thing to do,'' said Lemoore spokesman Dennis McGrath. ``We thought about Desert Shield and it being Christmas season, we decided: What the heck, let's do it.'' McGrath said the jet's engine and hydraulic system were pulled, and the only real concern was security. Police officers in this San Joaquin Valley community 150 miles north of Los Angeles agreed to keep a constant watch over the jet. By the end of the season, the display will cost Stanley between $1,000 and $1,500 in electricity bills alone. However, all the equipment and displays are on loan. Even the full team of reindeer was donated by an archery club. Out of the roughly 1,000 people who visit the display ever night, several stop to thank him. ``We have had some ladies and men drop by to tell us that they have a husband or wife over there, and they thank us,'' he said. ``But this is all to thank them.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan Seeking Ways to Improve Image With Americans
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By ELAINE KURTENBACH
DOC.TEXT: Could something as simple as books and pamphlets about the lifestyles of ordinary Japanese help solve Japan's image problem in the United States? Japanese officials say they sure hope so, and they're putting money on it. The government, at the urging of former Foreign Minister Shintaro Abe, is setting up a $370 million fund for public relations and joint U.S.-Japanese research on common problems. Foreign Ministry officials say the effort is necessary, given polls showing that Americans view Japan as a serious economic threat. Abe, a senior legislator of the governing Liberal Democratic Party, proposed the Japan-U.S. Global Partnership Fund in June during a visit to Washington. The idea was later endorsed by Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. ``American people feel the Japanese are always very efficient, that they band together among themselves and their only goal is to make profits,'' said a Foreign Ministry official on condition of anonymity. ``But we share many problems in common, such as educating our kids and the aging of our societies. If there are many opportunities for Americans to get acquainted, Japanese will look more human,'' he said. Foreign Ministry spokesman Taizo Watanabe said the fund was set up in response to ``apprehension about deterioration of trust because of a lack of communication efforts.'' It's a slightly more pragmatic approach to an old problem first dealt with in 1972, when the government set up the Japan Foundation. That semi-governmental institution has supported worldwide teaching and student exchanges as well as research on Japan, but has done little to educate the non-academic community in the United States, the Foreign Ministry official said. ``The relations between our two countries have outgrown the realm of scholarship. These days, even Americans who don't study Japan have to know about it because of the size of our economy,'' he said. In a supplementary national budget approved Monday, The Global Partnership Fund received $300 million directly from the government and another $74.6 million from the Japan Foundation. Its expenditures will be limited to interest earned on the capital, or about $25 million to $30 million a year. That money will be used to provide U.S. universities and public libraries with publications aimed at explaining the Japanese people. It also will fund think tanks for joint research on common problems, including environmental issues and aging in both societies, the official said. The fund is the latest in a series of moves indicating growing dissatisfaction among Japanese officials with their image overseas. Last week, two other influential Liberal Democrats flew to the United States seeking to calm anger among black leaders over a comment by Justice Minister Seiroku Kajiyama comparing American blacks to prostitutes in Japan who ``ruin the atmosphere of neighborhoods they move into.'' In recent years, the Foreign Ministry also has tried to improve Japan's relations with other Asian and Third World countries through more cultural exchanges and educational programs. But Japanese propaganda efforts overseas frequently are met with skepticism. ``Americans are tired of hearing that the real problem is they don't have a deep understanding of Japan,'' says Robert M. Orr Jr., director of the Stanford Japan Center in Kyoto, western Japan. ``The Japanese idea is that if you disagree with them, then you don't understand them.''

DOC.HEAD: Radicalism Will Make a Comeback in the 1990s, Researchers Predict
DOC.TEXT: Hippie icon Wavy Gravy was right when he predicted recently that the 1990s will be like the 1960s ``turned upside down and inside out,'' a survey of Stanford University students suggests. Two Stanford anthropologists who have surveyed student attitudes for 38 years predict that the 1990s may resemble the Vietnam War era, with a rise in extremism on both ends of the political spectrum. ``I wouldn't be surprised if there was a fairly substantial form of radicalism,'' said George Spindler, who, along with his wife, Louise, has queried Stanford students each year since Harry Truman was president. An upsurge in extreme right-wing views will occur because the middle-class feels increasingly threatened by societal uncertainties and minorities, the Spindlers say. Leftist extremism could rise from the threat of war in the Middle East and the specter of recession, they said. The survey indicated increased tension among young adults and middle-aged people. The survey, with 24 open-ended statements, was given to students aged 17 to 45. From several hundred to 4,000 people have responded each year since 1952. Different eras show marked changes in attitudes. In the 1950s, a majority of respondents completed the statement ``the future is...'' with ``rosy,'' or a similar positive word, the Spindlers said. Today, most said the future is ``dismal'' or ``something to worry about,'' they said. But black, Chicano and Asian respondents didn't seem as insecure about the future as their white counterparts. George Spindler conceded the survey of of elite college students may not fully reflect the views of average Americans. ``But university populations set the trend,'' he said. ``Then it filters down and causes changes in other populations.''

DOC.HEAD: For Young Japanese, Christmas Means Romance and Extravagant Spending
With PM-Bell Choir, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By ELAINE KURTENBACH
DOC.TEXT: In this country where only one percent of the population is Christian, Christmas is celebrated lavishly with fancy dinners, hotel floor shows and, most importantly, the exchanging of extravagant gifts. Christmas is a full-fledged festival here, largely because the Japanese delight in exchanging gifts and are drawn to things Western. As the holiday approaches, Christmas trees, poinsettias and holly brighten shop windows, kids eagerly await presents and the strains of familiar carols mingle with the chorus of Salvation Army volunteers outside department stores. But for those of courting age, Noel means romance. Spending Christmas Eve alone is the ultimate embarrassment, and efforts to make the right impression can top $1,000. ``Do you know who you're spending Christmas Eve with?'' the popular magazine ``Hot Dog'' asks its young male readers, before providing detailed pointers on the right clothes, restaurant, hotel and seduction techniques for the holiday. ``Although Dec. 24 is no different from any other of the 365 days of the year, it's even more important than your birthday,'' the magazine says. ``You've got to do very careful research into what she's hoping for on Christmas...There's a mountain of things to do.'' Japanese begin making restaurant and hotel reservations for the big night as early as April. Dinner shows with tabs starting at $225 a person, popular hotels and tours to such places as Hawaii, Guam and Southeast Asia fill up as soon as reservations open. Then there are the gifts. Department stores ring up 25 percent of their total annual sales in December because of Christmas and the tradition of offering year-end presents to express appreciation for favors. Annual sales of Christmas gifts total about $1.15 billion, about half for toys. Another substantial chunk of Christmas sales are to denim-clad college men, many of whom crowd beside ladies swathed in mink at Tiffany's and other posh stores, looking for a coveted pendant or ring for their sweethearts. A fashionable Christmas Eve - a gift worth at least $200, a day at Tokyo's Disneyland, and dinner and a room at a nearby luxury hotel - can cost about $1,000. Young bachelors typically moonlight, scrimp and sometimes go into debt to pay for one evening's extravagance. ``Christmas Eve costs at the very least about ($530) and the man has to pay for all of it. It's really hard,'' said one 23-year-old photographer. The celebration mystifies some Japanese. ``The Obsession of a Christmas for Two,'' the weekly magazine Asahi Journal called the phenomenon in a headline. ``Since when did Christmas become such a festival?'' radio announcer Shoko Yoshida said in a commentary in the newspaper Sankei Shimbun. ``Recently, `It's not the money that counts' has changed to, `Money is everything.''' An accompanying cartoon shows three Santa Clauses around a sales chart. ``I don't want to go to Japan,'' says one Santa. ``Japan's disgusting,'' says another. The ostentatious Christmas Eve is a relatively new phenomenon in Japan, where the holiday has long been a family affair. Since the end of World War II, Japanese families have celebrated the holiday with a gift or two for each child, and a dinner of roast chicken and an ornately decorated Christmas cake. ``When I was a kid, Christmas usually meant dad would come home drunk, because it was bonus season,'' says one young father. ``Now we celebrate it as a family, even though we aren't at all Christian.'' The government estimates this nation of 122 million people has slightly more than a million Christians. Most other Japanese, 99 percent, practice both Buddhism and the indigenous Shinto religion. Japan's first Noel was about 400 years ago, when Christianity arrived with Western missionaries and merchants. The religion was unwelcome for almost three centuries, forcing believers to worship in secret. Today, Japanese worship freely and growing numbers of young non-Christians are attending Christmas Eve services, drawn by the universal theme of peace and goodwill.

DOC.HEAD: American Group Advising GIs On How to Avoid Gulf Duty
With PM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By GEORGE BOEHMER
DOC.TEXT: About 200 American soldiers have sought advice on how to avoid service in the Persian Gulf, and at least 30 are applying for conscientious objector status, an American counseling network says. But the U.S. military says the problem of soldiers not wanting to face possible combat is ``minuscule'' considering the number of those who are willing to go. The American group, which calls itself the Military Counseling Network, has begun operating throughout Germany to advise U.S. soldiers on their rights. They make contact with the GIs by handing out leaflets at the U.S. bases in Germany that the soldiers are being deployed from, said Andre Stoner, a member of the group. Stoner, 28, of Harrisonburg, Va., and his wife Cathy, 23, of Lancaster, Pa., advise the soldiers and their families from their home in Krastel, in the Hunsrueck region of Germany, about 90 miles west of Frankfurt. Janice Hill, 32, of Philadelphia, does the same from her home in Rottenburg, about 36 miles south of Stuttgart. And a Roman Catholic priest, the Rev. Mike Baxter, counsels soldiers in the northern port city of Bremen. ``We are a counseling group and advise the soldiers on how they can legally apply for conscientious objector status,'' Stoner said. ``We don't tell them to desert or to do anything illegal.'' He said the network, which is supported by church and peace groups in the United States, had received about 200 telephone calls from interested soldiers so far ``and at least 30 of them are in the process of applying for conscientious objector status.'' While some of the soldiers fit the traditional description of a conscientious objector who has an abhorrence for war of any kind, others do not, Stoner said. He said some of the soldiers were ``selective conscientious objectors,'' meaning they would ordinarily be willing to fight to protect freedom in the United States. ``But they say `I don't think this is a just war and I'm not willing to fight to protect some oil sheik and George Bush's political career,''' Stoner said. He said response had been so great that additional network members were called in from the United States to help advise soldiers. Baxter was among them. Baxter, 35, a priest with the Holy Cross order in Albany. N.Y., said he has been in Bremen just one week. ``I've been in contact over the phone with about 15 or 20 GIs. I've ... really advised concretely seven or eight, and they are in the process of applying for conscientious objector status,'' Baxter said. Baxter, who describes himself as a Christian pacifist, said the military was now requiring most soldiers being sent to Saudi Arabia to wait until they reach the gulf before applying for conscientious objector status. ``We're trying to submit the application here (in Germany) and fix an agreement with the military that these people do not have to handle weapons,'' Baxter said. Ms. Hill said she was also getting dozens of calls from soldiers and their wives. She said some of the soldiers had already gone AWOL, ``which is something we never advise anyone to do, because it's a lousy life.'' An Army spokesman in Heidelberg, Capt. Dee Jepson, said the Army does not consider conscientious objection to be a big problem. ``The problem...is minuscule,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bell Ringers Beware: The Profession Is Dangerous
With PM-Bell Choir, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report. ^By SYDNEY RUBIN
DOC.TEXT: A set of rules for bell ringers issued in 1694 warned: ``All you that do intend to ring, you undertake a dangerous thing.'' Three centuries later, the British Medical Journal has documented the truth of these words in an article that is a litany of bell ringers' bruises and broken bones. Dr. A.C. Lamont, a pediatric radiologist, and Dr. N.J.M. London of the Leicester Royal Infirmary surveyed injuries among church bell ringers. There are about 40,000 in England, and they ring bells from 3,000 towers each Sunday, at Easter and on Christmas. For the article, appearing Saturday, the doctors reviewed the last six years of ``Ringing World'' magazine, looking for articles on injuries and accidents. They advertised in the trade magazine for ringers who had suffered mishaps, and sent questionnaires to 20 active bell towers, bringing a response from 221 ringers. The injuries identified included torn fingernails, fractures, bruises, corneal abrasions, rope burns, extracted teeth, lacerations, accidental near hangings, pulled muscles, ruptured ligaments and heads caught in rope loops. Five deaths were counted. The doctors' survey indicated that about 724 injuries befall ringers in the British Isles each year, half of which require first aid or other medical attention. ``Many ringers who returned the questionnaires insisted that ringing is very safe, but our results show that this view is rather optimistic,'' the doctors wrote in the journal's Christmas issue. They added that pride may have prevented some bell ringers from reporting injuries. Learning to control a bell takes time and practice, the article notes. Pupils of pealing must develop coordination to strike the bell in its proper place at varying speeds and intervals while avoiding bodily damage, it said. Novices commonly fall prey to the most notorious hazard of bell ringing: the ``high speed lift.'' This occurs, the doctors wrote, when the bell's stay breaks, the bell goes out of balance and the ringer who forgets to release the rope is whisked towards the ceiling at a speed approaching 55 mph. One letter to the doctors described the harrowing moments after a bell weighing about 1,000 pounds went over balance and the bell ringer went with it. ``I could hear voices telling me to `Let Go, Let Go,' and all I could think was I am not going to drop that far onto the cement floor, so I kept going right to the top until my right hand hit the hole and my head hit the ceiling,'' the ringer wrote. ``I had no choice but to let go,'' ending up with a bruised elbow, black and blue hip and a `little finger that blew up like a balloon.'' Two children surveyed by the doctors had teeth knocked out by wayward ropes. An 80-year-old ringer had a rope fall over his head, tighten over his eyebrows and, on the upward swing, lacerated his forehead and scalp. Only a quick twist of the head prevented a full-scale scalping.

DOC.HEAD: UPI, FNN Owner Says It Can't Repay $20.7 Million Loan
DOC.TEXT: Infotechnology Inc., owner of United Press International and Financial News Network, says it could not repay a $20.7 million loan that was called in early. The lenders, Security Pacific National Bank and MidLantic National Bank, now have the right to foreclose on Infotechnology's 46 percent stock interest in FNN, a cable television network. The FNN stock was placed as collateral for the loan, which originally was due next July. The banks did not say whether they would exercise their foreclosure option. Security Pacific said in a statement: ``The credit is in default and the banks have moved to protect their interests.'' An Infotechnology spokeswoman said Friday the company's lack of cash made it impossible to pay the principal and interest on the loan, which was called in by Los Angeles-based Security Pacific. MidLantic is based in Laurel, N.J. The banks did not say why they called in the loan early. The Infotechnology spokeswoman, who asked not to be named, said the company believes the banks will not foreclose on the loan. She said Infotechnology would continue seeking buyers for its media subsidiaries to raise cash. The development was the latest blow to Infotechnology, whose FNN subsidiary reported a $72.5 million loss for its 1990 fiscal year. UPI, a news wire service, reportedly has been losing as much as $2.5 million a month. Last month, UPI union and management employees agreed to a 35 percent pay cut for 90 days to give the news service time to find a buyer. UPI, founded in 1907 as United Press, has changed ownership three times in eight years. FNN provides stock quotes, business and financial news, and sports information on a cable TV network to more than 35 million homes served by 3,500 in the United States and Canada. Separately, Infotechnology said its stock would be removed from the National Market System listing but will remain on the National Association of Secrities Dealers listing. Infotechnology said NASD had approved an exception to filing requirements. The exception relates to FNN's failure to meet Securities and Exchange Commission net worth requirements, and to late filing of its quarterly financial report for the period ending Sept. 30. The NASD granted Infotechnology a filing extension until Jan. 15, a deadline the company said it expects to meet.

DOC.HEAD: Ailing Pan Am Says It Wants to Accept TWA Buyout
DOC.TEXT: Pan Am and TWA, two of the oldest - and weakest - airlines, neared agreement on a business marriage that would end their longtime rivalry and change the cast of characters in a deeply troubled industry. But Pan Am may have to seek bankruptcy protection anyway. Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airways, had proposed a buyout of Pan Am Corp. last weekend in a deal worth about $375 million. Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett responded with a letter Friday saying the deal could be ``advantageous to our shareholders, employees and other constituencies.'' But in a frank admission of Pan Am's critical money shortage, Plaskett said Pan Am would need an infusion of cash before the purchase could be completed. ``Under the circumstances, it would be futile to enter into a transaction without any provision for bridge financing, especially if TWA were not to commit to close the transaction regardless of our financial situation,'' Plaskett said. Icahn sent a letter to TWA's employees saying he had been considering ``the possibility of providing Pan Am with debtor-in-possession financing. This is a type of financing which might be possible if Pan Am decides to file a petition for reorganization in bankruptcy.'' In an interview published in today's New York Times, Icahn said of a bridge loan: ``Even though it's going to be tough, I'm going to make every effort I can.'' Combining TWA and Pan Am would mark the end of independence for Pan Am, which pioneered overseas air travel but has lost staggering amounts of money over the past decade. It has survived by selling itself in pieces. Earlier this year it agreed to sell London routes and some other assets to United Airlines for $400 million. Icahn had written to Plaskett a letter dated Sunday that offered to buy Pan Am's 150 million outstanding shares for $1.50 a share in cash and $1 a share in either preferred stock or notes. ``In these extremely complicated and troubled times for the airline industry, a combination of TWA and Pan Am might offer both of us the opportunity to compete with the three major U.S. airlines,'' Icahn wrote. The industry's three dominant players are American, United Airlines and Delta Air Lines. Friday was the deadline for Pan Am to accept. In his responding letter, Plaskett asked Icahn to ``send us promptly a detailed term sheet indicating among other things the basis on which you would be willing to provide bridge financing, precisely what you envision as conditions of closing, and the specific terms of the securities you are proposing to offer.'' Pan Am's letter, which didn't say how much cash was needed, was released shortly after Standard & Poor's issued a statement raising the possibility that Pan Am would have to seek bankruptcy court refuge if it couldn't raise cash. The airline industry is approaching record losses because of fuel inflation incited by the Persian Gulf crisis and slackening demand for air travel. Weak airlines such as Pan Am and TWA are under the biggest strain. Icahn's offer for Pan Am came at the same time he announced plans to sell all of TWA's London routes and some other assets to a healthier rival, American Airlines, in a package worth $625 million.

DOC.HEAD: Noted Palestinian Writer, Lecturer Dies
DOC.TEXT: Ishak Mousa Husseini, a noted Palestinian writer and teacher who sought to explain Arab history to the West, has died, family members say. He was 86. Arab leaders including PLO chairman Yasser Arafat and Lebanese President Elias Hrawi have cabled condolences to the family of Husseini, who died Tuesday at his home in Arab east Jerusalem and was buried Wednesday, family members said. The cause of death was not dislosed. Husseini was the author of 22 books and numerous academic essays during a teaching career that spanned more than four decades. He taught at Jerusalem's Arabic College, the American University of Beirut and the American University of Cairo. In 1982, he founded the Women's Art College, which is part of Jerusalem University, and was its president until his death. His fellow Palestinian writers in 1986 gave him the honorary title of ``dean of Palestinian literature.'' An expert in Semitic languages, Husseini was a leading figure in the Arabic linguistic academies in Egypt and Iraq. He often lectured in Canada and the United States and sought to explain Islam and Arab history to the West. Among his books is ``Moslem Brothers,'' a study on how fundamentalism began to work its way into Islam. His best-known fiction work is ``Memoirs of Chicken,'' written in 1943. It was considered controversial in the Arab world because it criticized the low status given to Arab women. Husseini's eldest son, Hatam Husseini, a political science lecturer at Shaw University in Raleigh, N.C., said Arafat wrote a personal letter saying, ``I have a special love for him. ... His death is a big loss.'' Hrawi's message of condolence recalled his time as a student of Husseini. Many of the elder Husseini's students went on to become professors, ministers and diplomats, said Husseini's son. At least 3,000 people attended Husseini's funeral on Wednesday, and many literary figures put special wreaths on his grave near Jerusalem's Temple Mount, or Harem es-Sharif. Hatam Husseini said that as a memorial to his father, the family will publish his complete body of work in English. He is survived by his wife, Alawieh, and three children.

DOC.HEAD: Wesley Bell Ringers Still Strong After Quarter-Century
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: For more than 25 years, Ed Duncan has been hearing bells. From tiny silver melody bells to the biggest, a thunderous 22-pounder, he loves them all. Even the answering machine at Duncan's home has a message telling callers they've reached the Wesley Bell Ringers, the nation's largest handbell choir. It all began in 1963, when Duncan's pastor at the Christ United Methodist Church asked him to establish a group to give the congregation's teen-agers something to do. ``One day I was idly thumbing through a catalog of church supplies and my eyes lit on this set of 25 bells you could buy,'' said Duncan, who plays organ and piano and teaches high school physics. ``I thought it seemed like something the kids could do right off the bat,'' he said. Over the years, the group has had as few as nine players to its current 30, the numbers changing because Duncan never turns away a potential player. ``That may be the thing I'm the most proud of, anybody can play that wants to. They don't have to be musicians,'' he said. Duncan arranges nearly all of the music for the group and said it's like scoring for three keyboard instruments and a percussion ensemble. There are several octaves of bells, and at least three sets are playing all the time. ``Each kid in the section has the same music, then we assign them a certain number of bells and teach them where the notes are located on the staff,'' he said. White-gloved, the bell-ringers perform in a complicated choreography that produces a rich sound sometimes reminiscent of a pipe organ. ``Spectacular!'' one listener was heard to say at a recent performance. The group has played in every state of the union, including performances at the U.S. Capitol, Disneyland and Disney World. Christmas programs are devoted mostly to carols, but the choir's repertoire includes popular, sacred and classical music. Last year, the bell ringers were guests of the Mormon Tabernacle Choir for a Christmas performance and recently were chosen to perform at a convention of bell choir directors. ``I really can't say with certainty, but as nearly as I know it's the biggest choir in sheer volume of bells and largest number of people. So I keep saying it's the biggest,'' Duncan said. ``And the bell manufacturers say its true.'' For the players, the group has come to represent an important bond with other members of their faith. Because of the Mormon Church's predominance in Utah, the group's teen-agers someties are the only Methodists in their school, and the choir offers a comforting sense of community. ``It's nice knowing you're not the only Methodist in town,'' said May Thomas, 19, who has played with the group for two years. Every summer, the group tours for five weeks. Fund-raisers and proceeds from sales of their recordings help finance the trip. Linda Gross, a parent volunteer who handles publicity, said the church has a fund set aside to pay Duncan and help with the summer tours, but he never takes the money. ``He pays his assistant a little and uses the rest is used for scholarships to get everyone on tour,'' she said. Jerry Moore, 18, a four-year veteran, said the ties run so deep between the players that he likens them to a big family. ``This definitely brings friends closer,'' he said. ``You become lifelong friends.''

DOC.HEAD: Drive-By Shooting of Children Elicits Shrugs From Community
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Xaziver in final graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: People in the neighborhood where five children were wounded by rivals in a drive-by shooting shrugged off the new level of mayhem in the nation's capital with shakes of the head and a what-can-you-do look in their eyes. ``That's the atmosphere around here,'' said a 28-year-old man who moved to suburban Maryland five years ago but returned Friday to visit his parents in the Shaw neighborhood. Even the classmates of four of the victims - the fifth was a 6-year-old girl - seemed to take the Thursday afternoon shootings in stride, said a teacher at the imposing cinder-block Shaw Junior High School. ``They look at it like, `It's just the neighborhood,''' said the teacher, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``It's another day at the office. No big deal.'' There was no rush of counselors into classrooms to calm the fears of students who must walk the same tough streets, said the teacher, who seemed surprised when asked how the school was reacting. In fact, he said, the students generally did not even mention the shootings, and no special effort was made to draw them out. On Friday, three youths - one age 16 and two age 14 - were charged in the shootings and police said they were looking for two more 14-year-old suspects. Meanwhile, two of the victims, including the 6-year-old girl, were released from Children's Hospital. The three others remained hospitalized. Some of those contacted in the neighborhood Friday seemed as if they were beyond shock over violence in this city of 625,000. Police say the city has had a record 471 homicides this year, 30 of them juveniles. In addition, 1,163 people have been wounded by gunfire, 204 of them juveniles. A 30-year-old man who lives near the neighborhood said, ``I'm very paranoid. I think that's what keeps me alive.'' Yet he wouldn't think of moving to safer environs. ``I love it too much,'' he said. ``It's intriguing, a constant mystery. To be here and survive here - it's a challenge.'' Shaw, less than two miles from the White House, is one of the city's poorest neighborhoods, but an economic upturn is expected next year when a subway station opens in the area. Today, the area where the shootings occurred is a mixture of single-family row houses - some with small but carefully manicured yards and Christmas decorations - houses subdivided into apartments and boarded-up buildings. A baseball field and a playground are nearby. Thursday's shootings resulted not from a random act of violence but from an altercation a week or so ago between two loosely organized groups of young people, Police Chief Isaac Fulwood said. ``I don't know whether it was drug-related or not, but I doubt it,'' Fulwood said angrily. ``Don't make everything drug-related; it cheapens the violence.'' In the old days, he said, the dispute could have been settled with a simple fist fight. He blamed the escalation on easy access to guns, pervasive violence on television and a breakdown in parental inculcation of values in children. The chief said he has spoken to young people about shootings and has found they show ``no remorse, not the first tear. There's no sense that there's anything wrong.'' The attack about 3 p.m. Thursday involved multiple gunshots by assailants in a car passing by the victims. None of the weapons was immediately recovered, Fulwood said. The names of those arrested were not released because of their ages, and Fulwood said no decision had been made on whether to try any as adults. Three were arraigned Friday in juvenile court. Xaziver Paul, 6, and Troy Gray, 15, were discharged from Children's Hospital on Friday, spokeswoman Barbara Cire said. Brian Lewis, 12, was listed in good condition. John Olden, 13, and Clarence Richmond, 14, were upgraded from serious to fair condition.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Suspends Military Aid to Guatemala
DOC.TEXT: Angered by slow progress in an investigation of the death of an American innkeeper, the State Department is suspending its $2.8 million military aid program to Guatemala. The action announced Friday stemmed from the death June 8 of Michael DeVine, 49, originally of Belleville, Ill., who lived in Guatemala for almost 20 years. At the time of his death, he was operating a hotel-restaurant in the northern part of the country. DeVine's body was found at the side of a road, his head partly severed and his hands tied behind his back. A private investigator reportedly has uncovered evidence pointing to involvement by a local Guatemalan Army unit. ``We have concluded that it would not be appropriate to continue a normal military assistance relationship with Guatemala at this time,'' a State Department statement said. It noted that the Guatemalan government ``rarely takes action to thoroughly investigate'' violators of human rights. It also expressed ``deep disappointment with the lack of commitment of the government of Guatemala to protect human rights.'' As an example, it cited the killing on Dec. 2 of 14 civilians in Atitlan province and the wounding of 19 others. Two servicemen were arrested and are still in custody. Officials in Guatemala City had little immediate comment on the announcement. President Vinicio Cerezo told reporters only that ``the government will make known its position at the appropriate time.'' Guatemala refused U.S. military aid in 1977 rather than accept the human rights conditions that were attached. The assistance gradually resumed in the mid-1980s. As for the DeVine case, State Department officials said U.S. diplomats pressed the Guatemalan government over a period of months to complete the investigation before Cerezo turns power over to an elected successor next month. But they said the investigation is at a standstill. The officials, who requested anonymity, said Guatemalan authorities have not acted on two outstanding arrest warrants. The authorities also have refused, despite U.S. requests, to question the former zone commander at the military base near the area where DeVine was killed as well as the former head of intelligence at the base. The U.S. officials said they are not certain as to the motives for DeVine's killing. Cerezo has acknowledged that the security forces could have been responsible for DeVine's death.

DOC.HEAD: Report Calls for Break in State Control of Economy
DOC.TEXT: An extensive Western review of the Soviet economy maps a bold strategy for a break with 70 years of government control, but whether Mikhail Gorbachev can carry out the reforms is very much an open question. The study, commissioned by the leaders of the United States and six other Western powers, called for Soviet citizens, already suffering from shortages of food and other basic goods, to accept even more economic pain in the short term. It prescribed such bitter economic medicine as the removal of price controls on basic commodities while at the same time imposing wage controls on workers. The study, prepared by the International Monetary Fund and three other Western economic organizations, conceded that unemployment would rise in the short term and economic output, which is already plummeting, would fall further as inefficient industries are phased out. However, it said only a cold-turkey approach to reform, similar to the methods being used in Poland, would work in the Soviet Union. ``The imperative is to make sufficient progress at the beginning so that reform is seen as an irreversible break with the past and the process gains an unstoppable momentum,'' the study said. But Western experts noted that even the Warsaw government has had trouble selling its austerity program, with Poles expressing their unhappiness in recent national elections. And Gorbachev does not start with the same base of popular support that the Solidarity movement had in Poland. Indeed, the Soviet president is having to battle with 15 restive republics who are tired of the central government botching the country's economy and want more freedom to try their own formulas. Still, U.S. analysts were optimistic the Soviets eventually will be able to embark on the radical reform proposed by the study, which was begun last July at the direction of President Bush and the leaders of Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Ed Hewett, a Soviet specialist at the Brookings Institution, a Washington-based research organization, said that while the odds were low that the proposed reforms could be implemented immediately, he would not rule out the chances that such changes could take hold within the next year. Hewett suggested it may take a true coalition government spanning the political spectrum with strong representation from the republics to push such a measure through. ``While it may seem difficult to see how such a program could be implemented now, politics in the Soviet Union is moving very fast and six months is a long time in Soviet politics,'' he said. The 50-page report supported Bush's contention that large amounts of direct Western aid should not be provided to the Soviets until they begin implementing more fundamental reforms of their economy. In the short term, the report said, Western countries should emphasize providing technical assistance to the Soviets in such areas as banking, law and transportation. It also said that targeted aid to help the Soviets with environmental problems and the modernization of their energy production system would be useful. ``The general recommendations of the report are recommendations that the United States will support and subscribe to,'' Secretary of State James A. Baker said. His comment indicated that the document is likely to form the blueprint for Western assistance to the Soviets in the next year. The study was ordered at the Houston summit in an effort to break a deadlock between French and German leaders who were pushing for an immediate $15 billion aid package and the reluctance of Bush and others to go along with that proposal. The study said that without the implementation of a major and far-reaching reform program, direct Western aid would be ``of little or no lasting value.'' But it held out the promise that once the reforms were implemented, such aid would be forthcoming. The report was prepared by the 154-nation International Monetary Fund and its sister organization, the World Bank; the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet Economy
DOC.TEXT: Here in brief are the principal economic recommendations made Friday by the International Monetary Fund and three other organizations in a report on reforming the Soviet economy. PRICES: Controls on prices must be removed quickly on many products in an effort to end shortages. For certain key commodities, the movement to market prices may need to be phased in over three years. WAGES: In order to insure that the initial spurt of prices does not trigger inflationary wage demands, wages should be controlled ``in the early stages'' of price decontrol. However, the wage policy should provide a floor as well as a ceiling on employee wages. MONEY: Interest rates should be raised, controls on bank credits to enterprises must be enforced and banks should have to hold a fraction of deposits as reserves on deposit with the central bank. PRIVATE OWNERSHIP: Small firms should be privatized quickly ``through outright sales to infividuals, cooperatives and others.'' Larger state-owned companies should have commercially oriented management with slower privatization, perhaps through conversion of enterprises into joint stock companies, owned by one of several state holding companies, or owned through mutual funds. SOCIAL SAFETY NET: Policies are needed to deal with the rising unemployment that will occur as inefficient businesses are phased out and also provide protection for low-income earners to compensate for the rising inflation once prices are decontrolled.

DOC.HEAD: Troops in Gulf Put on Higher Alert After Israeli Missile Firing
With PM-Gulf-US Forces Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An unannounced test-firing of an Israeli missile sent American forces in the Persian Gulf area briefly scrambling into a heightened state of alert, Pentagon sources say. The U.S. action Friday was a precaution against the possibility that Israel might have been launching a preemptive strike against Iraq, said one source, who like others spoke on condition of anonymity. ``Israel has been known to do preemptive strikes before,'' the source said, referring to Israel's 1981 bombing of an Iraqi nuclear plant. The 280,000 U.S. troops in the gulf area were put on heightened alert after U.S. intelligence sources detected the Israeli missile being fired and before it was clear the weapon was heading into the Mediterranean, the sources said. The alert lasted only a short time, they said. Israel feels threatened by Iraq's increasingly sophisticated ballistic missile capability, hich raises the possibility of a chemical weapons attack on Israel, especially if the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf attacks Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Experts Project More Than 380 Will Die in Traffic Crashes
DOC.TEXT: Safety experts are projecting between 380 and 480 traffic deaths during the four-day Christmas holiday. The National Safety Council each year estimates the number of holiday traffic fatalities for the heavily traveled holiday period, which began at 6 p.m. Friday and ends 11:59 p.m. Tuesday. Last year, 372 people died during the three-day Christmas holiday. This year's projection is higher because Christmas falls on a Tuesday, extending the holiday period another day, council statistician Terry Miller said. Safety officials say the death toll could be lower than in previous four-day Christmas periods because high gasoline prices may deter people from making long car trips or hopping from social event to event. ``People may just decide to limit their driving to necessary errands, going to the store and other things of that nature,'' Miller said. ``But it's hard to predict people's behavior in such situations.'' The council makes its projections by comparing the average number of traffic deaths each day this year with historical figures on traffic fatalities during past holiday seasons. The council also projects that between 350 and 450 people will die during the four-day New Year holiday period.

DOC.HEAD: `Candyman' Jerry Winters Found Guilty Of Racketeering, Extortion
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Jerry Winters built a candy empire, door by door. In the mid-1980s, teens were selling his chocolate in 33 states. He was making over $30 million a year. A business magazine named him ``Entrepreneur of the Year.'' But reality was a long way from sugar and spice for the ``Candyman,'' convicted Friday on five counts of racketeering, extortion and interstate fraud. Two associates were also convicted of racketeering and extortion. Six others were acquitted. Prosecutors portrayed Winters as a hot-tempered tyrant whose secrets to success included baseball bat beatings and torched delivery vans. U.S. District Court Judge Maryanne Trump Barry, noting his penchant for violence and use of aliases, denied a request for house arrest. The millionaire will spend the holidays in jail. ``This was, in a nutshell, a case of violence and threatened violence for the sake of a buck,'' said Barry, pointing at Winters' history of ordering beatings for some employees and competitors. After eight days of deliberations, the jury convicted Winters of two counts of federal racketeering, two counts of extortion and one count of interstate fraud. He faces up to 80 years in prison when he is sentenced in February. Winters, who did not testify, agreed to forfeit to the government $650,000 he obtained by racketeering. Before the jury filed in the courtroom with the verdicts, the heavyset Winters stood in an aisle, locked embracing his wife, Maureen. He sat impassively as the guilty verdicts were read. About 50 witnesses took the stand in the seven-week trial. Many testified that Winters' business skills included violence, threats and arson to stay atop the door-to-door candy sales industry. Winters' organization pulled in an estimated $32 million a year, with agents in 33 states, from Washington to New York. He and his agents made their money by recruiting teens to sell candy under such names as ``Student Aid Program,'' ``Inner City Youth Corps,'' ``Midwestern Youth Opportunities,'' and ``Fund Raiser Products Inc.'' All the groups operated strictly for profit. Winters, of Norwood, was named Entrepreneur of the Year by Venture Magazine, and New Jersey Monthly Magazine cited his organization as one of the 10 best places to work in the state. But Assistant U.S. Attorney Victory Ashrafi presented a bleaker story. Jurors were told of several cases in which Winters beat employees and competitors into submission for selling rival candy or infringing on his territory. Defense attorney Bruce Cutler told jurors that Winters was a churchgoing pillar of the community, who rose from poverty by selling his grandmother's fudge door to door. Cutler did not return calls Friday from New York, where he was representing reputed mob boss John Gotti in a hearing in federal court. Also convicted were Paul Ray, 35, of Texas, and Darrin Casper, 24, of Virginia. Ray was convicted of one count of racketeering and faces up to 20 years in prison. Casper was convicted of one count each of extortion and interstate racketeering and faces a prison term of up to 25 years. There was enthusiastic backthumping among the acquitted defendants: Anthony Allen, 24, of Passaic; Ralph Vilchez, 37, of North Bergen; Kevin Miller, 38, of Tappan, N.Y.; James Martin, 41, and Ronald Barks, 38, both of California; and Andrew Hanna, 37, of Las Vegas.

DOC.HEAD: Dapper Don Will Spend Christmas in Prison
DOC.TEXT: John Gotti, accused of ordering the murder of another reputed mobster to seize control of the country's largest crime syndicate, will spend Christmas in jail after being denied bail. U.S. District Judge I. Leo Glasser of Brooklyn decided against bail after a three-hour hearing Friday that was closed to the public and the press. At the hearing, prosecutors played tapes that secretly recorded conversations held in Gotti's Little Italy hangout, the Ravenite social club. Prosecutors maintain the tapes prove Gotti is a threat to potential witnesses and he and two co-defendants should be held without bail. The three men - Gotti, 50, alleged underboss Frank Locascio, 58, and reputed mob counselor Salvatore Gravano, 45 - have been jailed without bail since Dec. 11, when federal agents arrested them on racketeering charges including allegations Gotti engineered the killings of mob rivals. Law enforcers described the trio as the top leadership of the Gambino crime family. Prosecutors claim Gotti ordered the murder of his predecessor, Paul Castellano, to take over the Gambino family. The next hearing in the case was set for Jan. 18. Gotti has two nicknames: the Dapper Don and the Teflon Don, the first a reference to his natty wardrobe and the second to his three acquittals in the past five years. On Friday he wore a charcoal suit with a bright red, green and black floral-print tie. Speaking to reporters outside the courthouse, Gotti's lawyer, Bruce Cutler, said his client was disappointed by the ruling, but not surprised. ``It's the same menu in a different restaurant,'' Cutler said, referring to the latest effort to prosecute Gotti. Glasser closed the bail hearing after ruling the defendants' right to a free trial overrides the right of the press and the public to observe the proceedings. He reopened the courtroom to announce his decision to deny bail.

DOC.HEAD: Stricken Woman's Father, Demonstrators Exchange Sympathetic Words
LaserPhoto SPF1
DOC.TEXT: Nancy Cruzan's father and anti-euthanasia demonstrators exchanged sympathetic words on the steps of a hospital where the brain-injured woman lies dying. Meanwhile, a federal judge Friday criticized activists who want state health officials to restore a feeding tube removed from Nancy Cruzan last week. The action was the latest in a series of petitions denied since food and water were withdrawn Dec. 14 from Ms. Cruzan, who has been in a persistent vegetative state for nearly eight years. Joe and Joyce Cruzan obtained court permission to have the tube removed after providing testimony that their daughter would not want to live in her present condition. ``I guess I'm very concerned about you people being out here, particularly the young people,'' Cruzan told about a dozen people bundled in parkas, caps and mittens in 15-degree weather. The demonstrators have been holding a round-the-clock vigil. Cruzan came bearing a peace offering. He gave a coffee maker to David Hall of Fort Worth, Texas, director of a right-to-life group. ``Our prayers are with you,'' Hall said Friday, fighting back tears. ``It's a very tough time, but we don't begin to think we could understand or go through what you have gone through. We're standing out here praying and doing all that we can do in a way that we feel God would have us do.'' ``And we are doing the same,'' said Cruzan, a 55-year-old construction worker. ``We are doing what we feel God has directed us to do, and that is to carry out what we believe. We believe we are in the best position to know what would be Nancy's wishes.'' Ms. Cruzan, 33, has been in a vegetative state since a car crash nearly eight years ago. Doctors are convinced she will not recover. She was expected to die within two weeks of the tube removal and was in deteriorating condition today. Demonstrators have pitched two tents on the lawn of the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, drawing power from the building for their heaters and coffee pots. They planned to sleep there and in nearby cars, despite a prediction of up to 5 inches of snow and minus-30 wind chill overnight. Nineteen people were arrested Tuesday after they burst into the hospital and tried to reach Ms. Cruzan's room to reconnect her feeding tube. Five of the arrested demonstrators have been released on bond. The others vow to remain in custody until she is fed or dies. In the ruling issued Friday in Kansas City, U.S. District Judge Dean Whipple criticized protesters for going from court to court, seeking an order to restore the feeding tube. ``This court is mindful of the fact that this is the fifth petition of its kind filed this week in various Missouri courts - the previous four petitions having been dismissed,'' the ruling said. ``In light of the history of this case, this court finds that any further action would be frivolous at best, and an abuse of the legal process,'' the ruling said. The judge had set a hearing Friday on the petition filed by members of Operation Rescue, a nationwide anti-abortion group. But Whipple canceled the hearing and issued the written ruling instead. Court employees said the judge had been besieged by more than 2,000 phone calls by people asking him to intervene. On Friday morning the Missouri Supreme Court denied a second request that it order Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube restored. The high court and a Missouri appeals court on Thursday turned down similar requests.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Governor Grants Clemency to 25 Women Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Prison doors will open soon for 25 women convicted of crimes, including murder, that out-going Gov. Richard Celeste says were committed while the women suffered physical or emotional abuse. Celeste said Friday he granted clemency after studying 105 cases in which ``battered woman syndrome'' was a suspected factor. The governor acted after the Ohio Supreme Court and the Legislature established the syndrome as a defense against murder or other crimes. That defense was not available at the time to the women Celeste plans to free. Celeste, who leaves office Jan. 14, included a stipulation that the released inmates must perform 200 hours of community service in domestic violence programs. Paperwork and other red tape probably will mean that the women will not be released until after Christmas, he said. Most of the inmates were convicted of serious crimes including murder, manslaughter and assault. In four of the 25 cases, the women have served less than two years for the crimes they committed. Celeste stipulated that they must serve at least two years before their release. Celeste told a news conference that of the cases he reviewed, 32 were sent back to the state Parole Board for further review and 48 were rejected. He said about 15 other cases remained under review, and that he would announce his decisions in those cases in January. Celeste said Ohio became the last state to recognize the plight of battered women when the Ohio Supreme Court in March ruled that evidence of battered woman syndrome is permissible at trials. In those situations, he said women face physical or psychological abuse, frequently repeated and intensified, ``resulting in feelings of guilt ... a sense of isolation, and finally must submit to violence.'' After the Ohio Supreme Court ruling, the state Legislature enacted a law allowing evidence of battered woman syndrome to be used as a defense. Some of Celeste's decisions ran counter to recommendations of the parole board. But he said he read each case at least twice and consulted with court and other officials before becoming convinced that they were victims. Celeste said the parole board does not cite what criteria it uses in its decisions.

DOC.HEAD: German Govs Decide Not to Limit Jewish Immigration
With PM-Israel-Soviet Jews, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Germany's state governors have decided not to limit immigration by Jewish refugees from the Soviet Union who have been streaming into the old capital of the Third Reich in search of a home. ``We are moved by the trust that the Soviet Jews are showing toward Germany, where horrible things happened to Jews in the past,'' Gerhard Schroeder, the governor of Lower Saxony, said after the decision in Munich Friday. About 1,000 Soviet Jewish refugees have arrived this month in Berlin, the first major German city along the rail lines from the east. As many as 4,000 Soviet Jews are believed to have arrived in Germany this year. Officials reported a surge in the emigration of Jews toward Germany this week because of worries that th 16 governors meeting in Munich might set a quota on the number of Jews who could settle in Germany. Another factor in the Soviet emigration is fear that growing political tensions and economic hardships will lead to pogroms, as has occurred in Russia's past. Vocal anti-Semitism is on the rise in the Soviet Union. The governors decided not to establish any limits on Jewish immigration. Under the current rules, a Soviet visa is practically all that Jews need to move to Germany. Bavaria spokesman Wolf-Dieter Remmele said the governors ``expressed their basic willingness to accept the Soviet Jews, without any specific numbers being named.'' ``By all means, we will care for them,'' Schroeder said at a news conference in Munich. Jewish leaders in Germany have been urging a liberal acceptance policy, citing the nation's historical responsibility because of the Nazi murder of 6 million Jews. Under the current practice, Soviet Jews arriving in Berlin are guided to a counseling center, where authorities, after making sure they are Jewish, give them an orientation and house them at emergency shelters. After temporary stays in Berlin, the Jews are resettled in other parts of the country.

DOC.HEAD: Arabs Quietly Drop Opposition to Israel's U.N. Membership
With PM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: For the first time in eight years, Arab nations let the General Assembly recess its autumn session without making their annual effort to kick Israel out of the U.N. body. The Arabs apparently decided that challenging Israeli membership would have complicated the delicate diplomatic arrangements related to the Persian Gulf crisis, U.N. officials said Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. At Washington's urging, Israel has refrained from direct involvement in the crisis, while the United States accommodated its Arab allies in the anti-Iraq alliance by supporting three Security Council resolutions critical of Israel. On Thursday, the U.N. Security Council unanimously approved a referendum urging Israel to halt deportation of Palestinians from the occupied West Bank and Gaza. It also calls on the United Nations to monitor the safety of Palestinians there. The vote was sharply denounced by Israeli officials and Jewish organizations in the United States; Iraq and the Palestine Liberation Organization said the resolution did not go far enough. But it won the approval of Egypt and Syria, two Arab states that have troops in the U.S.-led multinational alliance pitted against Iraq. Since 1982, Arab nations have made an annual attempt to oust Israel by challenging its right to sit in the General Assembly among other ``peace-loving states.'' This year, the Arabs had planned to introduce a motion that Israel's U.N. credentials be accepted so long as the Jewish state does not represent ``Palestinian and other Arab territories occupied by Israel since 1967.'' Those areas, according to the amendment, include Jerusalem, the West Bank, the Gaza Strip and the Golan Heights. But none of the Arab delegations introduced the measure before the assembly recessed for the holiday, U.N. spokesman Fred Eckhard said. Israel captured Arab east Jerusalem from Jordan in the 1967 Arab-Israeli War, and has annexed it. Israel claims Jerusalem as its capital, and says it will never give the city up. It has also occupied the West Bank and Gaza Strip since 1967. Most countries reject Israel's claim on Jerusalem, pointing to a 1948 General Assembly plan that would have made Jerusalem an international city and established two countries, Israel and Palestine.

DOC.HEAD: Hair, Lint and Even Peanut Debris Blamed for Glitch in Shuttle Computers
DOC.TEXT: Lint, hair and even part of a peanut were found clogging an air filter designed to help cool two computers that failed on the shuttle Columbia's last mission. The clogged debris caused the two monitors to overheat, forcing the space agency to control the shuttle's $15 million Astro space observatory primarily from the ground, NASA spokeswoman Patricia Phillips said Friday. The debris appeared to be only partially responsible, however, Phillips said. Engineers from Kennedy and Marshall Space Flight centers determined that some components in an electrical circuit had failed also. Within hours after the Dec. 2 launch, astronauts smelled something hot and shut down the first computer and switched to a backup. Days later, the telltale odor reappeared and the crew shut down the second computer. The electronics are 7 to 9 years old and have a history of trouble, Phillips said. Marshall scientists had begun to redesign them even before their failure during the Columbia mission. New electronics will be ready by the time space shuttle Atlantis flies next in April 1992, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Buchwald Says `Coming to America' Ruling is Gift to Hollywood
DOC.TEXT: In a decision that may help unravel the mystery of Hollywood studio financing, a judge has ruled Paramount Pictures used an ``unconscionable'' formula to deny Art Buchwald royalties for the blockbuster film ``Coming to America.'' Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider said Friday that Buchwald, a Pulitzer Prize-winning humor columnist and author, and his producing partner deserve a fair share of the net profits from the Eddie Murphy film. The judge ruled that the studio used an ``unconscionable'' formula for computing the net. The judge had ruled earlier that Buchwald's 1982 script treatment, ``King for a Day,'' submitted to Paramount, formed the basis for ``Coming to America.'' Paramount and Murphy had denied there was any similarity and the studio refused to honor its agreement with Buchwald and producer Alain Bernheim. Buchwald hailed the ruling against accounting practices by Paramount as a Christmas gift to Hollywood's creative community while the studio denounced it as a blow to the free market system. The studio also maintained the movie, which grossed some $360 million, never produced any net profits. ``The court concludes that the ... provisions of Paramount's net profit formula are unconscionable,'' Schneider said in the 36-page written decision. He ordered a third phase of the trial to be held next year to determine the exact amount of damages due to Buchwald and Bernheim from Paramount. Attorney Pierce O'Donnell, who represents Buchwald and Bernheim, said he expects a multimillion dollar award. In court papers, Buchwald and Bernheim said they were entitled to royalties of up to $14.6 million. ``This may be the dawn of a new era of leveling the playing field in Hollywood,'' O'Donnell said. An excited Buchwald said from his Washington, D.C. home that he felt the judge's decision would spur change. ``They haven't been challenged for a long time on how they keep their books,'' Buchwald said. ``Now they're going to get a lot of lawsuits.'' Paramount lawyer Charles Diamond suggested the decision would have no impact on studio accounting and that the studio would prevail on appeal, which has not yet been filed. Paramount issued a statement denouncing Schneider's decision saying, ``The decision is a threat to the free market system.'' Among Paramount's financial practices singled out as unfair were excessive overhead and interest fees charged to film costs. ``Paramount's charge of a flat 15 percent for overhead yields huge profits even though the overhead charges do not even remotely correspond to the actual costs incurred by Paramount,'' the judge said. Diamond said Schneider was trying to rewrite Paramount's widely accepted policy. It calls for the studio to recoup its costs for a movie plus another 75 percent of that figure before it begins sharing net profits with participants such as Buchwald and Bernheim. Under their contract, Buchwald and Bernheim were entitled to up to 40 percent of the film's net profits. After a lengthy period of developing Buchwald's idea into a script, Paramount abandoned the project in 1985. ``Coming to America'' came out the following year. Buchwald's 1982 synopsis involved a young member of royalty from a mythical African kingdom who comes to the United States and is deposed in his absence. He winds up in a Washington ghetto working in a fast food restaurant where he meets and marries a young black woman. In the Murphy movie, a prince from a mythical African kingdom comes to New York in search of a bride, winds up in a ghetto working in a fast food restaurant, meets a young black woman and marries her.

DOC.HEAD: White House Wants Additional Medicaid Cuts
DOC.TEXT: The White House wants to cut an additional $18.7 billion from Medicare over the next five fiscal years. According to documents obtained Friday, that included $2.7 billion from the program in the next fiscal year in addition to the nearly $6 billion agreed to in the deficit reduction package in October. The extra cuts would come from payments to physicians and hospitals in fiscal years 1992 through 1996. The $500 billion deficit-reduction package covered five fiscal years, including the current one that began Oct. 1, and called for trimming $42 billion from Medicare over the period. Medicare is spending about $110 billion this year to provide health insurance to 33 million elderly and disabled Americans. The proposal is outlined in documents drawn up by the White House Office of Management and Budget in response to the Department of Health and Human Services' fiscal 1992 budget request. The Associated Press obtained a copy of the documents. In February, President Bush will present his budget proposals to Congress for the year that begins Oct. 1, 1991. Teaching hospitals would take the largest hit in OMB's ``pass-back'' plan. In the next fiscal year, payments to these hospitals would be cut $1.5 billion, and over five years the toll would be $9.3 billion. Reimbursements to physicians would be trimmed by $250 million next fiscal year, with Congress choosing from among a list of options. OMB also said it wants $5 million to establish a ``clearing house'' that would keep track of employment-based or other private health insurance. This would help HHS enforce a law requiring that for a worker over 65 who is covered by health insurance through his or her employer, the private insurance must be asked first to pay the claim. In these cases, Medicare is the secondary payer, but often patients don't disclose their private insurance and then Medicare pays when it shouldn't. Under OMB's proposal, a line would be added to W-2 forms requiring disclosure of health insurance coverage. These forms are provided for every worker by their employer to the Internal Revenue Service.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Threatens Veto Over Budget Provision
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says House Democrats are trying to renege on the budget agreement adopted last fall and he will veto any bill passed under a new House rule proposed by theDemocrats. If provisions of the agreement are rescinded, ``How can we expect the agreement to be taken seriously?'' Bush asked in a letter Friday to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. The issue is: Who estimates the dollar amount of certain spending and tax proposals, the Office of Management and Budget - an arm of the White House - or the Congressional Budget Office, a part of Congress?
