The budget agreement provided that OMB would make the estimates, but earlier this month the House Democratic Caucus voted overwhelmingly to back a House rule under which lawmakers would rely on estimates made by the Congressional Budget Office. The estimates must be made for proposed changes in so-called ``entitlement'' spending such as Medicare, or for tax changes. Entitlement spending amounts to roughly half the budget. Under the agreement, anyone proposing a change in one of those areas must propose an offset - either reduced spending in some other entitlement program or a tax increase. The rule is to be considered on the first day of the new congressional session, Jan. 3. ``In order to preserve the integrity of the budget agreement, I urge you to prevent the adoption of any rule that would violate our agreement,'' Bush wrote Foley. ``And in order to preserve confidence in that agreement, I must advise you that I will veto any bill that contains language such as that specified in the rule approved by the Democratic Caucus,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested For Lowering Himself Down the Statue of Liberty
DOC.TEXT: A man lowered himself by rope down the Statue of Liberty and was finally arrested when officers set up ropes of their own and grabbed him about 40 feet off the ground. Mark Randall, 23, of New York City used a mountain climbing rope Friday to descended nearly 50 feet from the statue's observation deck, said Manny Strumpf, a National Parks Service spokesman. Three officers from the police department's Emergency Services Unit sped to the scene in government boat. They lowered themselves from the 90-foot-high observation area, grabbed Randall, cut his ropes, and held onto him as the eased their way to the ground. Randall was charged with disorderly conduct and demonstrating without a permit, Strumpf said.He was released after being given two summonses. Randall told authorities he was demonstrating on behalf of Indian activist Leonard Peltier, convicted in 1977 of killing two FBI agents on the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota. The agents were killed in 1975 when they went to the reservation to pick up a fugitive. Peltier has been in federal prison for the past 14 years, serving dual life sentences. Randall, reached by telephone in his parents' Manhattan home, said: ``I had a vision that told me to do this. As long as he (Peltier) is in jail, I feel like I'm not free.'' Randall is not an American Indian and said he has never met Peltier.

DOC.HEAD: Winter in Hong Kong Means It's Time For Snake Soup
LaserPhoto TOK2
DOC.TEXT: Some people's idea of Yuletide fun is to watch the waiter bite the head off a live viper and pluck out the still-squirming serpent's bladder. The slippery green organ is then eaten raw. Sure, not everyone will cotton to that bitter flavor, but they say snake enhances sexual prowess, so what's not to like? For one thing, snakes may be threatened with extinction, Hong Kong's government has declared. On Friday, the government adopted a law that requires snake dealers to apply for import and export licences for king cobras, Asiatic cobras and Oriental rat snakes. Failure to comply could bring fines of up to $3,200 and up to six months in jail. Chan Ping-kwong, spokesman for the Agriculture and Fisheries Department, said the government would collect data on snake imports to make sure the reptiles aren't in danger of extinction. More than 100,000 snakes are imported by Hong Kong each year, mostly from China, Chan said. Serpent eating is a feature of social life in the British colony, especially during winter when the vipers are reportedly tastiest, having gorged themselves to prepare for hibernation. Snake soup is a staple of business banquets this time of year, and trade unions are organizing year-end snake feasts to kick off an election campaign for the legislature and other local offices next year. The most common snake dish is a soup, cooked with mushrooms, bamboo shoots and dried orange peels. The potion is reputed to speed the metabolism and improve male sexual performance. Another favorite, snakes' skin soaked in malt wine, is believed to have calming effects similar to that of tranquilizers. Perhaps the most spectacular way of eating snake is swallowing raw bladders. The dark green organ is extremely slippery and has an intensely bitter taste. To show how fresh their product is, Hong Kong vendors bite the snake's head off in front of customers, who get to watch the body of the reptile wriggle through the vendor's fingers as he searches for the organ. The conservation organization World Wide Fund For Nature said it supported the government's licensing decision. ``If unrestricted trade continues, snakes will one day become endangered,'' said Amy Lau, the fund's conservation officer in Hong Kong. Snake trader Tam Sun, who runs a small shop in downtown Hong Kong that sells snake soup, said he has no choice but to pass on the cost of the new import license to his customers, who now pay $2 for a bowl. ``Our profit margin is already pretty narrow,'' Tam said, after biting off the head of a green snake. ``Prices of snake soup will go up 30 percent.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Weapons-Smuggling Case Against 2 Europeans
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge dismissed weapons-smuggling charges against two Europeans accused of trying to ship thousands of anti-tank missiles and other weapons to Iraq, Iran and Libya. U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett's ruling Friday, after three weeks of government testimony, closed a high-profile case that began in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait in early August. She agreed with defense attorneys that there was not enough evidence to prove intent or a conspiracy to smuggle the weapons. ``Prosecutors connected with the case were involved in grandstanding from the very beginning,'' said defense attorney Don Lykkebak, noting the arrests and indictment were ballyhooed in a Washington news conference featuring TOW missile props. ``The problem was there was never any case.'' Claus Fuhler, 33, a German-born ophthalmologist living in Barcelona, Spain, and Juan Martin Peche-Koesters, 36, a Madrid businessman, were arrested Aug. 15 nearly two weeks after the Iraqi invasion. They were accused of trying to buy such items as 10,000 TOW missiles, 20,000 artillery shells, artillery-equipped jeeps, rifles, grenades and mortars, as well as nuclear waste and chemical garbage. The two men were charged with violating the Arms Export Control Act, which bans arms sales to the three countries. U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman issued a statement saying that despite the dismissal of charges his office would not be deterred from prosecuting arms smugglers. ``We accept the court's decision but we also want to stress the importance of pursuing arms traffickers who jeopardize our national security interests,'' he said. Customs agents said the arrests culminated a yearlong sting code-named ``Operation Dragon,'' in which a U.S. manufacturer of the TOW missiles tipped authorities that Fuhler and Peche-Koesters allegedly were seeking 10,000 missiles for $160 million. At the time of the arrests, an undercover agent posing as an arms dealer said the men were trying to buy 200 TOW missiles for shipment through Spain to Libya. U.S. Customs Service Commissioner Carol Hallett had said the case was ``clearly'' linked to Iraq's action in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: 19 Dead as Boat Capsizes Off Haifa With U.S. Soldiers On Leave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1,2,4, LaserColor TLV101
DOC.TEXT: A rented boat capsized in rough Mediterranean waters early Saturday while ferrying about 100 U.S. sailors back from shore leave to the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga. Police said 19 bodies were recovered. Before the latest police report, an American official confirmed 11 deaths and said nine men were still missing. Haifa police spokesman Chaim Avinoam said a total of 19 bodies were found after divers began searching the hull of the sunken ferry boat for victims. Police and American officials said Saratoga commanders had begun a head count of the entire Saratoga crew and that final fatality figures would not be available for several hours. At least 33 sailors were taken to Israeli hospitals for treatment, an Israeli doctor said. Police gunboats, helicopters and rescue vessels, which plucked 42 other seamen from the water and took them on to the Saratoga, continued scouring Haifa Bay before dawn. The Saratoga, part of the U.S. Sixth Fleet based in Italy, is stationed in the eastern Mediterranean as a battle group included in the multinational force opposing Iraq. The carrier has a crew of about 6,200. According to sailors at the scene and a U.S. official who spoke on condition of anonymity, the boat was a privately rented Israeli launch. ``It was overloaded at the rear and because of the high seas, water started coming over the stern,'' said one young sailor, who spoke on condition he not be identified. ``Once it started coming over, it capsized very quickly.'' Kip Burke, commander, Sixth Fleet Staff, based in Gaeta, Italy, said about 100 sailors were aboard the boat. He said an investigation had begun into the accident but he was uncertain how far off shore the boat was when the 1:30 a.m. incident occurred. ``There is a lot of confusion,'' Burke said. ``The biggest problem is counting heads.'' An estimated 1,650 American servicemen from the Saratoga and at least three escort ships disembarked at Haifa on Friday for Christmas leave, a U.S. spokesman said. All the sailors aboard the capsized boat were from the Saratoga, officials said. After the capsizing, the port of Haifa was declared a closed military zone and flares were seen illuminating the entire bay area. Israeli navy vessels and air force helicopters were helping search and evacuate the sailors. Reporters said the accident happened in rough seas with 3- to 4-foot-high waves. Twenty-three survivors were taken to Rambam Hospital in Haifa, said Dr. Zvi Ben-Yishai. They removed their soaked clothing - many of them wore Israeli army uniforms to warm themselves - and all had their feet enclosed in blue plastic bags. Some still were shivering hours after the accident, drinking hot soup from plastic bowls. Ben-Yishai said he knew of at least 10 other sailors taken to hospitals elsewhere in Haifa, a port frequented by U.S. vessels in the region and about 75 miles northwest of Jerusalem. In Washington, Lt. Col. Quentin Banks, a Pentagon spokesman, said identities of the dead sailors were not immediately released. The Saratoga is normally based at Mayport Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, Fla., but since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, U.S. forces have been added to the region. The Saratoga is accompanied by the destroyer Sampson, cruiser South Carolina and combat storage ship Sirius, said U.S. Embassy spokesman Don Cofman in Tel Aviv. He said the sailors in the accident were all apparently from the Saratoga.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Trappings Were Around 48 Million Years Ago
DOC.TEXT: Aaaah, chestnuts roasting in volcanic fires, 48 million years ago. Christmas didn't start in this part of the world, but there is geologic evidence that many of its trappings existed in the Pacific Northwest during the Eocene Epoch. Chestnuts, and forerunners of the traditional fir Yule log, were roasting in volcanic fires 48 million years ago in north-central Washington, before there were noses for Jack Frost to nip. ``We have the oldest fossil records of Christmas trees - the fir lineage - the oldest records of mistletoe, of holly and of Castanea (edible) chestnut, and the oldest fossil records of gooseberry, wild currant, apple, blackberry, and pear,'' said Wes Wehr, paleobotany curator at the University of Washington's Burke Museum. ``And, oh yes, also the oldest fossil record of cranberry,'' he said. ``I guess what I need to do is find the fossil turkey, and then we're ready for dinner.'' Evidence of the precursors to some of today's plants, including those used to celebrate Christmas, were found the past several years at fossil sites 100 miles apart, in Republic, Wash., and Princeton, British Columbia. Besides plants, the Republic site has been rich in insect finds, Wehr said Friday. ``Besides other things, we're getting the only records of the North American Eocene earwigs, and we have the earliest fossil record of the cutter bee,'' Wehr said. The plants and insects, along with early fishes, were preserved when a heavy layer of volcanic ash suddenly fell on a shallow lake that covered what is now Republic, a town of 1,000 people. The fossils have been gathered by Wehr and other scientists from around the country at a shale cliff on the north side of Republic. He started digging at the shale rocks in 1977, after there had been occasional fossil finds. The site, with a small museum, has gained status in paleontology circles. ``It's one of the great places in North America to see fish, insects and plants, all associated,'' Wehr said. ``It's been interesting to begin collecting a few specimens on what was a corner lot, and have it become a place where scientists come from around the country.'' Some of the leading paleontologists from around the United States, and from other nations, are expected to attend a workshop at Republic in June. Visitors, including tourists, are also given a tour of the Stonerose Interpretational Center, then encouraged to start breaking rocks. Many important scientific finds have been made by people who can't even spell paleontology, Wehr said. ``Often you will have a 9- or 10-year-old student break open a rock and they have found a distinct new species,'' Wehr said. ``It makes it all much more real.''

DOC.HEAD: Earth First! Defendants Arraigned on New Charges
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Ros cq 15th graf
DOC.TEXT: The co-founder of Earth First! and four members of the militant environmental group will stand trial on charges stemming from an alleged plot to sabotage nuclear power plants. U.S. District Judge Robert Broomfield set an April 2 trial date on Friday after accepting innocent pleas from four of the defendants charged in an indictment returned last week. David Foreman, who helped found Earth First! 10 years ago and resigned from the organization last summer, is charged with conspiracy to sabotage a nuclear facility and destruction of an energy facility. Broomfield set a Dec. 26 arraignment for Foreman. The other defendants are Mark Leslie Davis, Margaret Katherine Millett, Marc Andre Baker and Ilse Washington Asplund, all of Prescott. They face the same conspiracy charges as Foreman, plus charges of malicious destruction of property, destruction of property of an energy facility and depredation of government property. All pleaded innocent and will remain free on bond pending trial. Broomfield rejected a motion by Foreman's lawyer, Gerry Spence of Jackson, Wyo., that his client be tried separately from the other defendants. Davis, Baker and Millett were arrested in May 1989 as they allegedly were attempting to cut down a power pole west of Phoenix with a propane torch. The original indictment against the three and Foreman alleged they planned to topple the power pole as a training exercise for a broader attack on lines leading to three nuclear power plants, including the Palo Verde Plant 50 miles west of Phoenix. Asplund was added as a defendant in an second indictment issued last week, which alleges Davis and Millett sabotaged a ski lift in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: With EC Presidency Over, Prospect of Government Crisis Looms
DOC.TEXT: The accolades and self-congratulation over the accomplishments of Italy's six-month presidency of the European Community have faded to whispers. Now it's back to business as usual for the Italian government: trying to avoid collapse. Many are predicting that Premier Guilio Andreotti's five-party coalition may survive only a few more weeks. With the uneasy alliance between the dominant Christian Democrats and Socialists nearing the breaking point, the parties have scheduled a series of meetings for January to decide whether Italy's 49th postwar government can be salvaged. The country is also embroiled in a furor over President Francesco Cossiga, the head of state who is supposed to be above the daily trench warfare between political parties. Some politicians are demanding he resign for having defended a secret Cold War guerrilla force. There had been a tacit accord among Italy's fractious political parties to refrain from provoking a government crisis during the country's high-profile term at the helm of the EC, from July through December. Only two months ago Italy's leadership had been the target of scorn and ridicule in some EC circles, especially in Britain. The Economist magazine compared the Italian presidency to ``a bus trip with the Marx Brothers in the driver's seat.'' But the Italians claim to have gotten the last laugh. First, at an EC summit in Rome in October, they pushed through plans for monetary union that isolated British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and led to her downfall. Last week, Italy steered the community through a landmark summit that approved emergency aid for the Soviet Union and formally launched the 12-nation trading bloc on an ambitious path toward political and economic federation. ``Andreotti has sent the bus driven by the Marx Brothers back to Westminster,'' Turin's La Stampa newspaper headlined Monday. With the EC leadership about to be passed to Luxembourg, Andreotti may find it harder to keep his own government partners on course. He has been in office since July 1989, a feat of longevity in a country where governments often last only a few months. The 71-year-old Christian Democrat and six-time premier has skillfully managed to avoid a complete rupture in the fragile alliance with Socialists, Social Democrats, Republicans and Liberals. But the strains have grown in recent days. As usual, the squabbling is part of a power struggle in which the Christian Democrats, Socialists and opposition Communists play the major roles. The Socialists, led by former Premier Bettino Craxi, are Italy's third largest party and represent the Christian Democrats' key ally in keeping the Communists out of the government. The Socialists are demanding that referendums be held to revamp the country's electoral system and allow direct election of the president. The eventual aim of the Socialists, analysts say, is a strong presidency on the lines of the U.S. or French models, with Craxi as a candidate for the job. The presidency is now mainly a ceremonial post. The Christian Democrats prefer to strengthen the role of Parliament, where they can more easily maintain their dominance. Francesco D'Onofrio, a Christian Democrat parliamentarian, says there is an ``80 percent'' chance the government will collapse in January and a good likelihood of general elections in the spring, a year ahead of schedule. But the government might feel compelled to stay together if war breaks out in the Persian Gulf, D'Onofrio said. Italy has sent warships and fighter planes to the multinational force opposing Iraq. Another element of the political crisis is the controversy over Operation Gladio, a clandestine force created in the 1950s to wage guerrilla war in the event of a Warsaw Pact invasion. Gladio's existence was disclosed in October by Andreotti, with other NATO countries later confirming they had similar networks. Cossiga, a Christian Democrat, has vigorously defended Gladio as a legitimate force necessary to counter Communist threats to Western Europe during the Cold War. His statements raised the ire of some politicians, mainly the Communists, who say Gladio was linked with right-wing terrorism and targeted Italian Communists.

DOC.HEAD: Army, Navy Record Best-Ever Safety Results
DOC.TEXT: The past year was the safest on record for the Army and Navy, military officials said. Private vehicle accidents remained the biggest killer of soldiers and sailors. Accidents claimed the lives of 353 soldiers during the budget year ended Sept. 30, the Army said. The figure includes mishaps that occurred off-base and off-duty. The time period included the first rush of troops to the Persian Gulf. More than two-thirds of the deaths were from private automobile accidents. In the comparable period a year earlier, the Army had 369 accidental deaths. There were 732,000 Army personnel on active duty at the end of accounting period. Total Army accidents were down by 1,348 from the previous year, to 8,647, and deaths from aviation accidents fell from 35 to 33. Col. Steven Raho, deputy director of Army safety, attributed the safety improvement to a variety of factors, including increased effort by the Army to design safety features into new equipment rather than adding the features after production. The Navy, which had 579,000 personnel on active duty at the end of the budget year, said it recorded 255 total deaths from accidents, including 206 not related to Navy operations. That was down from 339 total Navy deaths the year before, of which 47 occurred in the April 19, 1989 explosion aboard the battleship USS Iowa. Two-thirds of total Navy accidental deaths were from private vehicle wrecks. The Navy had 39 deaths from aviation accidents, including those involving Marine Corps aircraft. The Navy total of 30 deaths from aviation was the lowest on record, as was the Marine Corps total of nine. The Marines do not publish lists of accidents from ground activities, and the Air Force said it was not yet prepared to release its statistics on fiscal 1990 accidents and deaths.
DOC.HEAD: Experiment To Bring Cameras Into Courtrooms
DOC.TEXT: Americans could get their first chance to see television coverage of federal judges at work next year. The experiment will likely begin in appeals courts in New York or San Francisco or a trial court in one of six states, court officials said Friday. ``The courts have been selected. Now, it's a matter of the news media requesting coverage in particular cases,'' said David Sellers, a spokesman for the policymaking U.S. Judicial Conference. The conference, composed of 27 federal judges and headed by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, approved the three-year experiment last September. Individual courts then were invited to volunteer. Those selected are federal appellate courts based in San Francisco and New York City, and U.S. District Courts in Indiana, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, Pennsylvania and Washington. A final report submitted Friday to the Judicial Conference by a special committee said, ``The selection of large courts would bring more judges into the program, and their location in metropolitan news markets would likely generate greater media activity.'' Beginning in July, broadcast and photographic access will be allowed in civil cases in the selected courts. Judges will have broad discretion to reject requests for coverage. Cameras and radio equipment have been banned from federal courts since 1937, but 45 states allow some form of broadcast or photographic coverage of proceedings in their courts.
DOC.HEAD: Democratic Leaders To Hold Off On Millionaire Surtax
DOC.TEXT: Democratic House leaders have abandoned a plan to present a surtax on millionaires as the first order of business when Congress convenes next month, but the proposal may resurface later, aides say. Democrats are turning their attention instead to piecing together a package aimed at promoting ``economic growth and tax fairness,'' one aide to a top Democrat said Friday. They hope to have the legislation ready by the time President Bush presents his State of the Union address on Jan. 29, the aide said. ``Don't focus too much on whether it's H.R. 1 or not,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. H.R. 1 is the number assigned to the first bill introduced in the House at the beginning of a session of Congress. The 102nd Congress convenes Jan. 3, when lawmakers are likely to introduce their first bills. The official said Democratic leaders still had not decided what would be in the economic growth package, but would not rule out a surtax on millionaires. Until now, Democratic leaders had spoken of making the session's first bill a tax hike on the rich. The issue was a big political winner for Democrats during this year's budget battle with the White House. They used the proposal - and Republican opposition to it - to characterize the GOP as the party of the wealthy.

DOC.HEAD: A Tree-mendous Performer
DOC.TEXT: When Ken Gates does a little stumping, he's not thinking about politics. Gates, the owner of a local electronics store, enjoys ``branching out'' during the holidays, donning a $1,000 custom-made Christmas tree suit and entertaining at nursing homes and hospitals. And this tree also has a few tricks up its ``sleeve.'' ``Sometimes when I'm at a hospital, I stand completely still at the nurses' station and someone will pass by to go see a patient,'' Gates says. ``On their way back by, I'll move. Usually, you'll find someone will scream.'' Gates has 1,200 bulbs, assorted ornaments and a blinking star on his costume. It's made of hula hoops held together with nylon thread. He carries a 32-pound battery pack to light the lights, which are capable of flashing in different colors. ``With the adult patients, it's wild. They just can't believe you have so many lights, and they've never seen anything like it before,'' Gates says. ``The kids just go crazy. They can't fathom seeing so many blinking lights and there's no cords, no wires to go behind it.'' A burn-unit patient at one hospital frantically rang for her nurses after he roamed down a hallway and past her room. ``She said, `I still think I got too much medication,''' Gates said, laughing.

DOC.HEAD: Student Uprising First Serious Challenge For Conservatives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to ADD dropped word ``school'' in 2nd graf. Pickup 3rd graf `The uprising...'; SUBS 20th graf ``We began...'' to fix wording referring to student. Pickup 21st graf `The neo-classical...'
DOC.TEXT: What started as a battle over dress and hair length has turned into a full-scale student rebellion. In the past month, thousands of high school students have taken to the streets in protest, occupied schools and won support from university students, who have begun their own demonstrations. The uprising is hampering the 8-month-old conservative administration's ability to govern Greece, and represents the New Democracy party's first serious challenge. Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis and his Cabinet held more than four emergency meetings in a week on the problem. Greece is not alone. In France this fall, thousands of high school students also held demonstrations demanding improved schools and safety. More than 50,000 high school and university students marched through the capital Dec. 18 calling for the resignation of Education Minister Vasillis Kontoyannopoulos. They also demand the scrapping of a newly proposed educational reform package, which include provisions for punishment for sloppy appearance or improper behavior. High school students say the legislation is vague about discipline and does not explain the grading system. They also want more government money for education. The demonstrators chanted ``our dreams will become your nightmares'' and ``the law will never be passed'' as they waved clenched fists at Parliament in central Constitution Square. ``The continuation of these mobilizations is not only harmful but dangerous. The government has proven it is understanding, but these actions just make things worse,'' Kontoyannopoulos said. High school students have taken over more than 2,000 schools around Greece, or 67 percent of the total, since late November. University students began sympathy strikes at their own campuses in mid-December. The high school students were protesting a series of presidential decrees this year that allow teachers to give penalty points to rule breakers. The rules included a phrase that said students must maintain a ``tidy and smart appearance.'' Enough points could lead to lower grades or transfer to another school. Students complained the decrees did not define proper dress and behavior but left the decision to teachers. The decrees were introduced as a stopgap measure until the government could introduce its reform package. In presenting the package, the government withdrew the decrees and ``control system'' but retained other proposals that angered the students. The university protest is aimed at a proposal that would allow the establishment of private universities, currently banned by the constitution. ``It degrades our education and degrees. If students want to attend private universities they should go abroad,'' said a student, who requested anonymity. The government has already taken tough stands to quench protests against economic austerity measures, a law labor restricting strikes and an anti-terrorism law that exercises prior restraint on press coverage of terrorist attacks. ``It is the philosophy of no concessions. They are trying to preserve their image of being decisive and uncompromising,,'' said former Socialist Education Minister George Papandreou, son of former Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou. His father's Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, ruled Greece from 1981 until Andreas Papandreou was voted out of office in June 1989. Coalition governments ran Greece until the conservatives were elected last April. Students are also upset that the government allowed riot police to use clubs and tear gas to disperse a previous demonstration. ``We began taking over our schools because we have various problems with the laws they are trying to force on us,'' said Michalis, a 17-year-old student who attends Athens public high school No. 1, the oldest in Greece and the alma matter of many politicians and academics. The neo-classical building, nestled near the base of the ancient Acropolis, has been closed since Dec. 10. Nervous students talk to visitors through a broken window. The front door is chained shut. Kontoyannopoulos' stated aim has to bring the school system in line with the ethics and goals of Orthodox Christian Greek society. More than 97 percent of Greece's population is baptized into the church. He said the socialists allowed the educational system to become undisciplined and politically biased.

DOC.HEAD: Michael Oakeshott, Political Philosopher, Dead At 89
DOC.TEXT: Political philosopher Michael Oakeshott, whose stress on personal responsibility and freedom was said by some to have laid the foundations for Margaret Thatcher's social policies, died at age 89, his family said today. Oakeshott died Tuesday at his home at Acton in southwest England. No cause of death was given. The son of a prominent socialist, Oakeshott was educated at Cambridge University's Gonville and Caius College. In 1951, when he became University Professor of Political Science at London University's London School of Economics, his conservative ideas were a sharp contrast with socialist Harold Laski, whom he replaced. Oakeshott held the post until 1969 when he was made Professor Emeritus at the University of London. Oakeshott was credited with turning conservative opinion away from social planning and back to personal responsibility and freedom. The Times of London wrote in an obituary notice today: ``More than anybody else Michael Oakeshott articulated the real philosophical foundations of Mrs. Thatcher's policies. Yet he had no direct influence on her and she was disposed to consider him irrelevant for her purposes because unlike Hayek, he made no practical recommendations.'' Mrs. Thatcher claimed that her philosophy of individual self-reliance was influenced by the Austrian economist Friedrich Hayek and his 1944 book ``The Road to Serfdom,'' a critical study of socialistic trends in Britain. Oakeshott once said in an interview: ``I am a member of no political party. I vote, if I have to vote, for the party which is likely to do the least harm. To that extent, I am a Tory.'' He always insisted political theory offered no guidance in political practice and that his work was intended only as a contribution to scholarship. Oakeshott's books included ``Experience and its Modes,'' published in 1933; ``Social and Political Doctrines of Contemporary Europe;'' ``Hobbes's Leviathan;'' ``Rationalism in Politics and Other Essays;'' ``On Human Conduct;'' and ``The Voice of Liberal Learning'' which came out just last year. ``A Guide to the Classics,'' which Oakeshott wrote with a colleague in 1936, dealt not with famous books but with picking winners at the racetracks, which he frequented. Oakeshott is survived by his wife and a son by a previous marriage.

Judge Refuses to Help Get Cheyenne Brando Back for Trial
DOC.TEXT: A judge has refused to assist prosecutors seeking to extradite Marlon Brando's daughter from Tahiti to testify at her half-brother's murder trial. Superior Court Judge Joel Rudof said Friday he declined to get involved because of the woman's precarious mental state. ``There is insufficient information to permit this court to further endanger what appears to be a fragile mental condition and attempt to have Miss Brando returned,'' Rudof wrote. The judge ruled after reviewing a psychiatrist's report. ``At this point it appears that unless her condition changes, she will not be able to testify. We are not going to appeal ... we will be re-evaluating the case without her testimony,'' said Sandi Gibbons, spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. The international legal tangle over the prosecution's key witness, 20-year-old Cheyenne, has helped slow proceedings. She fled to Tahiti after her brother's arrested and attempted suicide twice, leading to her confinement in a Tahitian mental hospital. Christian Brando, 32, is charged with the May 16 slaying of Cheyenne's Tahitian lover, 26-year-old Dag Drollet. The alleged crime took place in Marlon Brando's hilltop compound above Hollywood and trial has been set for Jan. 14. Miss Brando fled to Tahiti a month after Drollet's death and gave birth to his child. She has refused to return to California to testify, and authorities in Tahiti refuse to allow her to leave, charging her as an accomplice in Drollet's murder.

DOC.HEAD: Ad Agency Workers Spend the Day Helping Others
DOC.TEXT: One of New York's biggest ad agencies closed up shop early for the holidays and employees celebrated by serving food to the homeless, giving gifts to the needy, renovating homes and playing Santa to children. ``We're going to continue to do this and, if we don't, I encourage you to come back and write a nasty story about us,'' Jim Patterson, chairman of the J. Walter Thompson company, said of Friday's whirlwind of good deeds. Ken Adams, executive director of the volunteer group New York Cares, helped organize the effort for about 300 employees. He said he wouldn't have bothered if he thought it was just another ad agency gimmick, adding he plans to return next month to work with the company on more charitable causes. ``They always talked about the long term,'' he said. Employees fanned out to about 30 locations around New York City to help others on Friday. They threw a party for needy mothers and children, organized holiday festivities at a home for the elderly, served food to the hungry at four sites, helped renovate homes and wrapped gifts for children. Some, like Roger Groves, headed to Central Park to pick up trash. ``Instead of the big-bucks Christmas party, they're donating their time,'' Groves said of his fellow workers. ``Everybody feels good about it.'' Patterson said when he announced plans for the day of good deeds about 40 to 50 employees wrote him notes saying such things as, ``It's about time'' and ``Best thing you ever did.'' He said the boost in office morale was obvious. ``In a self-serving way, that helps this company,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Weather Holds Most of Nation in Icy Grip
DOC.TEXT: Snow fell across the Midwest from Nebraska to Oklahoma and on the cactus-covered terrain of Phoenix early today as a crushing blast of arctic air continued to hold almost all the nation in deep-freeze conditions. Snow was expected along most of the East Coast from Maine to the Carolinas and in the Midwest from the Great Lakes to Texas. Rain was forecast for parts of the South and Southwest. The storm that has claimed at least 14 lives since Tuesday appeared to be breaking up across the Far West, but temperatures were still expected to be cold, with highs in the 30s for Washington and Oregon and the 40s and 50s for California. Highs in the East were expected to range from the 40s and 50s in the north to the 60s in the Mid-Atlantic region and the 70s farther South. Most of the Midwest was bracing for bone-chilling cold, with highs not expected to get above -10 near the Canadian border and reaching only the 30s and 40s farther South. Florida, however, was expecting temperatures in the 80s. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Says Sturges Photos Show Child Sex
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Note contents of grafs 7, 9
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors defended seizing pictures from a prominent photographer, saying they were ``undoubtedly within the definition of child pornography'' and included one of him having sex with a minor. The government filed papers Friday opposing Jock Sturges' request for a court order requiring return of thousands of photographs and other property that officers seized from his San Francisco home last April. The papers said the seizures were justified by evidence from a photo lab that child pornography would be found at the home. Prosecutors also said officers acted properly in entering the home without a warrant because of concern that Sturges might destroy evidence or harm himself. Much of the material already has been returned, but some photographs will not be returned because they ``plainly are lascivious'' and are therefore ``contraband,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Floy Dawson in the court papers. Dawson told a reporter, however, that his office is not yet ready to file criminal charges against Sturges. Sturges, whose nude portraits, many of them of children, are displayed in major galleries across the nation, said police seized 100,000 photo negatives along with personal files and equipment during the raid. His lawyer said the search was illegal and the property must be returned. A hearing is scheduled Jan. 4. The government's papers Friday included statements by a police inspector and an FBI agent declaring the photos at a San Francisco laboratory and Sturges' home included pictures that prominently displayed the genitals of underage girls. Dawson appeared to acknowledge Sturges' claim that the FBI had been calling families he had photographed around the world and telling them he was accused of being a child pornographer and a pedophile. ``This can hardly be surprising'' in light of the evidence, Dawson wrote. ``Mr. Sturges had in his possession hundreds of photographs of pre-pubescent girls that vividly (focus) on the genitals, correspondence indicating his own sexual relationships with minor girls, and photographs of himself engaged in sexual contact with a 15-year-old girl.''

Jury Awards Paralyzed Former Dancer $14.3 Million
DOC.TEXT: A former ballerina who lost the use of her legs in a car crash seven years ago thanked jurors for their $14.3 million damage award but said no amount of money could make up for what she has gone through. A state Supreme Court jury set the award Friday for Shenikwa Dawn Nowlin, 31, who was paralyzed from the waist down when a car she was riding in went out of control on New York City's West Side Highway in August 1983, and crashed into a wall. Former New York Yankee infielder Andre Robertson, who was driving, testified that a warning sign was placed too close to a sharp curve and he didn't have time to slow down. ``Nobody can be compensated for the kinds of injuries I received,'' Nowlin said outside the courtroom after thanking jurors. ``If I had it to do over again, I'd be walking and not sitting here. No money can pay for what has happened to me.'' Nowlin, who is now a lawyer, was the Dance Theatre of Harlem's youngest member when she was 14. Jurors ruled that New York City was 67 percent liable for Nowlin's injuries because the sign didn't provide sufficient warning. They ruled Robertson was 33 percent liable for exceeding the highway's 40 mph speed limit. Nowlin and Robertson testified the car was traveling 60 to 65 mph when the crash occurred, but a witness said it appeared to be going 80 mph. The jury did not find Nowlin negligent for not wearing a seat belt. Robertson's attorney, Daniel McNamara, said his client's insurance would cover about $25,000 of the award, but because Robertson is not wealthy the city would have to pay most of the award. He said city officials could try to recover some of the money from Robertson later. It was not immediately known if Robertson or the city would appeal. Robertson, 33, retired from baseball last year and now works at a steam generating plant in Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Plane Landed on Wrong Runway at Boston Airport
DOC.TEXT: A wide-bodied passenger jet landed on the wrong runway at Logan Airport in July, but the Federal Aviation Administration had no record of the mistake, a newspaper reported today. FAA officials have records of only seven of 20 ``runway incursions'' at Logan reported to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration during the first eight months of the year, according to The Boston Globe. Barry Bermingham, FAA special projects manager for the New England region, said an ``exhaustive search'' is under way to determine why the agency was not aware of the July incident. He said it was possible the controller who handled the flight decided the landing error did not create a safety hazard so no report was filed. The incident was reported by the flight crew of the unidentified commercial airliner to NASA's Aviation Safety Reporting System. NASA gives those who file reports anonymity and immunity from penalties for possible wrongdoing. The system is designed to create a large data base of potential safety problems so aviation officials can correct problems. The report states the plane was cleared to land at Logan in cloudy weather with visibility of 15 miles. The pilot was using computers and an automatic pilot to approach the designated runway. But he landed the plane manually because the computer did not capture the glide slope, which is needed for an instrument landing. The pilot said he had no idea he had landed on the wrong runway until afterward. No one was injured.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
From Electrician To Head Of State: Walesa Sworn In As President
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs with Walesa sworn in; picks up 10th graf pvs, `Honoring the ...
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, the electrician who led a workers' movement that deposed Communist rulers to begin sweeping changes in Eastern Europe, was sworn in today as Poland's first popularly elected president. The 47-year-old labor activist, elected earlier this month by a landslide, assumed the country's highest office at an inauguration ceremony before both houses of Parliament. He took power 10 years after he led the shipyard strike that created Solidarity, the East bloc's first independent trade union. One year ago, he put together Poland's first non-Communist government, and democratic revolutions against other Soviet-influenced Communist regimes swept across Eastern Europe in the weeks afterward. ``I solemnly swear to the Polish people that I will be faithful to constitutional decisions. I will protect the dignity of the nation, the sovereignty and security of the state. I swear. ... So help me God,'' Walesa said in a firm, clear voice. His wife Danuta stood at his side as the oath was administered by parliament Speaker Mikolaj Kozakiewicz. ``The evil era when the authorities of our country were appointed under pressure of foreigners or as the result of forced compromises is ending,'' Walesa told the parliament immediately after his oath. He pledged Poland would become ``an element of the peaceful order in Europe'' but said Poles would have to believe in themselves to revitalize economic life. ``Passivity and apathy - these are the biggest obstacles on the road toward the well-being of Poles,'' he said. Walesa, elected Dec. 9, had refused to accept the post from the incumbent president, Communist Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who was this nation's last Communist leader. Jaruzelski was not invited to the ceremony. Jaruzelski jailed Walesa and other Solidarity leaders during the martial law crackdown in 1981. Legitimacy was to be conferred later in the day by Ryszard Kaczorowski, president of the anti-Communist government-in-exile in London that descends directly from the Warsaw government forced to flee from the Nazis in 1939. During the postwar decades of Communist rule, the government-in-exile nourished hopes of returning home. Kaczorowski, returning for the first time, was to give Walesa an insignia of office and other prewar symbols of power in the ceremony at the Royal Castle, where Poland's first democratic constitution was written in 1791. Walesa was also to accept the blessing of the Roman Catholic Church, with a Mass to be celebrated in honor of his presidency by the Cardinal Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic leader. In statements since his election, Walesa declared his presidency would mark the culmination of the struggle to throw off foreign domination. Honoring the dozens of Baltic Coast workers gunned down 20 years ago during anti-government strikes over bread and meat prices, Walesa said Sunday that as president he would strive ``to realize the last will of those who died.'' Free Poland has existed more in literature and song than in reality for the past two centuries. Since 1795, Poland has enjoyed only 21 years of independence from rule by foreign powers, principally Germany and Russia. Even that interlude, between the world wars, was darkened by a coup and strongman rule. Walesa's critics fear he will be another strongman in the tradition of Marshal Jozef Pilsudski, who after a 1926 military takeover allowed the trappings of democracy but pulled the strings as military commander. Walesa must assemble a government that maintains dramatic market-oriented economic reform that won the confidence of the West, while responding to discontent voters showed by overwhelmingly rejecting Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki's presidential bid. Walesa has pledged to complete the radical free-market reform of the economy, but the program has already boosted unemployment and sent prices soaring. Walesa won his office with 75 percent of the vote after fending off a dark horse challenge by unknown emigre businessman Stanislaw Tyminski, branded by Walesa as a front-man for a ``counter-revolution'' by former Communists. The bitter election campaign also split the Solidarity movement, leaving Walesa alienated from Mazowiecki and most of his other former intellectual advisers. As president, Walesa's first task will be to nominate a prime minister to run the government on a day-to-day basis, while preparing for elections that would replace the Parliament elected under a 1989 bargain that guaranteed 65 percent of seats for Communists or their allies. Walesa announced Thursday that he was unable to name a prime minister until after the Christmas and New Year holidays. He said he is wavering between two options. One would be to keep a modified version of Mazowiecki's current caretaker Cabinet for about three months until fully democratic parliament elections in the spring. The other would create an all new Cabinet that would be given a year to work before elections.

DOC.HEAD: Police Say Florida Man's Slaying May Be Linked To Serial Murder Suspects
DOC.TEXT: The slaying of a middle-aged man whose body was found dumped in a remote area may be connected to eight other killings believed to be the work of two women, police said. The body of Daniel Mitchell Conger Jr. was found Friday in woods at the end of a dirt road in this north-central Florida area. Conger, 50, was apparently shot with a small-caliber handgun, but police refused to say how many times. Authorities were hoping the results of an autopsy scheduled today would indicate whether the killing was linked to eight other slayings they believe are the work of two female serial killers. ``It might be related, we just don't know yet,'' said sheriff's Sgt. Robert Douglas. ``There's just not enough evidence yet to link it.'' Authorities began searching for Conger after he did not show up for work Friday morning. The bodies of the other victims, all middle-aged men, were found in remote areas of Florida and Georgia. Each had been shot with a .22-caliber handgun. In many cases, including Conger's, the victim's car was recovered in another county. Hundreds of sightings of women resembling composite police sketches of the suspects have been reported, but no arrests have been made.

DOC.HEAD: New Jersey Gaming Officials Accuse Union of Mob Connections
DOC.TEXT: The state is seeking the suspension of nine top officials of a casino workers union the federal government alleges is under mob control. In a complaint filed Friday with the Casino Control Commission, state law enforcement officials asked the commissioners to suspend the officials from the union and revoke their registration. Unions representing casino workers and their top officials have to be registered with the commission, which regulates gambling in Atlantic City. The complaint was filed by the state Division of Gaming Enforcement, an investigative branch of the state Attorney General's Office. The commission is scheduled to consider the complaint at its next meeting Jan. 2. The action follows the civil racketeering lawsuit filed Wednesday by the federal Justice Department against Local 54 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees Union. The local represents 15,000 casino workers and about 7,000 waitresses and bartenders outside the city. The federal lawsuit charges the local has been controlled through violence and intimidation for the last 20 years by a crime family reputedly headed by Angelo Bruno and Nicodemo ``Little Nicky'' Scarfo, now serving a 70-year prison sentence for racketeering. Union officials have denied the charges. The federal lawsuit and accompanying affidavits, according to the complaint, ``clearly establish the lengthy history of Local 54's domination by members of organized crime.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS WEBSTER, S.D.-dated last item in rdp to CORRECT in lead that Anderson is former state attorney general, sted attorney general, add mention of service on Federal Trade Commission.
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Sigurd Anderson, whose career in government also included stints as state attorney general and member of the Federal Trade Commission, died Friday of prostate cancer at age 86. Anderson, who immigrated to the United States from Norway at age 2, set up a law practice in Webster in 1937 and twice was elected Day County state's attorney. He enlisted in the Navy in 1942 and served both in the United States and in the western Pacific during World War II. Anderson achieved the rank of lieutenant commander in the U.S. Naval Reserve. In 1946, Anderson, a Republican, returned to South Dakota and was elected attorney general. He won a second term two years later and was elected governor in 1950 and 1952. After his second term as governor ended, he was appointed to the FTC by President Eisenhower. He resigned from the commission in 1964 to make another run for governor, but he lost in the GOP primary to Nils Boe. As governor, Boe later appointed Anderson to fill a vacancy as a circuit judge. Anderson retired in 1975.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Peace Talks Resume
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's Vietnamese-backed government and three guerrilla factions were under increased pressure to accept a U.N. peace plan as talks resumed today. Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen, who fell ill during the first day of talks Friday, was expected to rejoin the meeting of the 12-member Supreme National Council. The talks were to conclude later today. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas, addressing Friday's opening session, warned that time was running out to reach a settlement and urged acceptance of the plan that would give the United Nations a strong role in an interim government. ``The world has changed. Other priorities can and will require our attention,'' Dumas said. ``The international community cannot indefinitely work out the fate of Cambodia if Cambodians themselves do not have the political will to do so.'' He told a news conference that Friday's talks had been ``constructive,'' saying the factions asked questions but did not reject the plan outright. Britain, one of the authors of the plan, also has pressed for acceptance. It sent an envoy to Paris to discuss normalizing relations with the Phnom Penh government on condition it accepts the peace process. David Colvin, director of the British Foreign Office's Southeast Asian Department, said he told Hun Sen's delegation that accepting the plan could lead to normalizing relations with the West, but rejecting it would mean further isolation. All factions agreed to a version of the plan in September, but Phnom Penh has since balked, saying the proposal exceeds the authority of the U.N. Charter. The plan calls for the United Nations to administer Cambodia during an interim period leading to free elections. It also calls for a cease-fire and disarming of all four parties. Phnom Penh is concerned about the extent to which its government could be dismantled by the plan and about the extent of disarmament, said a senior Western official who spoke on condition of anonymity. Hun Sen said on his arrival here that ``serious measures must be taken to suppress the foundations'' of the Chinese-backed Khmer Rouge, the strongest member of the three-party resistance coalition. Their three-year reign of terror, which ended in 1979 with a Vietnamese invasion, left hundreds of thousands of Cambodians dead. The council, meeting for the second time since its creation three months ago, is made up of six representatives of Hun Sen's Vietnamese-backed government and two from each of the three resistance factions. Dumas said the peace plan, agreed to Nov. 26 by the five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council, was a compromise text that could be improved but not ``put into question.'' The permanent members are the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China. The International Conference on Peace in Cambodia adjourned in September 1989 after a monthlong effort failed to reach a settlement.

DOC.HEAD: Trial of Policeman Accused of Killing 4 Israelis, Wounding 27
DOC.TEXT: A military court today delayed for a week the court-martial of a policeman accused of fatally shooting four Israelis near Egypt's border with the Jewish state. The three-judge court opened proceedings today, but gave lawyers an extra week to prepare a defense for Ayman Mohammed Hassan. Brig. Mohammed Wagdi el-Leithy, the court's president, ordered Hassan held without bail until the proceedings resume Dec. 29. Hassan, 23, appeared relaxed and cheerful. He was flanked by two military policemen. During a recess, military police kissed him on the cheeks and gave him cigarettes and tea. One officer, armed with an automatic rifle and standing behind the judges' table, shouted to colleagues guarding Hassan to give the defendant his regards. He is being tried at 3rd Army headquarters, 10 miles west of Suez. The city is at the southern end of the Suez Canal, 85 miles east of Cairo. Hassan was charged with four counts of premeditated murder for the shootings Nov. 25 that killed four Israelis and wounded 27. In arguing for a postponement, his attorneys said they needed more time to study documents in the case. Cairo newspapers have reported that Hassan confessed to investigators that he had shot up the Israeli vehicles. He said he had acted alone, the reports said.

DOC.HEAD: KGB Chief Warns of Bloodshed in Bringing About Order
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with parliament ending debate on increasing Gorbachev's power, Tass saying most lawmakers support proposals. Pickup 11th pvs, `Kryuchkov said...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MOSB1
DOC.TEXT: The KGB chief warned today that the Soviet Union must be ready to accept bloodshed in exchange for order and accused the CIA and other foreign elements of stirring up trouble in the Soviet Union. Later today, parliament ended debate on constitutional amendments enhancing the powers of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, and the official news agency Tass reported that most lawmakers would support the proposals. In his 25-minute speech to the Congress of People's Deputies, KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov said outside forces ``are trying to exert overt and covert pressure on the Soviet Union and to impose doubtful ideas and plans to pull the country out of its difficult situation.'' The CIA is gathering information on workers' movements in the Soviet Union ``for its purposeful masterminding'' and funding ``anti-Soviet formations'' like radio stations that attack the Soviet Union, he said. Kryuchkov did not say what kind of ideas he thought foreigners were trying to impose on the Soviets. He asked the 2,250-member parliament to give his agency more power to fight corruption and nationalist uprisings. ``We will not avoid more serious consequences if we don't start immediately to fight destruction of our forces,'' Kryuchkov said. ``We should be ready to accept bloodshed if we want to speak about bringing order to the country.'' The speech, similar to one Kryuchkov gave earlier this month, came as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev struggles to maintain control over independence-minded republics, simmering ethnic conflicts and a collapsing economy. Food shortages have hit Moscow, Leningrad and other large cities, prompting Western countries to send emergency food. Fears of political turmoil were heightened with the surprise resignation Thursday of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Shevardnadze blamed ``reactionaries'' for moving the Soviet Union toward dictatorship and urged reformers to unite to preserve democratic changes. The proposed constitutional amendments debated by the lawmakers would transform the Soviet system of executive power into a presidential form of administration. Gorbachev wants more power to hold the country together and fight corruption while he carries out economic reform. ``Most legislators support the idea of strengthening presidential powers,'' Tass said. Opposition legislators belonging to the Inter-Regional group, however, said Gorbachev's powers should be dependent on the approval of the Supreme Soviet legislature. Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the Supreme Soviet, told the Congress in a 20-minute speech that the deputies should approve the amendments without reservation. ``If parliament trusts the president, it should untie his hands and not hold him on a rope of parliamentary debate,'' Lukyanov said. He said preliminary voting on the amendments will begin Monday. Kryuchkov said the KGB needs more authority to combat economic sabotage and nationalist militancy in the republics. Nationalists have assembled 26,000 armed fighters in the Soviet republics of Estonia, Latvia, Armenia and Georgia, he said. All 15 Soviet republics have declared sovereignty in some form from the Kremlin. Georgia, Lithuania, Estonia and Lativa have declared outright independence. In saying the country should be prepared for bloodshed, Kryuchkov referred to ethnic violence in some republics and asked, ``Isn't there bloodshed already?'' Boris Yeltsin, the reformist president of the Russian Federation, dismissed Kryuchkov's speech as old news. ``Yes, there is sabotage, yes there is corruption,'' he said. ``We have heard all this before.'' A representative of the Lithuanian government, attending but not participating in the congress, accused Kryuchkov of using scare tactics that have failed before. ``If he is speaking about bloodshed, then it will be him who causes it,'' said Algis Cekoulis. Hard-line Communists have urged Gorbachev to impose a state of emergency in republics ridden by ethnic conflict and separatist movements. Gorbachev has said he might do that if the Congress allows him to strengthen his hand in dealing with trouble spots. Kryuchkov also said he opposed private property laws that would let land fall into the hands of ``the black market and shady enterprises.'' Shevardnadze's unexpected resignation Thursday pleased hard-liners, who opposed his role in negotiating the unification of Germany and Soviet's role in the anti-Iraq coalition. Reformers have used his speech as a rallying cry. A parade of speakers at the Congress on Friday echoed the 62-year-old diplomat's warning that hard-liners were pushing the country toward a dictatorship. Gorbachev met Friday for two hours with Shevardnadze, reportedly to discuss some way of keeping his longtime ally in the government. It wasn't clear whether Gorbachev intended to ask Shevardnadze to continue as foreign minister or to take another post. A Shevardnadze aide said on Thursday that the resignation was ``irreversible.''

Combine Jane Fonda and her media mogul fiance, Ted Turner, and you have ``People'' Magazine's ``Power Couple of 1990.'' The couple topped a list of megamates the magazine named in its Dec. 31 issue. DOC.HEAD: Cheney: War Might Come `Soon' After U.N. Deadline
