DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told desert-weary Marines today he did not expect President Bush to wait long past Jan. 15 to send them to war against Iraq if Saddam Hussein leaves his army in Kuwait. Cheney did not say how long he meant by soon, but said he and Bush were against forgetting the U.N. deadline and instead giving economic sanctions more time to exact a toll on Baghdad. ``The president is deadly serious when he says the whole crisis cannot be resolved until Saddam Hussein goes back to Baghdad and withdraws his forces from Kuwait,'' Cheney told members of the 1st Battalion, 7th Marines, most of whom have been in Saudi Arabia since mid-August. ``I would think that soon after Jan. 15th if he has not withdrawn his forces from Kuwait we'll be in a position to take military action in conjunction with our allies,'' Cheney said while standing atop an M60-A1 tank in the desert some 50 miles from the Kuwaiti border the Marines might be asked to cross. Cheney, in response to a Marine's question, praised other Arab nations for their support of the military effort, particularly Egypt, where he is to stop Sunday to meet with President Hosni Mubarak before returning to Washington. Cheney brought Christmas greetings to the troops from Bush and the American people but added a somber note, telling them they might soon find themselves at war, or treating its casualties. As the secretary visited Marines in the desert and then flew by helicopter to a Navy hospital ship and Aegis cruiser in the Persian Gulf, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was making a separate round of troop visits as well. Just how soon American troops will be ready to fight is a question that became controversial this week when the deputy commander of Operation Desert Shield said ground forces might not be combat ready until well into February. Those comments were widely interpreted as weakening the Bush administration's effort to link the threat of attack to the U.N. deadline. Cheney today refused to comment on the remarks, made Wednesday by Army Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller. But his tough talk the past two days appeared to be part of an effort to convince Saddam ignoring the deadline carried a heavy risk. Bush, who was meeting with British Prime Minister John Major at the presidential retreat at Camp David, Md., rejected suggestions that troops in the Persian Gulf are not battle ready. ``If there was some clear provocation 10 minutes from now, the allied forces are ready to respond vigorously,'' Bush said when asked today about Waller's comments. Bush reiterated his determination to soon expel Iraq from Kuwait in a magazine interview released Friday. ``It can't drag on with indecision and it can't stop short of the U.N. mandate,'' Bush told U.S. News & World Report. ``See, that argues very forcefully against some of these scenarios that call for somebody to compromise: we'll give him something for this, give him something so he saves face. That is not in the books.'' National Security Adviser Brent Scowcroft, meantime, told reporters for The Associated Press and other news agencies that Jan. 15 was purely an ``authorization date'' and ``not an attack day at all.'' The U.N. resolution ``doesn't say (Saddam) is going to be attacked this date or that date or whatever,'' the national security adviser said, adding: ``One of the important points we're trying to get across to him is that we haven't blinked so far, we're not blinking now and we will not blink.'' Cheney and Powell during earlier visits on Friday drew applause from the troops when they promised, if war erupts, to wage a violent and destructive campaign. ``The only acceptable outcome, if hostilities begin, is absolute, total victory,'' Cheney declared. Powell said he hoped no bloodshed would occur. But if war comes, he said, ``When we launch it, we will launch it violently, we will launch it in a way that will make it decisive so we can get it over as quickly as possible and there's no question who won.'' It was the second straight day of tough talk from Pentagon leaders, who appeared to be trying mightily to offset speculation that the U.S. troops will not be in position to fight on Jan. 15. Cheney, in his pep talk to the troops, appeared to be trying to dispel the notion that Waller's comments removed any military threat from the deadline. Asked by an airman how long the United States would wait to attack if the deadline passed without an Iraqi withdrawal, Cheney said: ``While I can't tell you a specific date, for obvious reasons, when that would happen, I can say that we are eager to get this wrapped up as quickly as possible. We do not think that waiting indefinitely is going to solve the problem and I'm confident we'll move as soon as we can to wrap it up.'' He also promised that Washington would not interfere with strategic decisions of field commanders. ``There will be the freedom and flexibility to run a first-class military operation all the way,'' Cheney said to applause. ``They won't have their hands tied behind their backs. There won't be sanctuaries where the enemy can take cover.''

DOC.HEAD: At Least 19 U.S. Sailors Dead as Boat Capsizes Off Haifa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with sailors' accounts on cause, deadliest accident involving U.S. personnel since Operation Desert Shield began. Pickup 13th pvs, `There was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos TLV1,2,4,5 LaserColor TLV101,104,105
DOC.TEXT: A ferry capsized and sank in rough Mediterranean waters early today while taking about 100 American sailors from Christmas shore leave back to the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga. At least 19 drowned. American and Israeli rescue teams searched throughout the night for others feared missing after the Israeli ferry Tuvia went under shortly after midnight in windy, choppy seas about 200 yards from the Saratoga. The U.S. ship was about a mile off the coast. Forty-seven sailors were hospitalized and 38 rescued unharmed from the choppy seas, according to state-owned Israel radio. It said four were in serious condition and most of the others had been released later in the morning. It was the deadliest accident involving American servicemen taking part in the U.S.-led multinational force arrayed against Iraq and raised the number of Americans killed in Operation Desert Shield to at least 73. The sailors were among hundreds who spent their holiday liberty Friday in Haifa, some with wives and girlfriends who had flown from home to meet them. The Saratoga has a crew of about 4,500. A Haifa police spokesman, Chaim Avinoam, said 19 bodies had been recovered by midmorning. Army spokesman Ranaan Gissen said six of the bodies were found trapped in the two-deck, 57-foot ferry about 80 feet below the surface of the Mediterranean. Officials said at midafternoon that two other sailors still could be missing. Saratoga commanders recalled all 1,920 men from shore leave. There was no official report on the cause of the sinking. Witnesses said they believed there were too many people in the back of the ferry. Shaul Raziel, director of the Israel Port authority, said a combination of events probably caused the accident. ``The seating, or movement in one direction, a sudden wave, and the disaster happened,'' he said on army radio. Survivors said from beds at Haifa's Rambam Hospital that the Navy-chartered ferry had taken on water in high seas, then suddenly overturned as it was hit by two large waves. ``It felt like we were going against the waves, so we would go up and come down ... and everytime we would come back down water would come in,'' said Seaman Michael Benjamin, 19, of San Antonio. ``We were going on the waves, and I just noticed one that was bigger than normal and then we noticed another one that was bigger than normal. The next thing I know, all I saw coming in was water. I was tilted forward, I heard a lot of yelling, `She's going down.''' Benjamin suffered a neck injury when he was hit in the water by one of the rescue boats. In the next bed, Chief Petty Officer Lance Vickery, 33, of Mayport, Fla., said the Tuvia sank almost instantly. ``All of a sudden I saw water just come flying in. It was maybe two seconds, and the boat rolled right over,'' said Vickery, who suffered bleeding lungs from inhaling water. The port of Haifa was declared a closed military zone after the accident and flares illuminated the bay, dotted with search ships, helicopters, and U.S. and Israeli frogmen searching the sunken ferry. There was confusion over the number of casualties because some sailors aboard a nearby ferryboat, the Carmelite, jumped into the water to help rescue their colleagues, said U.S. Embassy spokesman Don Cofman. Some of the Carmelite passengers later were pulled from the water by rescuers, leading to uncertainty as to how many of the about 100 sailors aboard the ill-fated Tuvia were accounted for. The captain of the sunken boat, who gave his name only as Yossi, told reporters he believed the ferry sank because too many people were gathered in the stern. ``There were squalls all day and the waves were three to four feet,'' Tom Abbott of the U.S. Embassy's naval attache's office said at a news conference. Abbott said he talked to one person aboard the other ferry who said the Tuvia went down almost instantly. ``He turned his back, turned around again and the ferry was gone. It went down very fast,'' said Abbott. Cofman said it was believed all those aboard the sunken ferry were from the Saratoga but a few could have been from the escort vessels. The Saratoga is part of a task force has been anchored outside the breakwater off the northern port of Haifa since Thursday night. The Saratoga is accompanied by the destroyer Sampson, cruiser South Carolina and combat stores ship Sirius, said Cofman. Officials said the naval task force carries 6,200 men. The Saratoga is normally based at Mayport Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, Fla., but has been in the Mideast since the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. One American sailor told Israel army radio he thought the ferry Tuvia was swamped because it had ``too many people for too small a boat. ... It couldn't hold the weight and it just sank.'' But a crewman, reached by telephone at the Haogen boat company offices, said the boat was licensed to carry 131 people and had 102 aboard. He said the Haogen company had worked with the Navy ferrying sailors ashore since Haifa first began being used as a liberty port about 20 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Arctic Weather Keeps Most of the Nation Chilled
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to update with weather deaths in Wisconsin and Texas, warm weather in East, picking up at 6th graf pvs, `Only the...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing
DOC.TEXT: Frigid weather held much of the nation in a vice grip today as subzero cold refused to budge, conjuring more snow, ice, freezing rain, an ice-jammed river and even a few twisters thrown into a barrage unlikely to go away by Christmas. The far West got the beginnings of a break as the arctic deep freeze that brought rare heavy snowfall to Seattle and a light snow to California's seashore started to edge its way eastward. ``It will get colder as the days go on, especially toward Christmas,'' National Weather Service meteorologist Thomas Helman said in Wisconsin. ``For Monday and Tuesday, we're looking at lows of 10 to 20 below.'' The East, meanwhile, had uncommon warmth, with temperatures in the 50s as far north as New York. The weather was blamed for at least 16 deaths since Tuesday, in Washington, Iowa, Oregon, Montana, California, Wisconsin, Texas, Oklahoma and Mississippi. Only the extreme Northeast and parts of the West Coast escaped rain or snow Friday. A few flakes even fell on the cactus-covered terrain of Phoenix, as the first snow in nearly four years hit the southern Arizona city. More heavy snow was forecast for the Great Lakes. Flurries also were seen for the East Coast from Maine to the Carolinas and across the Midwest from the Canadian border to Texas. Rain was forecast for less frigid areas in the South and Southwest. Only southern Florida escaped the cold, with temperatures hovering around 80 degrees. In Montana, temperatures fell to 49 below zero in Wisdom, 45 below at Yellowstone and 30 below across much of the rest of the state Friday. Elsewhere in Arizona, 6 inches of snow fell in Flagstaff, with up to 3 feet piling up in the mountains as storms closed the Flagstaff, Grand Canyon and Show Low airports. A rare snowfall also dusted Monterey in central California and Malibu in the south Friday. ``It's a white Christmas but it's a white Christmas with whitecaps,'' said windsurfer Mark Moody, who didn't let the snow keep him out of the water at Leo Carrillo Beach, nrthwest of Los Angeles. ``It reminds me of Lake Michigan,'' said Moody, who learned to windsurf in Chicago. The icy weather paralyzed citrus growers in Arizona and California, dreading the deadly effects of frost. ``We're frightened, and all we can do is sit and watch,'' said Todd Burden, part-owner of B&B Farms in Mesa, Ariz. In the Midwest, paralyzing cold weather stopped cars in their tracks while ice- and snow-covered highways made travel treacherous. Scores of people were injured in weather-related accidents and thousands were stranded. The most recent storm-related death was reported Friday afternoon, where a Mississippi twister knocked a tree into a house and killed a man. One person was killed in Montana when two cars collided in a cloud of snow thrown up by a snow plow. Up to 50 families in Pocatello, Idaho, were evacuated from their homes Friday when overnight temperatures that dipped to 17-below created ice jams that caused the frozen surface of Portneuf River to rise more than 4 feet in two hours. Schools were closed in many states, giving children an extended Christmas holiday. Sports events in New Mexico, South Dakota and Wisconsin were canceled to keep students off the roads at night. In Cavalier, N.D., four men trapped in a stalled jeep resorted to burning Christmas wrapping paper to keep warm as the wind-chilled temperature fell to 80 below. ``Nobody knows why we weren't injured,'' said passenger Mark Sagert. ``I was facing death and I knew it. I was thinking about my wife and family.'' In Belt, Mont., rancher Frank Urick had to hitch a team of horses to a sleigh to haul feed to livestock when his pickup truck froze up. ``All I have to do is give them a bucket of oats,'' he said. ``It's not as comfortable as it would be in the cab of a heated pickup, but we manage to get by.'' In central Mississippi, a tornado ripped through Vaiden, destroying 10 houses, downing trees and injuring 15 people. About 3,000 homes in southern Oregon were left without power when a natural gas supply system failed Friday. Utility officials said it would take as long as four days to restore gas to all of the homes, and there was a run on electric heaters in the interim. ``I tried to buy an electric heater and started calling all over town and they said they were sold out hours ago,'' said Trudy Bache of Grants Pass, Ore.

DOC.HEAD: Last Change of Soviet Guards at WW II Memorial in Berlin
LaserPhoto BER1
DOC.TEXT: Soviet troops goose-stepped away from a memorial to victims of World War II for the last tme Saturday as they handed over control of an enclave in western Berlin to civilians. Several hundred people watched a Soviet honor guard escort the final two-man watch away from the large memorial in Tiergarten, the sprawling park just west of the Brandenburg Gate, which used to mark the division of East and West Berlin. Soviet officers and Berlin legislators laid wreaths before the memorial and bands played the national anthems of the Soviet Union and Germany. The mayor of the Tiergarten borough, Wolfgang Naujokat, said civilian police would guard the monument and it would be kept as it is - including the two old Soviet tanks and two artillery pieces that were part of the Red Army's advance into Berlin in 1945 as Nazi Germany fell to the Allies. After the Berlin Wall was built in 1961, the monument became an odd Soviet enclave 500 yards inside West Berlin where the guards had to be relieved by convoy. The end of the Soviet guardpost at the memorial was a provision of the Soviet-German treaty of friendship and cooperation signed Nov. 9 - the first anniversary of the opening of the Berlin Wall - by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and German Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: If Deadline Ignored War Likely Would Come Soon
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney hopped atop a tank Saturday to tell desert-weary but eager Marines war likely would come soon after Jan. 15 if Saddam Hussein ignores an ultimatum to withdraw from Kuwait. Cheney did not say whether he meant days, a week or longer but he said he and President Bush would not forget that United Nations deadline in favor of giving sanctions against Iraq more time to work. ``With the press here, I can't get too specific about dates but obviously we want to get it over with as soon as possible,'' Cheney said while standing on an M60-A1 tank in the Saudi desert about 50 miles south of Kuwait. Still, Cheney, on his second day of pre-Christmas visits with some of the nearly 300,000 American troops in the region, did escalate the pre-deadline rhetorical war by saying: ``The president is deadly serious when he says the whole crisis cannot be resolved until Saddam Hussein goes back to Baghdad and withdraws his forces from Kuwait. ... I would think that soon after Jan. 15th if he has not withdrawn his forces from Kuwait then we will be in a position to take military action in conjunction with our allies.'' As Cheney was visiting the Marines in the desert and then Navy personnel aboard a hospital ship and Aegis missile crusier in the Persian Gulf, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Gen. Colin Powell was making separate visits to troops as well. Cheney and Powell have been in Saudi Arabia since Wednesday, meeting with senior and field commanders to assess the readiness of the American forces less than a month from the U.N. deadline. The trip was thrown into controversy the first day when the deputy commander of Operation Desert Shield, Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, told reporters U.S. ground forces might not be combat ready until mid-February. It was his opinion that Bush should put any attack plans on the shelf until the entire deployment, still awaiting the arrival of more than 100,000 Army ground forces, was ready. Cheney and Powell refused throughout the week to comment on Waller's remarks, but their hawkish pep talks to troops appeared designed to convince Saddam, in case Waller made him think otherwise, that the deadline still carried a military threat. ``We will be ready, whenever the president says go, to do whatever has to be done,'' Cheney told sailors aboard the USS Bunker Hill after seeing a demonstration of its guns and firing a dozen rounds into the gulf himself. ``We're ready today if we have to do something, obviously.'' Bush, meanwhile, said that U.S. forces are battle ready. ``If there was some clear provocation 10 minutes from now, the allied forces are ready to respond vigorously,'' Bush said from Camp David, Md. Cheney told the Marines who have been in the desert since August, when the American deployment was just beginning, that they now had plenty of help. ``We've got enormous forces deployed here in Saudi Arabia and we're prepared to use them,'' Cheney said. Cheney appeared to have the remarks of the Army's Waller in mind when a Marine asked him about the readiness dispute and said many homesick Marines ``prefer to go to war and get it over with.'' Said Cheney: ``We always knew the Marines were going to be ready before the Army was.'' And again later, when a Navy sailor asked about reports American forces were not ready to fight, Cheney said, ``The Army may be a little slow but we know the Navy's ready.'' But one of the Marine unit's senior officers, Brig. Gen. Tom Draude, said he concurred with Waller's assessment. ``I don't think you should initiate something as serious as combat until you have got everything you possibly can,'' Draude said. Cheney watched the Marines practice tank-killing by light infantry, donning chemical protective suits and decontaminating tanks and other armored vehicles. He promised them that if Saddam used chemical weapons, ``our response will be absolutely overwhelming.'' After a helicopter trip over the gulf - and past several vital Saudi oil installations being defended by American forces - Cheney toured the USNS Mercy, one of two hospital ships send to the Mideast, before finishing his day with a stop on the Bunker Hill.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Finds `Honest Work'; Riyadh vs. Albuquerque
With AM-Gulf-US Forces
DOC.TEXT: Even in the Saudi desert, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney can't resist taking a swipe at his former line of work. The former Wyoming congressman told troops Friday that there won't be any interference from Washington if war erupts - not even from a Congress the Bush administration at times criticizes for meddling in its Persian Gulf policy. Would Congress be behind the president in event of war?, Cheney was asked. ``Congress is always way behind the president,'' he answered, throwing his arm over his shoulder and pointing backwards. Then Cheney delivered his kicker: ``I used to be in Congress before I found honest work.''

Army Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller plopped himself into the center of a major controversy last week when he said American ground troops in Saudi Arabia probably won't be combat ready until mid-February. That's a month after the U.N. deadline for Saddam Hussein to pull his army from Kuwait, and Waller's message ran counter to the tough-talking approach the Bush administration was taking in trying to convince Saddam he'd best meet the U.N. ultimatum. Waller's comments might make him appear a dove, trying to find an excuse to avoid combat. He wanted to make sure reporters knew otherwise, so he ended his candid interview session by passing around a copy of a favorite passage. From John Stuart Mill, it reads: ``War is an ugly thing but not the ugliest of things. The decayed and degraded state ... which thinks nothing is worth war is much worse. A man who has nothing for which he is willing to fight, nothing he cares more about than his personal safety, is a miserable creature who has no chance of being free.''

First came questions about whether the United States was ready to attack Iraq. Then another about the depth of Arab support for the anti-Iraq coalition. The next Marine to ask Defense Secretary Dick Cheney a question had something else in mind. ``Who do you think is going to be in the Super Bowl this year, sir?'' the lance corporal asked. Cheney quickly entered his home team, the Washington Redskins. His second choice was the San Francisco 49ers, but Cheney quickly realized he couldn't stick with it - both the Redskins and the 49ers are in the National Football Conference so only one could make the Super Bowl. So he threw the question to the crowd. ``Buffalo'' was the first shout. Cheney nodded in approval. ``Houston,'' came from the back of crowd. Ever the politician, Cheney decided to stay out of the debate, shrugging his shoulders and moving on to the next question.

An Army GI was having trouble the other day telling a girlfriend back home why she should send a care package not to him but to a friend stationed in the northern Saudi desert. ``Mike's got it a lot tougher than me,'' was how the GI put it at first during a phone conversation with his girlfriend. Indeed. The GI was calling from an official Saudi government guest house, inside the walled confines of an ornate palace complex where two Saudi kings have lived. Just outside the room from which the GI was calling hangs a two-story high crystal chandelier. And everywhere you look is opulence - marble, crystal, huge fountains, art works. Either reluctant to describe all this or finding it difficult to find the right words, the soldier put it this way: ``I'm doing OK. I'm in a city better than Albuquerque.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Postpones Second Half of Evacuation Drill
DOC.TEXT: Iraq called off the second half of a civil defense drill on Saturday, and local newspapers said officials planned an exercise to evacuate the entire capital at a later date. Officials had planned to evacuate the city's western half, which has 2 million residents, in a drill similar to one held on Friday. No explanation for the delay was given. However, Friday is the Moslem holiday, so government offices and schools were closed anyway. A drill on Saturday would have meant a shutdown. Interior Minister Samir Mouhamad Abdul-wahab said the results of Friday's exercise were ``encouraging.'' In that drill, hundreds of thousands of residents from east of the Tigris River were transported by private automobiles and buses to locations north, east and south of the city for several hours. ``We are proud of the results of the drill and we are confident that more drills will be held,'' the army daily, Al-Qaddissiya quoted Abdul-wahab as saying. The interior minister, who is also head of the main civil defense committee, said blackout drills would be held in Baghdad and other cities. No dates for those, or for the evacuation of the entire capital, were given. The civil defense commitee was set up a few weeks ago to prepare the poulation for a possible war. The U.N. Security Council has authorized the use of ``all necessary means'' to dislodge Iraq from Kuwait if it does not withdraw from the emirate by Jan. 15.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says US Forces in Gulf Battle Ready
With AM-Gulf-US Forces, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, contradicting a top military commander, said Saturday allied forces in the Persian Gulf are prepared to deal ``vigorously'' with any Iraqi provocation on a moment's notice. Bush sought to put to rest comments by Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, the deputy commander of allied forces in the gulf, that the troops will not be battle ready by the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for the withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. ``If there was some clear provocation 10 minutes from now, the allied forces are ready to respond vigorously,'' Bush said. Bush spoke to reporters at his wind-whipped, fog-shrouded mountaintop retreat where British Prime Minister John Major was his overnight guest. Bush's statement was backed up in Saudi Arabia, where Defense Secretary Dick Cheney told Marines they can expect to go to war soon after Jan. 15 if Iraqi President Saddam Hussein refuses to leave Kuwait. ``I would think that soon after Jan. 15th if he has not withdrawn his forces from Kuwait we'll be in a position to take military action in conjunction with our allies,'' Cheney said while standing atop an M60-A1 tank in the desert some 50 miles from the Kuwaiti border. Major, who accompanied Bush to the news conference, left the clear impression that British policy is no less aligned with the U.S. stand in the gulf than it was under former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. ``If there is going to be a conflict in Kuwait, that's really a matter for Saddam Hussein,'' Major said. ``He knows what the Security Council resolutions say. They couldn't be clearer ... What's he's done is unforgivable.'' Speaking later to reporters at Andrews Air Force Base before his departure, Major said he and Bush were ``entirely of one mind'' on the gulf crisis. If Saddam refuses to withdraw, ``we are ready to use force to free Kuwait and restore the legitimate government.'' As further evidence that all is well in the British-American connection in the post-Thatcher era, Bush and Major began addressing each other as ``John'' and ``George'' shortly after their talks got under way on Friday. Bush said the American and British positions are ``totally together.'' Under questioning, Bush also said the Soviet Union has given ``every indication'' that its support for U.S. policies in the gulf will continue notwithstanding the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. Major agreed, adding, ``our clear hope is that the expressed direction of Soviet foreign policy and internal political and economic reform will continue unchanged.'' Shortly after Waller made his remarks about the lack of military preparedness in the gulf, the administration began looking for ways to soften their impact. Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Waller really meant that the forces were not as ready as they would like to be ``for all contingencies.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III suggested Waller's remarks were aimed at keeping the Iraqis guessing. ``When I was in the Marine Corps, one of the important principles of warfare that I learned was that it was critical to preserve the element of surprise,'' Baker said. Bush seemed mystified that Saddam has yet to budge despite the massive array of firepower deployed near his borders. ``I am convinced that Saddam Hussein hasn't gotten the message yet for some odd reason ... a message that all of us are determined to fulfill to the letter all of the United Nations resolutions,'' Bush said. He added that he expected to hear more about the preparedness levels of the allied forces on Monday from Cheney and chairman of the joint chiefs of staff Colin Powell upon their return from a tour of U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. Besides the gulf, Bush and Major discussed the impact of the Shevardnadze's resignation, the NATO alliance in the post-Cold War era and efforts to revive the global trade talks, which collapsed two weeks ago. Major said they discussed the ``remarkable changes'' going on in South Africa. ``I told the President and Secretary Baker about the European Community's decision to lift its investment ban and expressed the hope that the United States will soon feel able to lift some of the restrictive measures that they have in place.''

DOC.HEAD: With Minority Scholarships, Inconsistency Reigns
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Education Department last week placed new limits on minority college scholarships. Invoking civil rights law, the department ruled that aid financed from a college's own funds must be color-blind. Yet two months earlier, in a far more liberal reading of those same statutes, a regional office of the Education Department could find nothing wrong with Harvard University's giving admissions preference to offspring of alumni. Both rulings by the same federal agency expose an old truth about college admissions and scholarships: Laws and lofty principles may be invoked one day to support a desired social end, only to be abandoned to suit another occasion. Confusion reigned last week over guidelines on race-based college scholarships. Colleges and civil rights groups generally reacted angrily to the Bush administration's new rules forbidding the spending of institutional scholarship money to redress racial imbalances on campuses. The ruling, issued by the department's assistant secretary of civil rights, Michael L. Williams, gave colleges and universities four years to comply with the new guidelines on minority scholarships. Nearly everyone, including Bush, predicted a long struggle ahead in Congress and the courts. But over the years, colleges and civil rights advocates have proven no more consistent in their principles than the government when it comes to promoting campus diversity or creating a level playing field in granting admissions and financial aid. Until the early 1960s, colleges commonly used racial and ethnic quotas and perverted the financial aid process to limit the numbers of blacks, Jews and other minorities. Yale University, Bush's alma mater, was among the most zealous of the Ivy League institutions in using quotas and aid denials to keep their campus white, Christian and wealthy, according to a 1985 study, ``Joining the Club,'' by Dan A. Oren. Last week, many of the very colleges that had long used quotas and scholarships to exclude minority students were now invoking their right to establish ``goals'' for increasing the campus presence of blacks and others, and to use race-based scholarships toward that end. According to the College Board, 696 colleges and universities offered grants and scholarships based entirely on a student's minority status in the 1990-91 school year. The long-simmering dispute over the fairness of the Scholastic Aptitude Test to minority students displays similar ephemeral patterns. The SAT was first used in 1926, when exclusionary quotas were the rule. The idea was to create an objective measure to test the academic mettle of the college-bound - to move, at last, toward an admissions process that was blind to all but a student's merit. Yet, civil rights and women's groups call the exam biased. They claim that this test, originally devised to open campus doors to the underprivileged, is slamming them shut. And those same civil rights groups that once yearned for a level playing field for minority applicants now can be heard demanding special advantages. College admissions and scholarship policies have always been full of inconsistencies, biases and illogic. Most admissions officials agree that's unavoidable. After all, students are being evaluated, not machines. And the admissions process aims to achieve many goals at once: an academically capable student body, yes, but also a diverse one that includes blacks, whites, Hispanics, some superbrains, some athletes, perhaps a cellist or two. The goal of ethnic and racial diversity doesn't always mesh perfectly with fairness in the awarding of scholarships - and that's where disputes like last week's arise. The latest debate began because an assistant education secretary ingenuously tried to lend an element of consistency to the awarding of scholarships by applying a strict constructionist interpretation of civil rights law. But history suggests that such efforts to tidy up this inherently sloppy business of scholarships aren't necessarily welcomed, or needed. ---= EDITOR'S NOTE - Lee Mitgang has covered education for the AP since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: In The Holy Land, Christmas Comes Three Times A Year
DOC.TEXT: Every child wants Christmas to come more than once a year. In the Holy Land, it does. More than 40 denominations are represented in Israel and they will mark Christmas on three dates - Dec. 25, Jan. 7 and Jan. 19 - with rituals that include bonfires, processions and chanting in Aramaic and Coptic. Such diversity also brings discord. Rival Christian groups jealously guard their rights to the Church of the Nativity in Bethlehem, built in the 4th century over the grotto where tradition says Jesus was born. The rivalry led to pitched battles and injuries in past centuries,and in past decades to fist fights between priests. The latest argument among clerics concerns which sect has the right to repair the church's leaky roof. Daniel Rossing, an Israeli expert on Christian affairs, said the squabbling should be seen in the context of Christians fading to a minority in the Holy Land over the centuries. ``When you've lost so much in terms of numbers and power, you become very protective of what you have left,'' he said. ``What we have here is a microcosm of the Christian world. It may look divided, but we must not forget the vast richness of the many faces of Christian tradition here.'' At no time is the richness more visible than during the Christmas season, marked in the Holy Land more by religious fervor than by the shopping fever of the West. Western rite churches will celebrate Christ's birth Dec. 25, and most Eastern rite sects on Jan. 7. In Jerusalem, the Eastern, or Orthodox, churches stick to the Julian calendar, accounting for the 13-day difference from the Western Christmas on the Gregorian calendar. Armenian Orthodox also use Julian calendar, but will celebrate Christ's birth on the Epiphany, or 12th day of Christmas, Jan. 19. The diversity of Christianity is revealed in the many denominations represented in the Holy Land. There are Chaldeans, a Catholic sect with origins in the Persian Gulf; the Copts from ancient Egypt, and the Maronites, an Eastern sect based in Lebanon with a patriarch recognized by the pope. Others include Greek Orthodox, Syrian Orthodox, Roman Catholic, Armenian, Franciscan, Lutheran, Baptist, Anglican, Presbyterian, Pentecostal, Mormon and Ethiopian Orthodox. Each sect has its own Christmas customs. Syrian Catholics pray and sing around a bonfire outside their St. Joseph's Church in Bethlehem on Dec. 24. ``It reminds us of the shepherds who huddled around a fire on this night, and it also symbolizes the light of Christ,'' said Monsignor Buttros Abdel Ahad, the vicar-general. Anglicans sing carols in Shepherds' Field at Beit Sahour near Bethlehem on Dec. 24 before midnight services. At Christmas dinner of lamb and apple pie the next day, a family leaves an empty seat at the table for a wandering stranger. At St. John's Church in Jerusalem, the Franciscan midnight Mass on Dec. 24 centers on a reproduction of a manger built every year by brother Claudio Barrato, complete with moving figures and lights. ``Sometimes things go wrong and I have to crawl inside and adjust it,'' the 70-year-old monk said with a smile. ``The real thing is the Mass, the devotion. The manger is just something to help the heart.'' On Jan. 18, the Armenian Christmas Eve, the Armenian patriarch enters Bethlehem in a black limousine led by four policemen on horseback, an honor guard given all patriarchs since Ottoman Turkish rule. Various sects used to hold elaborate candlelight processions with bagpipes and boy scout troops, but the pomp was dropped after the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. Most Christians in Bethlehem are Palestinians and Bethlehem is in the occupied West Bank. Many say they cannot celebrate elaborately while fellow Palestinians are being killed or wounded in confrontations with Israeli troops. They still hold Masses on Christmas Eve, however. The Roman Catholic ceremony is most widely known in the West because its traditional choir concert often is shown on television abroad. On Jan. 6, there is another kind of concert. The Greek Orthodox, Syrian Orthodox and Copts all hold services simultaneously in various parts of the Church of the Nativity, their chants in Greek, Aramaic, Coptic and Arabic competing vigorously in volume. A 19th century code spells out each sect's rights in the church, but frequent fights have broken out among the Greeks, Armenians and Franciscans, the sects that act as custodians of the church. Confrontations often occur on the traditional church ``cleaning day'' betweem the Western and Eastern Christmases, since rights to clean parts of the shrine can imply ownership. In one case, some priests entitled to clean the upper part of a church wall had to use 12-foot-long brooms because of an argument over leaning a ladder against the lower part washed by another group. Some past disputes were more involved. In 1847, a silver star disappeared from the church grotto, where it marked the site of Christ's birth. Five years of negotiations, involving French diplomats and the Turks who then ruled Palestine, were needed to reach an agreement on replacing it.

DOC.HEAD: Impossible Shopping Quest Gone to the Dogs
DOC.TEXT: Don't ask Macy's. Don't ask Hasbro. Don't even ask Santa Claus. And don't make any promises to the children. ``Go Go, My Walking Pup'' is sold out. Without the furor that accompanied the Great Cabbage Patch Kid Shortage, the $40 walking dog has became the hot, impossible-to-get toy of the Christmas season. ``It is a product that is impossible to find. There's not enough of them,'' said Thomas R. Kully, a toy industry analyst for William Blair & Co. of Chicago. Nobody knows that better than Hasbro Industries, the Pawtucket, R.I., company that markets the 18-inch, battery-operated white Maltese on a leash. ``Go Go has run out. If there are a handful across the country, I'd be surprised,'' said Wayne Charness, a company spokesman. He said about 300 people a day call the headquarters in search of the dog. They are told that it will be January or February before the company has more Go Gos, which are made in China. ``It's very flattering when a product of yours takes off, but on the other hand, it's frustrating because we can't meet the need,'' Charness said. He would not say how many of the dogs were sold, but Kully estimated sales at between $15 million and $20 million, compared with the $500 million in sales that Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtle figures should do. In most parts of the country, it has been difficult to find the dog since November. Lines formed early outside a Lionel Kiddie City Toys store in New York when a late shipment of the dogs arrived about a week ago. They were sold out as quickly as the purchases could be rung up on the cash register. ``We had lines in other stores in 16 other states,'' said Joel H. Weiner, a spokesman for Lionel Leisure Inc., the parent company of Lionel Kiddie City Toys and Lionel Playworld. Still, he said, Go Go has not caused the kind of stir that the Cabbage Patch Kids made in 1983. The dolls, which are now also marketed by Hasbro, received a rush of media attention early in their first holiday shopping season when they became hard to find. The Go Go dog shortage has gone relatively unnoticed, except by parents trying to find the toy. A spot check of about 20 stores in the New York and northern New Jersey area found that none had the dog and all knew about the shortage. Karen Kraus, a saleswoman in Macy's toy department, said the store gets dozens of calls a day asking about the pup. Of all the new toy products, ``the hottest is Go Go, I guess because it does something - it walks,'' she said. ``It's cute.'' Stores placed orders in June for the dog, which sells for about $40. It reached the shelves by August and a commercial featuring a young girl walking the dog made it high on the list of toys wanted by girls. Hasbro pulled the advertising two weeks before Christmas. ``It's unusual,'' Charness said. ``You don't see products that are as incredibly hot as this one is. The toy industry is a fashion industry. I don't think you can ever really predict what is going to be the hot product going in.'' He suggested parents stuff their children's stockings with IOUs. ``There will be plenty of Go Gos next year,'' he promised.

DOC.HEAD: Bush, Major See Eye To Eye on the Gulf
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBs 8th graf prvs with Major departure, statement of support for driving Iraq from Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, rejecting suggestions that the allied forces in the Persian Gulf are still not battle ready, said today any provocation by the Iraqis would trigger a vigorous response at a moment's notice. At the same time, Bush expressed confidence that the Soviet Union will continue to be aligned with U.S. policy in the gulf despite the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. With British Prime Minister John Major at his side, Bush spoke to reporters on the helipad at his wind-whipped, fog-shrouded mountaintop retreat here. Bush was asked about the comments Wednesday of Lt. Gen. Calvin A.H. Waller, who said in Saudi Arabia his troops will not be ready for combat by the Jan. 15 United Nations deadline for Iraq to withdraw its forces fom Kuwait. ``If there was some clear provocation 10 minutes from now, the allied forces are ready to respond vigorously,'' Bush said. When asked about the impact of Shevardnadze's resignation, Bush said there is ``every indication'' there will be no change in Soviet policy toward the gulf. Major reaffirmed his strong support for U.S. policy in the gulf, much as he did on Friday in private talks here with Bush and in a series of television interviews. Speaking to reporters at Andrews Air Force Base shortly before departing for home, Major said he and Bush were ``entirely of one mind'' on the gulf crisis. If Saddam refuses to withdraw, ``we are ready to use force to free Kuwait and restore the legitimate government.'' Presidential spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Friday that Bush and the recently installed Major are in ``full agreement on almost every point'' on the gulf situation. He did not say where the two disagree. They agree on the need to implement the United Nations resolutions on the gulf and that ``partial solutions are unacceptable,'' Fitzwater said. He added that the leaders also expect that Soviet support for the U.S. position on the gulf will continue notwithstanding the resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze on Thursday. ``They had a very friendly trip. They are on a first-name basis,'' Fitzwater said. Besides the gulf, they discussed the impact of the Shevardnadze's resignation, the NATO alliance in the post-Cold War era and efforts to revive the global trade talks, which collapsed two weeks ago. The Bush administration was distressed when former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher stepped down three weeks ago, but Major has moved quickly to ensure a policy of continuity, particularly on the gulf question. Consistent with the U.S. view on the gulf, Major on Friday rejected the notion that efforts should be made to lure Iraq's Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait through the offer of concessions. ``There is nothing whatsoever to negotiate about,'' Major said. Saddam ``has to go,'' he said. Secretary of State James A. Baker III echoed that sentiment after meeting with Major at the State Department. ``Nobody that I know of is willing to negotiate backwards from the U.N. Security Council resolutions,'' Baker said. ``We simply cannot appease aggression. If we really believe that there's an opportunity for a new world order, we can't start out by appeasing aggression.''

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Resignation Shows Perestroika In Dire Shape
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: With top Kremlin officials speaking last week of the dangers of dictatorship and bloodshed, world leaders wondered whether the Soviets would stumble on their way out of the Cold War era. The stunning resignation of Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Thursday was the strongest signal yet that the reforms that he and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev began nearly six years ago have run off the rails. ``Dictatorship is coming!'' Shevardnadze warned from the congress podium, as Gorbachev and nearly 1,900 parliamentarians listened in shock. KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov warned it would be necessary to ``accept bloodshed if we want to speak about bringing order to the country.'' The streets of Moscow were calm, the sky crisp and blue, the temperature well below freezing. Snow lay on the ground, and families prepared as best they could to welcome the New Year's holiday. But tempers were flaring in the long lines that formed outside nearly empty stores. Some spoke darkly of fleeing the country until the approaching storm blows over. Military patrols were checking citizen's documents in the port city of Klaipeda in the secessionist republic of Lithuania in the north. In the southern republic of Georgia, Shevardnadze's native land, the newly elected non-Communist government announced plans to form its own militia under the republic's Interior Ministry. Violence here, revolutionary or repressive, is almost impossible to control once unleashed, as it has been so many times in the Soviet Union in this century - and so often in Russia and its empire over the past millennium. The Soviet Union has lost an estimated 40 million people to war, famine and terror since the Bolshevik revolution of 1917. They know suffering, and fear it as much as they fear a return to the past. Shevardnadze's emotional speech thrust those fears firmly into the center of Soviet political debate. He criticized neither Gorbachev nor the Soviet leader's proposals to further strengthen the powers of the presidency, a step that other reformers have warned could lead to a return to dictatorship. But Gorbachev was angered by the speech, which he said caught him by surprise. He said he had planned to appoint Shevardnadze to the post of vice president, to be created under his proposal to forge a ``fully empowered'' presidency. Gorbachev's public acknowledgement that he was planning to remove Shevardnadze from the foreign ministry confirmed fears expressed by some reformers, that foreign policy would fall into the hands of Yevgeny Primakov. Primakov, despite his apparent loyalty to Gorbachev, does not carry Shevardnadze's mantle as architect of the end of the Cold War. Since the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait last August, Gorbachev has dispatched Primakov on diplomatic shuttle missions that were designed to avoid the use of U.S. military force in the Persian Gulf. Primakov's meetings with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein were viewed by some Soviet and Western observers an effort to balance Shevardnadze's clear alliance with the U.S. administration on gulf policy. That alliance offended many Soviet conservatives, who objected to abandoning a longtime ``anti-imperialist ally,'' Iraq, and to any use of Soviet armed force in the Persian Gulf - particularly in league with Washington. The military conservatives are led, at least in public, by two colonels who are members of the congress - Viktor Alksnis and Nikolai Petrushenko. Shevarnadze alluded to them in his resignation speech. The colonels practically crowed with delight as Shevardnadze resigned. But the reformist newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda lamented that ``now the American versions of Alksnis and Petrushenko have received evidence that they were right'' in warning that the Kremlin could not divorce the past so easily. The maneuvering over foreign policy, vital to the outside world, paled in comparison to the titanic struggles being waged over the future of Soviet domestic policy, the very structure and shape of the nation. Although Shevardnadze did not criticize Gorbachev or his efforts to strengthen the presidency, he clearly intended his speech as a rallying cry to what he called the ``scattered'' forces of reform. Other reformers took up where Shevardnadze left off. ``Reactionaries, centralists, and imperialists have united and are on the attack,'' Ukrainian delegate Vladimir Chernyak told the congress Friday. ``At the head of the coup stands Gorbachev. It's possible he himself doesn't know it,'' said Chernyak. ``By demanding for himself more and more powers, he is creating the legal basis for a dictatorship - maybe not for himself personally.'' ---
EDITOR'S NOTE: Bryan Brumley, The Associated Press Bureau bureau chief in Moscow, has covered Soviet affairs since 1981.

DOC.HEAD: Volunteers, Retired Soldiers Filling In for Activated Reservists
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of National Guardsmen called to duty in the Persian Gulf are being temporarily replaced in some states by volunteers whose duties include watching over vacant armories and assisting in natural disasters. Usually called the state guard or the state defense force, groups totaling nearly 10,000 such volunteers - mostly retired soldiers and sailors - exist in 24 states and Puerto Rico. ``We're sort of a has-been force until we're needed,'' said Tom Anderson, president of the National Association of State Defense Forces. Most have been relatively inactive in recent years, but Persian Gulf call-ups have expanded the role of these purely state-operated organizations, said Anderson, commander of the New Mexico State Defense Force. ``We have people from all walks of life. I would say that our membership is pretty much split between veterans as well as young people having no military service whatsoever,'' said Commander Robert Haas of the 750-member Ohio Military Reserve. None of the organizations has federal status, although the National Guard Bureau in Washington, D.C., assists the states in coordinating their activities. The governors can call up the state units to help with disasters and other activities usually handled by activated Guard units. Size, duties and history of the units vary widely. Texas has a 1,300-member state guard, and units in Tennessee and Georgia number about 1,000. Rhode Island's State Defense Force, created in 1987, numbers just three, and Vermont's 8-year-old state guard consists of 12 retired military officers. The 400-member Indiana Guard Reserve last summer provided relief and assisted in the cleanup of southern Indiana hit by devastating storms. Last year, the Virginia Defense Force helped with crowd control at 17 events around the state. It has done search and rescue missions and is helping a small town develop a plan to handle toxic chemical spills. Some of the units, such as Alaska's, were formed at statehood. Others were authorized by state constitutions and some formed during World War I. In Mississippi, the State Guard operated under an attorney general's opinion until the Legislature put it into the law in 1989. Many units have deep roots in U.S. history. New Mexico's militia traces its beginnings to an organization know as ``Los Vecinos'' (the neighbors), dating back to 1606, when the Spanish explored the Rio Grande valley. Georgia's State Defense Force traces its heritage to a colonial militia organized in the Massachusetts Bay Colony in 1636. In Michigan, the recruitment of military retirees begins in earnest next month. The Michigan Emergency Volunteers is re-emerging, after having florished during the two world wars before being disbanded in 1946. ``We've had it before,'' said retired Brig. Gen. Warren Lawrence, who will oversee the organization. ``It's something that really should be in place, at least in skeletal fashion to activate on a needs basis.'' Much of the state guards' work right now is voluntary. None has been called to duty by executive orders of governors. In few states, if activated by the governor, state units would get the same pay as National Guardsmen. ``Right now, we're watching over about 55 National Guard armories across the state,'' said Maj. Gen. Roy H. Swayer Jr. with the Mississippi State Guard. ``Our volunteers have gone into these armories as custodians to keep up with what is going on.'' Members of the Tennessee Defense Force are repairing doors, helping with finances and generally cheering spouses of mobilized National Guard troops. ``We've gotten an enormous amount of volunteer work going on, with people assisting units that have mobilized - lawyers helping draw up wills, helping with family support groups, things like that,'' said Brig. Gen. Frank Pointer. Tom Hegele, a member of the North Carolina State Defense Militia, said the groups are volunteers in every sense of the word. ``At a time like this, there are people out there who wish there was something they could do to help,'' said Hegele, who works for a state agency. ``This might not be much, but for some people it is a way they can contribute,'' he said. ``We're telling people who might have aged out of active service or the Guard to look us over and see if they're interested.''

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Pudding, Mince Pie Illegal Under Olde English Laws
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 1 graf background at bottom.
DOC.TEXT: Merrie, merrie Englande is once again planning its traditional Christmas dinners, largely unaware that the long shadow of 17th century killjoy Oliver Cromwell hangs over the festivities. The staunch Puritan who ran the country between 1642 and 1660 banned hearty Christmas feasting - and no one can say for sure that the law has been revoked. So it may still be illegal in terms of the 1644 Act to bake and eat mince pies and Christmas pudding on Christmas Day. Cromwell ruled that these were ``abominable and idolatrous confections to be avoided by Christians.'' And woe betide anyone who manages a Christmas dinner of more than three courses - simple gluttony to Cromwell's Puritan way of thinking. Geoffrey Humphrys, who has spent hours among the statute books in his local library, says he believes Cromwell's law is probably still in force. ``Some people argue that the Cromwell era was simply a kind of interim period between the dissolution of the monarchy and its restoration and that his laws are not to be taken seriously,'' he said in an interview from his home in North Walsham, Norfolk. ``But some are still on the statute book. I've seen them.'' Fortunately the Puritans' more drastic anti-Christmas measures did get the chop, according to J.M. Golby and A.W. Purdue, authors of ``The Making of the Modern Christmas.'' ``For a dozen years the traditional Christmas festivities were prohibited: Parliament sat on Christmas day, its soldiers attempted to ensure shops were open and the churches remained closed while evergreen decorations were prohibited,'' they said. Finally, the good and aggrieved men of Kent marched in support of Christmas jolliness. Ten thousand signed a resolution that ``if they could not have their Christmas day, they would have the king back on his throne.'' With the restoration of the monarchy after Cromwell, most Christmas customs were legalized once again. According to Golby and Purdue, the Puritans objected to Christmas celebrations because the holiday was rooted in pagan worship. Ancient Britons celebrated Dec. 25 as The Birthday of the Unconquered Sun, marking the death of the old year and the beginning of the new. But Cromwell wasn't the only spoilsport in English history who tampered with Christmas, Humphrys has discovered. The Holy Days and Fasting Days Act of 1551, never revoked according to Humphrys' research, makes it illegal to skip church on Christmas Day and there are penalties for those who have ``no lawful or reasonable excuse to be absent.'' This law, he says, also obliges worshipers to walk to church and back. Other exercise is largely forbidden: the only sports allowed by the Lawful Games Act of 1541 are archery, leaping and vaulting, according to Humphrys. An Act of 1625 decrees that footballers may kick a ball around, but only in their own back yards, as ``there shall be no meetings, assemblings or concourses of people out of their owne parishes for any sporte or pastime whatsoever.'' That law is still rigorously enforced. There is also no chance of going out and shooting the extra pheasant if unexpected guests arrive. A law enacted in 1831 says the only legal use of a weapon on Christmas Day is in defense of the realm or in self defense, says Humphrys. The office of the Lord Chancellor, chief legal officer of England and Wales, was tickled by Humphrys' Christmas thesis. ``We don't really have an expert on this subject,'' said a spokesman, cloaked as always in anonymity. ``Obviously, it's a bit obscure.'' However, he said it was quite likely Humphrys was correct. ``If something is in the Statutes in Force book, it is still the law, no matter how old it is.'' However, legislation of 1831 stipulates nobody can be arrested for anything but serious crime or breach of the peace on Dec. 25, Humphrys said. And anyway, he adds, policemen should not be on the beat on Christmas Day. A law promulgated under King Charles II in 1677 state that ``noe servant, artificer, workeman, labourer or other person whatsoever shall do or exercise any worldly labours, business or worke of their ordinary callings'' on that day.

DOC.HEAD: Opponents Throw Bottles At 6 Robed Klansmen in Cincinnati

Eds.: Leads with 13 grafs to UPDATE with seven arrests and one injury to a fire captain, revises crowd size to 1,500, sted 250 based on police estimate, quotes from police. DELETES outdate material. Picks up 10th graf pvs: `The U.S. ...'
LaserPhoto covering
DOC.TEXT: Six robed Ku Klux Klan members gathered in a downtown plaza today and were met by 1,500 people who shouted down their speeches and threw objects at them, police said. Seven people were arrested. Police sprayed Mace to stop protesters who charged them as they escorted the Klansmen to a nearby building after the 45-minute rally in Fountain Square. A demonstrator who threw something at one of the Klanman's cars as they drove off was among those arrested on charges of disorderly conduct. At least one fist fight broke out in the crowd. ``It was getting ugly real quick,'' said Assistant Police Chief Edward Ammann. He said police recovered 40 to 50 objects the protesters threw during the rally, including rocks, ball bearings, pieces of machinery and a two-pound can of sliced pineapple. ``It's one of the more serious demonstrations that we've had,'' Police Chief Lawrence Whalen said. One fire captain was injured when he was struck in the arm by a thrown object, Whalen said. No other injuries were reported. The Klansmen, barred by a City Council directive from concealing their faces behind hoods, erected a 10-foot wooden cross in the square, which is decorated with Christmas trees, as protesters shouted ``Death to the Klan!'' City officials cited safety concerns in denying the Klan permission to set fire to the cross. A Klansman began the rally by holding up a Bible and yelling, ``Life, life through Jesus!'' But when the speaker grabbed a bullhorn, jeers and taunts drowned out the rest of his address. ``America loves ignorant idiots,'' one heckler yelled. ``It's a damn shame the city is protecting them,'' shouted another. Police had said they did not expect a large turnout of Klan members. ``The history of these things is if you have two dozen Klansmen there, you'll have a lot,'' Ammann said. The U.S. Knights of the Ku Klux Klan, based in Hamilton, had planned to have several speakers at the rally. Ron Lee, the group's imperial vice president, had said he wanted no violence. As ordered by the city, the Klansmen removed the cross after the rally because the city opposes leaving religious symbols on the square. City lawyers have said Cincinnati wants to avoid legal debates about government entanglement with religion. The Klan obtained the rally permit after a federal judge allowed a Jewish congregation to put a menorah on the square for the full eight days of Hanukkah. City Council members on Wednesday enacted a ban on wearing hoods or masks on public property, saying they were concerned about the possibility of violence. Violation of the ordinance is punishable by up to of 30 days in jail and a $250 fine. Councilman Nick Vehr, who proposed the ordinance, said police need it to identify lawbreakers. Vehr modeled the ban on a 39-year-old Georgia law, which was upheld by that state's Supreme Court this year. Lee had said that after going ahead with its rally, the Klan would file a lawsuit in federal court challenging the new ordinance as a violation of members' civil rights.

DOC.HEAD: On Christmas, Little Time to Dwell on Family
DOC.DATELINE: ABOARD THE USS JOHN F. KENNEDY (AP)
DOC.TEXT: Instead of getting married over the Christmas holidays, Navy Lt. Dan Turner will be practicing combat tactics in his A-7 light attack aircraft. Petty Officer 2nd Class Joseph Roberts desperately wants to spend Christmas with the 3-month-old son he's never seen. But he'll be repairing jet engines. Trying to cope with his first Christmas away from his family, Fireman Apprentice Deval Sanders will spend the day helping to run the generators on the aircraft carrier USS John F. Kennedy, a prospect he finds ``very depressing.'' Eight Christmas trees have been flown to the carrier in the northern Red Sea. The catapult shuttle that hurls the attack jets and fighters into flight has been painted with the words ``Merry Xmas.'' The American public has overwhelmed the ship with Christmas cards and goodies. But even with the trimmings, much of the traditional holiday spirit will be missing for the 5,200 sailors and fliers on the Kennedy who know they could be at war with Iraq within weeks. Capt. John P. Gay, a decorated Vietnam War combat pilot who took command of the 82,000-ton carrier earlier this month, has decided that Christmas is going to be a regular working day. That means most of the 70-odd strike aircraft on the carrier will be flying, which will leave few sailors much time to dwell on war, peace or family celebrations back home. Capt. Jim O'Connor, the carrier's chief chaplain, said it would be a low-key Christmas. ``You don't want to overdo it because guys are trying to work through being away from their families,'' he said. ``If you overdo it, you simply deepen the pain, shall we say. It's going to turn them off.'' Since the Kennedy is in international waters, Christmas services can be held openly - unlike in Saudi Arabia, where only Moslem religious observances are legal. The U.S. military said religious services for troops in the desert will be held privately. There will be a Christmas Eve candlelight service for Protestants on the Kennedy, midnight mass for Catholics, a Christmas Day service and a band of roaming troubadors singing carols from table to table in the mess halls. ``There's a certain intensity at this time because of the possibility of war and there's that matter of separation,'' said O'Connor, a 51-year-old Lutheran minister from New Port Richey, Fla. ``I myself think this is a time to take Christmas seriously ... and ask Jesus to be the Prince of Peace,'' he said. From the boiler room in the bowels of the huge carrier to the bridge overlooking the flight deck, there is a sense of unease. Nobody knows when they're going home. Everybody's life is on hold. For Lt. Turner, a 29-year-old pilot from Jacksonville, Fla., Christmas was supposed to be spent with his parents in San Diego and four days later he was to walk down the aisle with his fiance, Jodee. ``We're trying for March 23, but I don't know if we're even going to make that,'' he said. Instead of pre-wedding festivities, Turner will take a break from flying and join fellow pilots to open stockings sent by the wives' club of VA-72 Squadron. Their ``ready room'' is adorned with a Christmas tree, decorations, and a huge card on the wall with photos of wives, girlfriends, children and pet dogs peeping out of Christmas ornaments. For Roberts, a 31-year-old aviation maintenance technician from Boston, Christmas is going to be ``lousy'' because he still hasn't seen his son, Ryan Thomas. ``I've seen pictures of him,'' he said. Sanders, a 22-year-old damage control apprentice from Michigan City, Ind., said he knows he's going to be ``a little homesick'' on Christmas. ``I've got to block it out,'' he said. Other members of the crew are trying to cope in different ways. Petty Officer 3rd Class Janofsky Herrion, 21, of Essex, Mo., a mechanic, said he's glad Christmas won't be a holiday here. ``If we (weren't) flying, we'd just be sitting around wondering what our families are doing, wishing that we could be there. Our reality is we're out here and we've got a job to do,'' he said. ``It's going to be a special Christmas for me, just because of all the support we've gotten from back home,'' said Lt. Cmdr. Val Diers, 33, of Norman, Okla., the maintenance officer for an A-7 squadron. Speaking of the gift packages, he said: ``I'm convinced by the end of this cruise I will have gained 20 pounds and all my teeth will have fallen out - it's that bad.''

DOC.HEAD: Answer to Sugar Shortages in Iraq: Dates
DOC.TEXT: Resourceful Iraqi bakers may have found one answer to shortages of sugar caused by the U.N. sanctions imposed against Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait. Dates are the Iraqis' favorite winter fruit. But they have rarely tried to turn them into desserts. Now, though, confectionaries are now making date-based sweets instead of the traditional, richer sweets that require plenty of sugar, flour and fat to make. The younger generations have heard about a delicacy called madgoga from their grandmothers, but a few have tasted the sweet. Madgoga ``is cheap and easy to make. I wonder why we had forgotten it and have only remembered our best traditional sweets in this hour of crisis,'' said Abdul Hussein Jawad, whose family is a well-known Baghdad sweetmaker. Jawad said he makes madgoga by adding sesame paste to ground dates. Sometimes he adds nuts and coconuts to make it tastier and more nourishing. Dates and milk constituted the staple diet of Bedouin tribes in the desert, mainly because the fruit is rich in vitamins and milk prevents dehydration. Madgoga was rediscovered after sweets shops were forced to close in the wake of international sanctions that followed the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The embargo has forced the government to ration food items including cooking oil, flour, milk and sugar. These items have disappeared from the markets, but families receive limited quantities from government centers. Iraq claims that more than 2,000 children under age 5 have died because of shortages in medicines and baby food that followed the U.N. embargo. Diplomats say there are no serious shortages of basic medicines. Iraq, the world's leading producer of dates, used to provide international markets with more than 80 percent of its supplies. Under the U.N. trade embargo, Iraq was expected to lose about $50 million in date exports this year. The country produces 300 kinds of dates but exports about 20 varieties, keeping the rest for domestic consumption.

DOC.HEAD: American Sailors Recount Harrowing Escape
With AM-Gulf Capsize, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Chief Petty Officer Lance Vickery recalls waves tumbling into the stern of the bobbing ferry headed back to the USS Saratoga and joking, ``Whoa, looks like we're flooding.'' Only minutes later, his words came true, turning a simple ride back from Christmas shore leave into a harrowing fight to survive. The Israeli ferry Tuvia capsized shortly after midnight on Saturday, throwing more than 100 men into the cold waters of Haifa Bay. At least 19 sailors drowned, and scores were injured. The sailors were part of the multinational force arrayed against Iraq. Vickery, 33, was among four American sailors interviewed at Haifa's Rambam Hospital. He is from Jacksonville, Fla., is not far from Mayport, the Saragota's home port. Three of the sailors said the boat had been taking on water over the stern in heavy seas, then capsized when it was hit by a big wave. Vickery said the fatal wave came about a minute after he had cracked his joke. ``All of a sudden, I saw water just come flying in,'' he said. ``And it was maybe two seconds, and the boat rolled right over.'' The 13-year veteran sailor found himself trapped in the ferry's cabin, frantically struggling to find a window as the ship sank. ``I started breathing in water and almost died,'' Vickery said. ``If I had been under the water maybe another 30 seconds, I wouldn't be lying here right now. I'd be in one of those body bags out there.'' When he made his way to the surface he found ``guys floating everywhere, screaming and yelling like chaos.'' Despite his own predicament, he grabbed a struggling fellow sailor by the collar and dragged him toward a floating, plastic foam life ring. One rescue boat, already overloaded, passed by and threw life preservers. In what ``seemed like an hour,'' another boat came, also full. ``So they just dragged us through the water back to the Saratoga, and I was a real happy person to see those guys snatching me up,'' he said. As Vickery was being treated for bleeding lungs caused by water inhalation, his hospital roommate, Seaman Michael Benjamin, 19, of San Antonio, Texas, was recovering from a neck injury suffered when a rescue boat hit him while he was in the water. Both were wearing blue hospital pajamas and, when they walked to the visiting room's balcony could see the Saratoga anchored outside the Haifa harbor. Benjamin, who has been in the navy for just a year, said the ferry had been jostled in heavy seas. ``As we were going on the waves, I just noticed one that was bigger than normal and then another one that was bigger than normal,'' he said. ``The next thing I know, all I saw coming in was water,'' he said. Benjamin said he dove from the ferry, then had to swim frantically to get away from the suction of the sinking boat. Clinging to a foam plastic float, he was passed by one rescue boat and hit by a second. ``I looked around and I see this big hull coming at me and we were all yelling, but I guess the ship didn't see us,'' he said. ``I was trying to get out of the way, but I got hit by the ship.'' Dazed, Benjamin stripped off his jacket, shirt and shoes and kept treading water until he found a piece of driftwood to cling to. ``I was scared,'' he admitted. ``I was having a hard time staying up in the water.'' A rescue ship picked him up, he estimated, about a half hour to 45 minutes later. Two other men interviewed at Rambam Hospital identified themselves as Technician John Richards, 31, of Twin Lake, Mich., and Airman Lamont Jones, 20, of Claremont, Va. Both were breathing with difficulty despite gas masks. Richards recalled seeing a large wave and feeling the ship heeling to one side. ``All I can remember thinking is, `Oh my God, it's sinking,' and then I was scrambling for my life,'' he said faintly.

DOC.HEAD: Big Business For Airlines, Moving Companies As U.N. Deadline Nears
DOC.TEXT: Throughout the Persian Gulf region, airline tickets are selling out and moving companies are busy packing as foreigners rush to leave before the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face possible force. Britain, Ireland, Sweden and New Zealand are among countries that have recently advised dependents of nationals working in Bahrain, neighboring Qatar and parts of Saudi Arabia to leave the region before the deadline expires. Travel agencies are being flooded with calls as thousands try to purchase air tickets - either because they're leaving soon, or as a precaution in case they have to leave later. ``The phones are ringing all the time,'' said Bill Horsley, sales manager at Bahrain's Kanoo Travel Agency, one of the largest in the region. Horsley said companies were booking seats in blocks on some flights to Europe and other points to ``make sure that their people are protected.'' Airlines and travel agents surveyed in Bahrain said flights to Britain, the Philippines, India and Egypt were fully booked from about Jan. 4 through Jan. 15, with long waiting lists. In some cases the lists are so long they've been closed off. ``I wouldn't say there's panic, but concern is spreading,'' Horsley said. He added that many of those who have reserved seats may not use them after all, citing the period immediately following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, when about half the passengers who bought tickets out of the region later sent them back for refunds. The British community in Bahrain is down from around 9,000 before the invasion to 4,500, and numbers are still falling following the British government's advice that all dependents should leave by Jan. 15. There about 750 U.S. nationals in Bahrain. The U.S. government has not advised citizens to leave, and embassy officials say there is no immediate sign of an American exodus. The officials have assured Americans that they will be protected in case of war and evacuated if necessary. About half of this island nation's 500,000 inhabitants are expatriates. So far, India, Pakistan, the Philippines and other Third World nations that provide the bulk of the expatriate work force in Bahrain have not advised their citizens to leave. The foreign exodus from Bahrain does not appear to be as pronounced as in eastern Saudi Arabia. There, the great majority of Westerners are reported to be leaving, except for those in essential jobs. The U.S. community, mainly oil workers and their families, has shrunk from 12,000 people to 8,000 in recent weeks and the exodus is expected to accelerate before Jan.15. Among those Britons planning to stay in Bahrain with his family is Richard Warnes, a senior engineer at the state-run electricity company who has been in the country for 12 years. ``When the shooting starts the first thing that will happen is Bahrain airport will be closed and we'll be stuck here,'' said Warnes, 43. ``We've decided we'll stay here and sit it out. We're expecting a shooting war. It's going to be pretty nasty, a lot of troops are going to suffer.'' But Warnes expressed confidence in the defensive shield laid around Bahrain by the U.S.-led multinational force, including anti-missile and anti-aircraft defenses. He acknowledged there is a risk that Iraqi missiles with chemical warheads might get through and hit Bahrain. But he was confident that 99 percent would miss their targets or be shot down. ``Our main worry is what will happen with the schools,'' said Warnes, father of a 6-year-old girl and 7-year-old boy. As civilians leave the island, schools have been losing teachers and some are shutting down. Moving companies report a heavy workload as expatriate families ship their household belongings out of the region. ``We're seeing more people moving for good, rather than just sending some of their stuff away,'' said Louise Foster of Scotpac International Removals. Ms. Foster said the company was shipping out dozens of households a week - and only two households have shipped their belongings into Bahrain through her company so far this month.

DOC.HEAD: Flames Burn Marina, Three Forced To Jump In Water To Escape
DOC.TEXT: Boats and a building caught fire at a marina pier on the Lake Washington Ship Canal early Saturday and three people jumped into the water to escape the flames, officials said. Firefighters had to fight the blaze in below-freezing temperatures and cramped space at the end of a dead-end street. The National Weather Service said the temperature was in the teens and the wind-chill factor near zero. The fire was at the Leco Marine pier, east of Ballard Bridge on the south side of the canal that links Lake Union with Puget Sound. The blaze was fueled by creosote-treated wood on the pier and by barrels of flammable liquids after spreading to a two-story building used by LeClair Marine Construction. Firefighters and witnesses said the fire apparently started in a wood stove aboard a 30-foot pleasure boat moored at the pier. However, fire department spokesman Albert Smalls said he could not confirm that was the cause. When the flames spread to the pier, one couple tried unsuccessfully to start their boat motor to flee. The crew of a police boat told them to jump in the water. ``They said bail out, and then they threw their dog in the water,'' said Kent Ferris, who watched from shore. ``About 30 seconds later the boat went up.'' Smalls said a third person also jumped. There were about 30 boats along the shore, and some burned, with flames leaping from boat to boat. Smalls said at least three boats were destroyed. He said damage would be significant but had no dollar estimate. Three people were treated at the scene for smoke inhalation, Smalls said.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Down Dramatically at Refinery, But Not at Gas Pumps
DOC.TEXT: While crude oil prices have plunged since October, the sign at Fletcher's Amoco last week still read $1.37 a gallon for unleaded gasoline, only a couple of pennies less than when oil prices peaked nearly two months ago. And Fletcher's isn't alone in being slow to drop prices. Its pump price reflects the national average, according to the American Automobile Association. Many factors may be helping to keep prices up, but a major reason is that dealers are trying to recoup losses they incurred in August when their profit margin was severely squeezed. ``We would like to keep the prices coming down,'' said Bobby Fletcher, owner of the station along a busy commuter corridor outside Washington. But in an interview last week, Fletcher said he couldn't make sharp cuts and still keep a reasonable margin, considering what he pays for gasoline and a recent federal gas tax hike. The Exxon station across the street showed the same price, and a Crown gas-and-go down the road was just a penny cheaper.
