Industry officials say retail prices are, in fact, coming down and in recent days some dealers have dropped unleaded regular a few pennies a gallon. Some of that decline, however, has been masked by the 5-cent increase in the federal gasoline tax last Dec. 1. The slow price decline has left many motorists perplexed as they recall the lightning price increases that took place at gasoline pumps in the days after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait when the price of crude oil soared. Although crude oil prices have fallen from a peak of $40.40 a barrel in early October, to about $27 a barrel last week, the price of retail gasoline has remained almost steady during most of that period. In its pre-Christmas survey of 5,000 service stations, the American Automobile Association reported Friday the average price for unleaded regular gasoline was $1.37 a gallon, only 1.4 cents lower than in the week before Thanksgiving, or about 30 cents a gallon higher than beore the Persian Gulf crisis began. Wholesale gasoline spot prices on the New York exchange closed last Thursday a penny lower than pre-Iraqi invasion levels, and crude prices were only 17 cents a gallon higher. ``We think it's outrageous,'' said Joan Claybrook, president of Public Citizen, a Washington consumer advocacy group. She said that with the current roller-coaster price situation for oil and refined products there was too much ``opportunity to maneuver'' all along the line from oil production to retail sales. ``They're trying to recoup some of the costs that they claim was never passed along. But the motorist is at the end of the chain and ... has not had the relief,'' says Richard Hebert, a spokesman for the AAA. But those in the oil industry - from producers to refiners to gasoline dealers - vigorously deny any price gouging. Their prices are dictated primarily by supply and demand, they argue. ``We're returning to our normal margins,'' said Charles Dibona, president of the American Petroleum Institute, the oil company trade group. ``The price of crude went way up, the price of gasoline went up half as much, the price of crude is falling back somewhat and you're back to a normal relationship.'' Phillip Chisholm, executive vice president of the Petroleum Marketers Association, said dealers and middlemen were severely squeezed in August and September between rising costs and pressure to keep prices down. ``A lot of them are trying to recover the margins that they lost,'' he said. Gasoline prices never increased as much as crude oil partly because oil companies heeded the pleas from President Bush in late August and September to curb prices. Refiners and retail dealers took the hit. According to figures compiled by the American Petroleum Institute, spot crude prices increased 46 cents a gallon in the two months after Iraq invaded Kuwait. Refiners on average passed only 33 of those cents onto dealers who, in turn, passed only 25 cents to their customers. As a result, their margin - the difference between what the gas costs them and what they sell it for - virtually disappeared for a time. Some dealers reported selling gasoline for what they paid for it and absorbing overhead costs. A few days after the price of crude hit $40.40 a barrel in early October, wholesale gasoline prices peaked at nearly $1 a gallon. At the pump, service station owners added on taxes - 30 to 35 cents, depending on the locality - and transportation costs, plus a margin. According to industry experts, dealers typically want to maintain a 6 cent to 7 cent margin, which includes their overhead costs and a profit. Retail prices jumped to about $1.38 cents a gallon on average nationwide in early October, according to the AAA surveys. As tensions eased somewhat in the Mideast, the price of crude began to drop through November and December, and oil companies began to lower wholesale prices as well. Average wholesale prices at the refineries - before taxes and transportation - were 97 cents a gallon in late October. Those prices dropped to 77 cents by mid-December, only about a dime higher than pre-Iraqi invasion levels, according to API figures. ``Our average wholesale gasoline price in the 30 states we market is down about 20 cents a gallon from middle October,'' said Neal Geary, a spokesman for Amoco in Chicago. Mobil reported that prices to its dealers have dropped about 8 cents a gallon this month. Those wholesale price reductions in general appear not to have been matched by dealers. At Fletcher's Amoco, the price hit a peak of $1.44 on Dec. 1 after the nickel-a-gallon federal tax went into effect. It has since droppe to $1.37. Fletcher wouldn't reveal his wholesale price, referring such questions to Amoco. ``To some extent you're trying to recoup'' from the lost margins as crude oil prices soared, Fletcher said. But customers are price sensitive and he anticipated further declines soon.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Shakes San Jose
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with reports of damage to businesses. Will be led as soon as more details become available.
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook this central American capital Saturday, causing some damage and sending a panicked population into the streets. The tremor measured 7 on the Richter scale, according to radio reports. The reports said the earthquake damaged businesses and shattered windows across the city. Injury reports and further details were not immediately available. The quake, which hit at 11:28 a.m. local time (12:28 p.m. EST), cut off telephone and electric service. A reading of 7 on the Richter scale indicates a major earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Combat Doctors May Use Experimental Drugs Without Patient Consent
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration says Army doctors in the Persian Gulf need not obtain patient consent before using experimental drugs on the battlefield, particularly in the event of chemical or biological warfare. The new rule, signed Friday by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan and Deputy FDA Commissioner James S. Benson, grants Defense Department requests to waive patient consent in using ``investigational new drugs'' in ``certain battlefield or combat-related situations.'' ``Combat-related'' might mean only the threat of combat, the regulation said. Armed forces doctors, like civilian physicians, normally must get informed consent before using such drugs. But the Pentagon, in an Oct. 30 letter to the FDA requesting the waiver, said ``military combat is different.'' ``If a soldier's life will be endangered by nerve gas, for example, it is not acceptable from a military standpoint to defer to whatever might be the soldier's personal preference concerning a preventive or therapeutic treatment that might save his life, avoid endangerment of the other personnel in his unit and accomplish the combat mission,'' the letter said. ``Based on unalterable requirements of the military field commander, it is not an option to excuse a non-consenting soldier from the military mission, nor would it be defensible militarily, or ethically, to send the soldier unprotected into danger.'' Investigational new drugs are those that have emerged from formal clinical trials and are being used by physicians who promise to report results, but have not yet been granted full approval by the FDA. The Pentagon and FDA did not reveal what drugs were involved, but the Pentagon stressed that ``these are not exotic new drugs.'' But Dr. Sidney M. Wolfe, director of the Public Citizen Health Research Group, said Saturday the new regulation was ``an outrage'' because it told soldiers in the field they ``are going to become guinea pigs for drugs not proven to be safe and effective.'' Wolfe said there was still more than three weeks before the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline authorizing the use of force if Iraq does not leave Kuwait. There is plenty of time to have soldiers sign consent sheets concerning use of experimental drugs, he said. ``It is immoral and unethical to force people to go into battle having them subjected to unknown risks of unknown drugs,'' Wolfe said. The Pentagon letter, which was published Friday in the Federal Register, said among drugs being considered were a common intramuscular injector in a different packaging and a vaccine long recognized as effective against a specific disease but not used enough to accumulate data needed for a regular drug license. Another is ``a drug in common use at a particular dosage level, but to preserve alertness of the soldiers, we prefer a lower dosage tablet'' that the FDA has not approved, the Pentagon letter said.

DOC.HEAD: Paper's Apology Calls Editorial `Misguided And Wrong-Headed'
With AM-Editorial Recant
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of The Philadelphia Inquirer's editorial in Sunday's editions, headlined, ``An apology,'' and subtitled, ``The editorial on `Norplant and poverty' was misguided and wrong-headed.'' --- It's rare that we regret publishing an editorial from almost the moment it appears in print. And it's rarer still that we feel the need to apologize to our readers for a misguided and wrong-headed editorial opinion. But such is the case with the editorial that appeared in this space on Dec. 12 entitled ``Norplant and poverty.'' Great pain, anger and controversy have resulted from that editorial, and we deeply regret our decision to print it. Among the people who were incensed by the editorial were many of the Inquirer's own reporters, editors and members of the Editorial Board. In the days since it appeared, we have been doing a lot of listening and soul-searching. We realize now that we hastily and foolishly juxtaposed two news items that appeared in the Inquirer the previous day - federal approval of the long-term contraceptive Norplant and the release of a research group's report that said nearly half of black children are living in poverty and that the situation is getting worse with time. The editorial posed the question of whether encouraging women who are on welfare to use Norplant could help reverse this bleak trend. Where did we go wrong? Let's begin with the headline, which asked whether contraception could ``reduce the underclass'' and thus aroused people's fears of something far worse than promoting birth control. Later, we used the word ``eugenics'' as a way of explaining what we didn't mean, but it only inflamed matters more. Most fundamentally, in linking the issues of race and contraception, we left too many people with the impression that our cure for poverty was to reduce the number of black people. Although that certainly was not what we meant to suggest, the fact that so many people interpreted it that way is a clear indication that the editorial was fatally flawed. Therefore we failed in our effort to provoke thoughtful discussion on the issue of birth control and poverty. It's true that many single young women lessen their chances of escaping poverty by having children too early in life. But it's also true that the very hopelessness of their circumstances often underlies the decision not to postpone child-bearing. Creating hope where none now exists must be the main tenet of any effective war on poverty. In the previous editorial we said that women on welfare should be encouraged, but not compelled, to use Norplant. We suggested incentives, such as an additional benefit of some kind. Our critics countered that to dangle cash or some other benefit in front of a desperately poor woman is tantamount to coercion. They're right. We still believe that this new form of reliable birth control, which is likely to have wide appeal to middle-class women, should be equally available to poor women who want to use it. But we also realize - and should have been even clearer about it - that this has to be a matter of personal choice. We don't seek to limit the options of poor women, but to empower them. We remain committed to a whole host of strategies for reducing poverty - from better schools to job training to radical welfare reform. We think education about birth control is important, and if Norplant lives up to its advance billing, it could be helpful to many women. And we wish we had said it that way to begin with. The earlier Norplant editorial undercut our credibility and our efforts to be a thoughtful, responsible and compassionate voice on the complex issues of poverty. We apologize to those we hurt and offended.

DOC.HEAD: From Electrician to Head of State: Walesa Takes Oath as President
LaserPhotos WAR50,52
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa, who led Solidarity's 10-year struggle to depose Communist rule, took the oath Saturday as his nation's first popularly elected president and declared Poland finally free of foreign domination. The 47-year-old labor activist, a peasant's son who was educated to repair machinery, pointedly excluded his Communist predecessor from the swearing-in ceremony before Parliament. He pledged that Poland would become a stable element in a peaceful Europe, seek friendly relations with its neighbors and continue the dramatic market reforms started by the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who Walesa defeated in the elections. Walesa's swearing-in came a decade after he led the shipyard strike that created the East bloc's first independent trade union, and one year since he put together its first non-Communist government. ``I solemnly swear to the Polish people that I will be faithful to constitutional decisions. I will protect the dignity of the nation, the sovereignty and security of the state,'' said Walesa in a clear voice, holding up his right hand. His wife, Danuta, stood solemnly at his side. Walesa did not invite President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the longtime Communist leader who imposed martial law to crush Solidarity in 1981 and imprisoned Walesa for nearly a year. Present instead of Jaruzelski was Ryszard Kaczorowski, president of the anti-Communist government-in-exile in London. The government-in-exile was set up after the prewar Warsaw government was forced to flee the Nazis in 1939. Kaczorowski, 71, was received as a head of state as he returned to his homeland for the first time on a specially dispatched government plane. Handing over the presidential insignia, seals, handwritten constitution and other symbols of prewar authority in the gilded Royal Castle, Kaczorowski said the government-in-exile had fulfilled its mission and could now cease to exist. Walesa also accepted the blessing of the church. A Mass was scheduled in his honor by the Roman Catholic primate, Cardinal Jozef Glemp. Hundreds of people chanting ``Our president! Our president!'' lined the narrow cobblestone lanes of the Old Town when Walesa walked the short distance from the castle to St. John's athedral. He raised his hand in his familiar V-for-victory sign, made famous during Solidarity's struggle. In his inaugural speech, Walesa said: ``The evil era when the authorities of our country were appointed under pressure of foreigners or as the result of forced compromises is ending.'' Poland has known only 21 years of full independence since it was partitioned in 1795. It was reconstituted as the Second Republic in 1918, only to fall under German and then Soviet-imposed Communist rule for 50 years until Solidarity took over the government in 1989. Jaruzelski remained as president under a negotiated deal. He stepped down early to make way for new elections. Walesa pledged Poland now would become ``an element of the peaceful order in Europe.'' He said it seeks good relations with Germany and its neighbors to the east: Lithuania, Ukraine, Byelorussia and Russia. He did not mention the Soviet Union. He told Poles that Saturday was the beginning of ``the Third Polish Republic,'' but that they must believe in themselves. ``Passivity and apathy - these are the biggest obstacles on the road toward the well-being of Poles,'' the president said. ``When we start to work with confidence, the most developed countries will show more interest in us as well.'' He promised to stick to the shock economic reform program named for Finance Minister Leszek Balcerowicz, which he said was a sign to the world of Poland's ``determination and ability to make sacrifices.'' After taking his oath, the beaming Walesa was rewarded with cheers of ``Sto Lat'' (``May You Live 100 Years'') by parliamentarians and invited guests. Later, he visited the presidential palace, Belweder Palace, where he received a traditional Slavic welcome in the form of bread and salt. The former army corporal also received a pledge of loyalty from Poland's generals and admirals in an outdoor military ceremony. Walesa's critics, citing his dominating personality and reliance on national symbols, have voiced fear he might become a strongman. He won a landslide victory Dec. 9 over businessman Stanislaw Tyminski. But the bitter election campaign shattered Solidarity's unity, leaving Walesa alienated from his rival, Mazowiecki, and most of his former intellectual advisers. As president, Walesa is chief of state and commander of the military. His first task will be to nominate a prime minister to run the government on a day-to-day basis. He must also prepare for elections that will replace the parliament elected under the 1989 bargain with the Communists that guaranteed 65 percent of seats to the now-dissolved party and its allies. Walesa said Thursday that he will not name a prime minister until after the holidays.

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Lotteries Dish Out $1.1 Billion Payoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to CORRECT that 90 ticket-holders divided top prize. Pick up 4th graf, `Thousands more...'
DOC.TEXT: Jubilant workers in Valencia shut their factory down early and residents of a modest Madrid suburb flocked to the streets Saturday to celebrate winning part of Spain's $1.1 billion Christmas lottery. The state lottery's top prize was the $236 million ``El Gordo'' (The Fat One) - divided among 90 ticket-holders. Since each of the 90 tickets cost more than $250, most were split among families, friends, club members and colleagues. Once somebody bought a ticket, he or she could divide it into many shares as desired. Thousands more Spaniards won other substantial prizes in the annual drawing, which Spain bills as the world's richest. About $105 million in prizes was spread about the Madrid suburb of Alcorcon. Police said extra units had been called to duty to control heavy traffic as winners began a street party near the outlet that sold the tickets. ``You can imagine what it's like with everyone in the street,'' he said. ``Since the prize was well distributed, practically every bar is having a private party.'' The 200 employees of a refrigerator factory in Valencia split $95 million. Those working the Saturday shift hugged each other on the factory floor and then closed down for the day. The Christmas lottery has been a holiday fixture since 1818 in Spain, where Carlos III established state lotteries in 1763. The lottery awarded a total of $1.1 billion in prizes, including $236 million for ``El Gordo.'' Total ticket sales this year were $1.56 billion, 70 percent of which went to prize money and the rest into state coffers. Per capita income in Spain was $8,673 in 1988, the last year for which figures are available.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Denied Request To Spend Holiday With Parents
DOC.TEXT: A woman free on bail after admitting that she tried to hire a hit man to kill her parents will not be allowed to spend Christmas with them, a federal judge has ruled. U.S. District Judge Diana Murphy said she sympathized with Heidi Steiro's desire to see with her parents, but turned down the request Friday even though her parents wanted to see her. Earlier this month, Steiro, of St. Anthony, admitted that she instigated the murder-for-hire scheme but pleaded guilty to a lesser charge of making a threatening phone call. She is free on bail while awaiting sentencing but is prohibited from seeing her parents, though she talks to them frequently by phone. Assistant U.S. Attorney Joan Lancaster said she has concerns about the safety of Steiro's parents. ``Apparently, Mom and Dad want her back,'' Lancaster said. ``To be so forgiving of somebody who has hired somebody to kill you I find quite remarkable.'' Steiro, 21, was arrested in September after she offered an undercover officer $45,000 to kill her parents and made a phone call to make sure they would be home on the weekend she wanted them slain, authorities said. Steiro, who was working as a lab technician at the University of Minnesota, told authorities she stood to inherit $2 million. Her attorney, F. Clayton Ryder, said he will keep trying to reunite Steiro and her parents, Richard and Gloria Steiro, of Boulder Junction, Wis. Ryder said Steiro was disappointed but understands the judge's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Ambitious Museum Fails to Get State Certification
DOC.TEXT: It was billed as a big idea with big results: converting an abandoned factory into the world's largest museum of contemporary art. But five years later, the project that piqued interest in art circles and set hope alight in this struggling mill city has run into a serious setback. State planning officials refused to grant full certification to the plans. Inspector General Joseph R. Barresi, a vocal critic, said that as a practical matter that decision will ``close the book'' on the museum. But proponents stoutly deny the project's dead. ``We've pulled this out of the fire before,'' said North Adams Mayor John Barrett III, who's also chairman of the cultural development commission that oversaw a $1.7 million feasibility study. ``I've been in the game too long to just fold,'' said David Ross, director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston and another commission member. The plan to turn the old 28-building Sprague Electronics Co. factory into the home of huge, minimalist works and other contemporary art, was hailed at its inception as a way to bring benefits of the state's then strong economy to a forgotten corner of the Berkshires. But then the state's fortunes dropped, and questions arose. ``We can't deny essential services to mentally retarded and elderly people while we buy millions of dollars of modern art to be placed out in the Berkshires,'' said state Rep. Greg Sullivan. A statement released last week from Gov.-elect William Weld's office said only that he would take ``a very good hard look at it, but he feels as though it's going to have to compete with other projects given existing resources.'' Among the questions raised by critics of the project are its attendance projections. Proponents project that the museum would bring 130,000 people or more a year to the site, at least 2{ hours by car from Boston. Critics note that that would be more than the number of people who visit the nearby Clark Art Institute, which has traditional works of art and has free admission. Thomas Krens, who devised the idea while he was director of the Williams College Art Museum, said he's optimistic about the project, but he added: ``Over the course of the last year, the rules have subtly shifted in the middle of the game.'' Krens, now director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York, resigned from the cultural development commission at a meeting this month after members voted to send out a request for operating proposals from established institutions, including the Guggenheim. At that meeting, its first in more than a year, the commission approved a revision of the original plan study, sending it on to the Division of Capital Planning and Operations. It excluded hotel and other commercial space and carried a price tag of about $45 million for the first phase, compared with earlier estimates of $77 million. A key change was the decision to request proposals for an operator, a decision proponents likened to looking for an anchor store for a shopping mall. But then the Division of Capital Planning and Operations' deputy commissioner, John I. Carlson Jr., said he could certify only two of the five key items, the physical plans and cost estimate. Carlson said he could not certify as feasible parts of the plan dealing with a required 30 percent non-state share of the financing, management and operations plans, and the availability of art and money for its installation. Carlson's decision was released Monday by Barresi, not Carlson himself. Carlson followed that release with a terse statement leaving the door open for a revised plan from the museum proponents that could possibly meet his objections. In his decision, Carlson urged the drafting of a new grant agreement. It should include such specific conditions as securing a museum operator and presenting a business plan and five-year operating budget projection.

DOC.HEAD: Port Where Ferry Tragedy Occurred Is Frequent R&R Spot
With AM-Gulf-Capsize, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Israeli city of Haifa is a frequent port of call for American sailors seeking rest and recreation. Last year, more than 45,000 sailors attached to the U.S. Sixth Fleet visited the hilly Mediterranean city. At least 19 American sailors were killed early Saturday when a chartered Israeli ferry capsized as it was carrying them back to the USS Saratoga after shore leave in Haifa. The Saratoga, part of the 6th Fleet, is deployed in the region as part of Operation Desert Shield, the military buildup launched after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Accompanied by three escort ships, the Saratoga had dropped anchor off Haifa on Thursday, and shore leave for 1,920 of the crew began Friday. Sailors rescued from the capsized ferry said they had spent their shore leave having dinner, drinking or visiting discotheques. Haifa, Israel's third-largest city, has been a liberty port for U.S. sailors for about 20 years. Despite its mixed Jewish-Arab population, the city has been relatively unaffected by the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Last year, a budget crunch almost forced the closing of USO operations in Haifa. The USO has a library, a sitting room, a canteen and an information center. Volunteers help visitors arrange tours of the Holy Land. The center was saved by appeals from the 6th Fleet, the Jewish Institute for National Security Affairs in Washington and congressional intervention. Many American visitors have compared Haifa to San Francisco. Biblical Mount Carmel is a backdrop to the city, and steep roadways lead away from the port. The city, with about 240,000 residents, has been continuously inhabited since the 14th century B.C. and was the site of Elijah's biblical conflict with pagan priests.

DOC.HEAD: A Look At Poland's New President
With AM-Poland, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronology of important events in the life of Lech Walesa, who was sworn in Saturday as the first popularly elected president of Poland: --- December 1970 - An electrician at Lenin Shipyward in Gdansk, Walesa helps lead his first strike when protests over food price increases sweep the Baltic ports. Dozens are shot by security police. Walesa is arrested and temporarily dismissed from his job. 1976 - Shipyard again dismisses Walesa for criticizing Communist-linked union. 1978 - Unemployed because of his activism, Walesa begins organizing free trade unions independent of the Communist Party. August 1980 - Walesa jumps the fence of the Lenin Shipyard to take charge of a strike, eventually signing agreements with the Communist government creating Solidarity, the first independent trade union in the Soviet-bloc. Leads the union through tumultuous months as new freedoms sweep Poland and discontent with the Communist regime grows. Dec. 13, 1981 - Is interned under martial law. Released in November 1982. December 1983 - Is awarded Nobel Peace Prize but does not go to Oslo to collect it for fear he will not be allowed to re-enter Poland. May and August 1988 - Waves of strikes combined with rising social discontent and a collapsing economy force the Communist regime to make its first overtures to Solidarity. April 1989 - Solidarity is restored to legal status. June 1989 - In partially free parliament elections, Soldidarity wins all but one seat available to it. August 1989 - Walesa proposes Tadeusz Mazowiecki as the first non-Communist prime minister in the East bloc. Dec. 9, 1990 - After a volatile campaign, Walesa wins the presidency by a 3-1 margin. Dec. 22, 1990 - Walesa is sworn in as president.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Honored For 75 Years of Perfect Attendance at Church
DOC.TEXT: Marguerite C. Grotte would have gotten her 75th perfect attendance award at church last year, but that snowstorm in 1917 was a real beaut. Miss Grotte started attending the Rugby Congregational Church in Brooklyn's Flatbush section in 1914 and has made it in every week since then - except for that one blustery morning 73 years ago. On Sunday, church officials plan to present her with an attendance pin signifying 75 years in which she has had perfect attendance, said Richard A. Ebbitt, deacon emeritus. That's 1915, her first full year at the church, then 1916, 1918, and every year through 1990. Miss Grotte, who's believed to be about 80 but refuses to confirm or deny it, takes the bus to church every week, where she has served as church clerk since 1940 and as Sunday school superintendent since 1955. She also plays the piano and teaches a class of 5- and 6-year-olds. ``There's a great deal of enjoyment attached to it,'' she said, ``and yes, I think I still learn things from the children.''

DOC.HEAD: Dull-As-Dishwater Governor's Accomplishments Little Known Outside State
DOC.TEXT: He left no footprints on the national scene and was considered dull as dishwater at home. But Gov. Joe Frank Harris quietly put his mark on Georgia through education reform and the historic appointment of a black to the state's highest bench. Harris retires next month after eight years in office, to be succeeded by Lt. Gov. Zell Miller. ``The criminal justice system was one of the last bastions of Old South racism, and his breakthrough there was important,'' said Joseph Lowery, president of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Lowery said he gives Harris an ``A-1'' grade for appointing black lawyer Robert Benham first to the Court of Appeals and later to the Supreme Court. Harris also sent the National Guard to racially troubled Forsyth County in 1987 to protect civil rights demonstrators staging a march against segregation that drew national attention. Jimmy Carter's progress on civil rights in his 1971-1974 term helped him jump from the governor's mansion to the White House. But national attention wasn't in the cards for non-smoking, non-drinking, no-cussing Harris. ``I haven't been flamboyant,'' Harris conceded in a recent interview, explaining that the lack of razzle-dazzle in personal style stemmed from a bit of fatherly advice years ago. ``Something my dad used to tell me is that people can spot a phony three miles away and that you need to be what you are. And that's what I've always tried to do - to be Joe Frank Harris. ... Day in, day out, I just want to be what I am.'' Education reform was the issue that dominated his administration, but he also doubled the size of the state's prison system and directed the passage of legislation to bring order to the state's haphazard growth. He kept a lid on taxes for his first term, making good on a campaign promise that helped put him into office. But he didn't renew the no-tax pledge to win re-election in 1986, and three years later presided over the largest tax increase in state history. Now, the state is teetering on the edge of a recession-induced financial slide. Environmental issues were particularly troublesome for Harris. His attempt to build a hazardous waste disposal facility rekindled an environmental movement in the state as angry opponents of the project banded together. The facility still has not been built. Harris, a state legislator for 18 years, was elected to office in 1982 with the backing of the conservative church vote, a boost from his no-new-taxes pledge and the support of his political mentor, powerful House Speaker Tom Murphy. Education reform was the persistent dream of the Harris administrtion. Shortly after taking office, he appointed an Education Review Commission. The result was a legislative act that restructured the way Georgia schools were funded, organized and taught. The reform boosted state and local spending for education by 75 percent over five years, and early indicators show student scores are up. But the state still is troubled by a high dropout rate, and teachers and administrators still complain of low salaries and too much paperwork. On the social front, his administration reacted to publicity about the chaotic state of procedures for investigating suspected child abuse by supporting legislation designed to improve the system. There were modest increases in welfare benefits during his administration, and tentative steps toward helping the homeless. But critics give him his lowest marks for social concerns. ``I feel like Joe Frank never did listen to the cries of the poor, the sick, the helpless or the children,'' said Frances Pauley, an 85-year-old human rights activist. ``I don't think he set us back,'' said Lowery of the SCLC. ``I just think he didn't drag us forward.''

DOC.HEAD: Syrian-Backed Palestinian Group Opens Baghdad Office
DOC.TEXT: The Syrian-backed Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine reopened its office in Baghdad Saturday, 11 years after it was closed by the Iraqi government following a split with Damascus. Abdul-rahim Malouh, a member of the group's Politburo, said reopening the office was meant to express solidarity with Iraq in its standoff against the United States in the Persian Gulf crisis. Malouh said the Damascus-based group would fight alongside Iraq if war erupted, but he did not elaborate. The PFLP, formed by George Habash in 1967, is a Marxist radical faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. It has one seat on the PLO's executive committee and is the second-largest group in the PLO next to Yasser Arafat's Fatah. Iraq closed down the group's offices in 1979 shortly after Baghdad and Damascus, ruled by rival wings of the Arab Baath Socialist Party, broke relations. Malouh said the group will maintain its main offices in Damascus, although he acknowledged that the Syrian government might not be happy about the group's having an office in Iraq. ``The reopening of our office at this time has a very significant meaning. It means we support Iraq fully and completely in its struggle against the United States,'' he said. Malouh said the group did not consult the Syrian government before opening the office in Baghdad but Damascus has not objected to it. Syria has committed 20,000 troops to the U.S.-led military buildup in the Persian Gulf region. Habash visited Iraq after the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and said the PFLP would support President Saddam Hussein in his effort to link the Palestinian issue with resolution of the gulf crisis. Saddam has tried to link an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait with an Israeli withdrawal from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The Palestine Liberation Front, headed by Abul Abbas, has offices in Iraq. Another radical faction, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine, is expected to open its offices here soon. That group is headed by Nayef Hawatmeh, who split with Habash in 1969 after a dispute over ideology and direction.

DOC.HEAD: Bumper Harvest Is China's Good News-Bad News Joke
DOC.TEXT: Like farmers all over China this year, Ma Ziwen reaped one of his best wheat crops ever. But the bumper harvest has brought disappointment for Ma and problems for the government. The official media for months have been filled with reports of a bountiful grain harvest from the high plateaus of Tibet, where barley is grown, to the fertile rice paddies of the southeast. The crops were so plentiful that free market prices tumbled. That meant Ma, a young farmer in northern China's Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, lost the profits he expected from farming 10 extra acres this year. He'd hoped to earn enough to buy a bicycle. For the government, the harvest is like a good-news, bad-news joke. It had mounted a major campaign this year to increase grain production and organized peasant brigades to irrigate more farmland. But it found it lacked money to buy the harvest and facilities to store it. The situation is not as severe as in the Soviet Union, where distribution problems are expected to lead to widespread hunger this winter despite a record grain harvest. But China does stand to lose much of the extra grain to spoilage. One official estimate is that 42 million tons are lost every year because of poor storage facilities. This year, the loss likely will be higher because 33 million to 44 million tons of the 462 million ton harvest are being stored outdoors. China last year reaped 448 million tons, equaling a 1984 record. Most of China's grain is sold to the state under contracts that farmers sign individually each spring. They are free to sell anything they produce over contract on China's small free market. But this year's big supply caused free market prices to fall. Ma said he had hoped to get 1,300 yuan, or $250, for the 2,200 pounds of grain he had left after fulfilling his contract. Instead, free market buyers offered 820 yuan, $160. Meanwhile, the grain keeps flooding in. In late November, more than a month after the harvest, farmers still were bringing loads to Ningxia's Hexi Township granary even though it had long since been filled, granary workers said. The nearby Tongxin County granary stopped buying after it filled its warehouse in late October, said granary director Yang Hanyu. That's exactly what Beijing wants to avoid. It has ordered local grain bureaus to buy all grain if farmers do not want to sell their extra crops on the free market. The government promised loans from the central bank to pay the bills but the money has been slow in coming. The government fears social unrest in the countryside if farmers take heavy financial losses. It also fears farmers will refuse en masse to plant as much grain next year and instead choose high-profit crops such as tobacco. With the population at 1.13 billion and growing 1.5 percent annually, the government says China must produce at least 500 million tons by the year 2000 just to keep pace. China imported 14 million tons of grain this year, much of it from the United States, but hopes to become self-sufficient. Increasing the harvest is not as easy as this year's bumper crop made it look. Although the state increased spending on agriculture by $496 million, or nearly 8 percent, officials acknowledge a key reason for the good harvest was unusually good weather. In order to make significant long-term gains, the state would have to reorganize its agricultural system - something that could be politically as well as economically difficult. It would mean replacing the millions of tiny, family farm plots with farms large enough to use heavy machinery and well-managed enough to use advanced technology. It would also mean raising returns to farmers.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Inquiry Finds No CIA Link to S&L Scandal
DOC.TEXT: Congressional investigators found no evidence to suggest that the CIA was involved in the nation's savings and loan scandal, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee says. Rep. Anthony Beilenson, D-Calif., made the disclosure Friday in announcing that the committee has decided not to proceed with a formal investigation of ties between CIA operatives and failed S&Ls. The committee conducted a nine-month preliminary inquiry following reports in The Houston Post that 26 failed S&Ls were either controlled by, or lent money to, CIA operatives or organized crime associates with connections to the agency. The committee staff found five former CIA operatives, but uncovered no evidence that they used their associations to ``facilitate fraudulent activities at financial institutions,'' Beilenson said in a letter to Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., who requested the inquiry. Annunzio is chairman of the House Banking subcommittee on financial institutions. The Post pointed out in a story Saturday that it never published any allegations that the CIA operatives named in its stories fraudulently obtained loans by using their CIA connections. The subcommittee staff found at least four institutions that were used by the CIA for financial services. But the staff said it could not find any evidence that funds had been used to support unauthorized CIA activities. The Post quoted the committee's chief counsel, Michael Sheehy, as saying the panel's staff had not attempted to track any S&L money obtained by CIA operatives to determine if it had been used for illegal CIA-related purposes. Beilenson said that in some cases, individuals claimed to know sources with information about CIA involvement in savings and loan failures. But he said they ``either refused to identify the source or the source refused to be interviewed.''

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Put Off Vote on Powers, KGB Chief Warns Of Bloodshed
With AM-Soviet-Analysis, Bjt
LaserPhoto MOSB4
DOC.TEXT: Soviet lawmakers, still reeling from last week's sudden resignation of their foreign minister, on Saturday put off a controversial vote on granting more power to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. KGB chief Vladimir Kryuchkov, meanwhile, warned the country to brace for potential bloodshed in ethnic and separatist conflicts. He told lawmakers the KGB needs more authority to combat economic sabotage and militant nationalism. Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's parting warning that hard-line lawmakers were pushing Gorbachev to create a ``dictatorship'' apparently struck a chord, forcing deputies to think carefully about giving Gorbachev emergency presidential powers. The 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies decided to begin preliminary voting on the issue on Monday. Anatoly Lukyanov, chairman of the commission that drafted the amendment on presidential powers, said lawmakers disagreed on some provisions and wanted more time to make changes. The official Tass news agency quoted Lukyanov as saying some deputies wanted to ``build anew the whole structure of state power.'' Gorbachev is seeking direct control over a reorganized executive branch of government to deal with a worsening economy and fragmenting union. ``If parliament trusts the president, it should untie his hands and not hold him on a rope of parliamentary debate,'' said Lukyanov, who is also a deputy in the Congress. Lawmakers did give preliminary approval to a law setting down rules for holding nationwide referendums. The law would require the signatures of 2 million citizens before holding votes on any subject except changing national or republic borders. Gorbachev has said he wants referendums held this winter on whether to allow private property and on whether the 15 republics should remain in a union. All 15 of the republics have declared some form of sovereignty or independence. The KGB chief warned that the restiveness could lead to violence. ``Today, if we undertake decisive actions to restore order, we have to accept the fact that there could be bloodshed,'' he told lawmakers. ``We will not avoid more serious consequences if we don't start immediately to fight destructive forces,'' Kryuchkov said. He also said outside forces ``are trying to exert overt and covert pressure on the Soviet Union and to impose doubtful ideas and plans to pull the country out of its difficult situation.'' The KGB chief accused U.S. intelligence of gathering information on workers' movements in the Soviet Union ``for its purposeful masterminding'' and of funding ``anti-Soviet formations'' such as radio stations that attack the Soviet Union. Kryuchkov did not say what kind of ideas he thought foreigners were trying to impose on the Soviets. He said some suppliers of humanitarian food aid were contributing to problems faced by the country, saying that 40 percent of a recent grain shipment contained spoiled or inferior quality seeds. Reformist lawmakers played down Kryuchkov's speech. Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin told reporters in the lobby: ``Yes, there is sabotage, yes there is corruption ... We have heard all this before.'' Algimantas Cekuolis, spokesman of the self-declared independent Lithuanian government, accused Kryuchkov of using scare tactics that have failed before. ``If he is speaking about bloodshed, then it will be him who causes it,'' said Cekuolis, who was attending the Congress as an observer. Many Congress members remained perturbed by Shevardnadze's resignation. Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, whose own resignation has long been demanded by liberals, called Shevardnadze's method of quitting during the Congress ``unusual.'' ``There is a definite resignation procedure and he should have taken advantage of it. If I paid attention to criticism, I could have hanged myself long ago,'' he said, according to Tass. Shevardnadze had said he was tired of defending the government's policies. Yeltsin dismissed rumors of a conspiracy by right-wing lawmakers to remove reformists from Gorbachev's government. ``This is an invention aimed at aggravating the situation as to make strong presidential power a necessity. This is the only thing (the Kremlin can do) to set things in order,'' he said, according to Tass. Gorbachev met with Shevardnadze for two hours on Friday, reportedly to discuss some way of keeping his longtime ally in the government. It was not known whether Gorbachev intended to ask Shevardnadze, a respected diplomat and longtime ally in reform, to continue as foreign minister or to take another post. Foreign Ministry spokesman Vitaly Churkin said Shevardnadze's decision to quit was ``irreversible.'' Officials had no further information Saturday about a possible replacement for Shevardnadze. Presidential spokesman Vitaly Ignatenko said Shevardnadze and Gorbachev did not speak on Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Hold First Sanctioned Opposition Rally, Union Declares Independence
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Albanians on Saturday held the first legal opposition rally in decades, cheering demands for the release of political prisoners and for more reform in the Communist nation. Also Saturday, the country's trade union declared independence from the Communist Party, promising to fight for higher pay and better conditions for workers, a union official said. Chants of ``Freedom!'' and ``Democracy!'' echoed from about 12,000 people gathered at the peaceful one-hour rally in Tirana, the capital. It was called by the Democratic Party of Albania, an opposition party legalized last week. The boisterous crowd, some waving Albania's red flag with a ouble-headed eagle, roared approval when opposition leaders demanded the release of political prisoners. Leaders also demanded freedom of worship. The tiny Balkan nation is the last in Europe to be ruled by a Stalinist regime. On Friday, however, Communist leaders began dismantling the cult of Stalinism, ordering all statues and symbols bearing the Soviet dictator's name removed. The Communists promised a government change earlier this month, but it is not clear how far Albanian leaders are willing to go toward creating a true democracy. Albania's new opposition has encountered numerous obstacles. Opposition leaders say local Communist officials still hinder activists traveling to provincial cities. Journalist Lazar Stani said after the rally that the Communists had agreed to permit the appearance of an opposition newspaper twice a week - a major opposition demand. Stani said the paper, Democratic Renaissance, would would be published this week. There was no government confirmation that permission had been granted. Student protests over conditions in slum-like dormitories swelled two weeks ago into demands for democracy, and helped force the ruling Communists to permit other parties. On Saturday, police sealed off side streets near the site of the rally, but reporters saw no arrests or clashes between police and demonstrators. Three trucks with helmeted riot police swiftly appeared when chanting crowds leaving the rally site got to central Skanderbeg Square, about a mile away. But the demonstrators moved on when ordered to do so by police. Another police cordon guarded the giant statue of Albania's Stalinist founder Enver Hoxha, which dominates the square. Opposition party leaders urged the cheering crowd at the rally to work peacefully for democracy. Violence and vengeance have scarred the history of Europe's most isolated and backward nation, and the new opposition wants both to contain popular discontent and to avoid provoking a backlash from the Communists. The main message from the new party was that Albanians - who have known only feudalism or Stalinist repression - have nothing to fear from freedom. Economist Gramoz Pashko, a founder of the opposition party, assured Albanians that they would not suffer in a gradual transition to market economy but would get the chance to own land and make money. Heart surgeon Sali Berisha, another founder, demanded the postponement of parliamentary elections from Feb. 10 to at least April. The February date leaves the opposition little time to organize against the powerful Communists. State television briefly showed the rally on its evening news, but gave a vague account of opposition demands. Also Saturday, the 850,000-member official trade union declared it would no longer act as ``the lever of the party,'' said Genc Resuli, head of the union's International Department. The break with the Communists was approved by the union's 201-member Central Committee, he said. The union also pledged to work for higher pay and better conditions, including a cut in the working week from six to five days, Resuli said. Many Albanians say rising food prices mean they are struggling to manage on wages averaging $50 a month. In a development apparently related to efforts to improve the economy, the state ATA news agency reported the reshuffling of some posts including the ministries of transport and finance, and the appointment of a new head of the Albanian State Bank.

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Kill Arab Attempting to Infiltrate From Jordan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with Jordanian officials denying knowledge of incident. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `Also Saturday...'
DOC.TEXT: Israeli troops on Saturday killed a man carrying a firebomb after he cut through a border fence from Jordan, the army announced. Jordanian officials denied any knowlege of an infiltration attempt. It was the eighth attempted infiltration from Jordan this year. Arab reports said witnesses saw a second man wounded and captured him, but an army spokesman denied this. ``An army border patrol spotted tracks of one individual,'' said the spokesman, who cannot be identified by name under military regulations. ``They followed them until they encountered the person and opened fire.'' The incident occurred near the Jewish settlement of Argaman in the occupied West Bank. Argaman is 30 miles northeast of Jerusalem. The infiltrator was carrying a firebomb and two copies of the Koran, the Moslem holy book, the spokesman said, suggesting he was a Moslem fundamentalist. In the last reported infiltration from Jordan, an Israeli soldier was killed Nov. 13 by a 17-year-old Jordanian who penetrated an army position near the Adam Bridge near the West Bank city of Jericho. The teen-ager was captured. In Amman, a senior military spokesman said that Jordanian authorities ``are unaware of any infiltration attempt from the Jordanian territories into Israel.'' ``After investigations, our army units... did not find any traces of any infiltration across the borders,'' said the spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Also Saturday, the body of a retired Palestinian postal worker was found in the West Bank town of Jenin, Arab hospital officials said. They identified the man as Yasser Abul el-Assan, 35. Jenin residents said he was suspected of collaborating with Israeli authorities but that no Palestinian group immediately claimed responsibility for the attack. The army confirmed the killing and said it was under police investigation. El-Assan's death raised to 322 the number of Palestinians suspected to have been killed by fellow Arabs since Palestinians launched an uprising against Israeli rule three years ago. Most were accused of collaboration with Israeli authorities. At least 779 Arabs have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians, and 57 Israelis have also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Charles Churns Through Desert Dust Aboard A Tank
LaserPhoto DHR3
DOC.TEXT: It wasn't quite Santa on his sleigh dashing through the snow, but Prince Charles churned through the desert dust on a tank Saturday bringing Christmas cheer to British troops and U.S. Marines. A herd of camels wandering along a nearby oil pipeline provided a biblical touch. But there were no Christmas trees in sight, only clumps of scrub grass in the undulating sand. For members of Britain's famed Desert Rats and half a dozen U.S. Marines, however, it was Charles himself that made the Christmas season special, not the trappings. ``It was thrilling,'' said Capt. Michael Castagnero, 34, of Pitcairn, Pa., who spent hours with his soldiers reading a People magazine article on protocol and practicing bowing their heads in preparation for the visit. ``We have a lot in common because he was married the same month I was. You watch how his marriage is unfolding - the same as mine - so it's been kind of interesting,'' he said. But Castagnero said that bowing didn't come easily for the Marines, who are coordinating U.S. air and sea fire support for the British regiment. ``It's usually chest high, head up,'' he said with a laugh. British Lance Cpl. Steve Layland of Liverpool, who was a bit nervous about meeting royalty for the first time, said the prince's visit made his Christmas. ``He's cool,'' he said. ``It really is a terrific boost to everybody's morale,'' said Lt. Col. Arthur Denaro, commander of the Queen's Royal Irish Hussars, who were part of the legendary Desert Rats in North Africa during World War II. Hours after arriving in Saudi Arabia, Charles took a 10-mile ride through the desert on a Challenger tank named Churchill in honor of Britain's World War II prime minister, who fought with the Irish Hussars in the late 1890s. The 42-year-old heir to the British throne, who only recently recovered from a serious double break in his right arm suffered in a polo accident, jumped off the tank with ease and saluted Denaro, an old opponent on the polo field. `At least I climbed on without breaking the other arm,'' Charles joked about his tank ride. ``I didn't drive it.'' ``I can salute, which is a great thing,'' he added. The prince then shook hands and chatted with several British tank crews and the Marines, asking about their non-alocholic Christmas and the Anglo-American language barrier. Denaro, who laughingly noted that his army polo team had defeated Charles' on several occasions, had a serious message for the prince. ``We're ready to go,'' he said. ``We've got some brigades fully up and running and a full brigade with a division coming in, and they'll be ready, too.'' Charles said he was impressed with the Anglo-American alliance in the desert, where British troops are under U.S. tactical command. ``It's marvelous to see them all in such good form - good sense of humor, which is what really keeps everybody going,'' he said. Marine Lance Cpl. Joseph Horvath, 19, of Oak Lawn, Ill., had only one regret - that Charles had not brought Princess Diana. ``It would have been nice to see the princess - really liven things up here,'' he said. ``All you see driving down the street is the Arab women with the veils over their faces and you can't really see them.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: 100 Soviet Jews Arriving Every Hour
DOC.TEXT: The emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel peaked in a weekend airlift with an average of 100 newcomers arriving every hour, news reports said. Israel television reported that from Thursday night to Saturday morning, 5,500 Soviet Jews arrived and another 1,500 were expected on eight flights by early Sunday. A spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which handles immigrant transportation, could not immediately confirm the figures. Israeli officials have said the upsurge of immigration was due to fears of political instability in the Soviet Union. This was exacerbated by the resignation on Thursday of Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, who warned the country was sliding into dictatorship. They also cite the economic crisis in the Soviet Union, and improved transportation arrangements that allow Jews to fly out of the former Soviet bloc capitals. On Saturday, the Jewish sabbath, the government waived a ban on flights and ordered the national carrier El Al to use every plane available to ferry the Jews from Eastern Europe. Officials expect more than 30,000 Soviet arrivals in December, bringing the year's total to about 200,000. That figure includes Jewish immigrants from Ethiopia and elsewhere. In 1949, the biggest year of immigration in Israel, 240,000 Jews arrived. Officials expect 1991 to be the biggest year of immigration to Israel. Israel's population of 4.7 million does not include 1.7 million Palestinians and 100,000 Jewish settlers living in the occupied territories. Palestinians are worried the emigres will be used to colonize the occupied territories. he Israeli government recently announced plans to build new housing for Soviet arrivals in Arab east Jerusalem. The pace of immigration is causing housing shortages and unemployment among the immigrants. Israeli officials are fearful the thousands arriving also will overwhelm schools and social services. In Tokyo, the new U.N. high commissioner for refugees said Saturday there are concerns of a mass exodus from the Soviet Union as problems mount there. ``I hope not, but there's a great concern among the Europeans,'' said Sadako Ogata, a U.S.-trained professor and specialist in human rights. She added that some officials in Japan are also closely watching the Soviet emigre situation because of the proximity of the two nations. ``You have to recognize we're neighbors,'' she said. Mrs. Ogata, 63, replaces Thorvald Stoltenberg, who recently resigned to become deputy prime minister of Norway.

DOC.HEAD: Drug Traffickers Criticize United States in Letter
DOC.TEXT: Drug traffickers Saturday said the United States has no right to judge Colombia's government for allegedly taking a softer stance in its war on the cocaine trade. The Medellin cocaine cartel, using its pseudonym The Extraditables, made its statements in a letter addressed to the U.S. ambassador in Colombia, Thomas McNamara. A copy of the letter was sent by fascimile mail to news organizations. President Carlos Gaviria's new strategy entails ending extraditions to the United States and giving reduced sentences to cocaine traffickers who surrender and confess. On Tuesday, reputed Medellin leader Fabio Ochoa surrendered to authorities. U.S. officials have expressed concern the new policy may hurt regional anti-drug efforts, and the traffickers' letter was apparently in response to the U.S. reaction. The traffickers' statement said the U.S. officials ``are the only ones in the world who negotiate with drug traffickers.'' The traffickers said while Colombian drug offenders are given the harshest treatment in U.S. jails, some American smugglers serve no time. The letter mentioned Barry Seal, a U.S. trafficker turned government informant, as an example of an American criminal ``who never knew the jails of the United States.'' After helping the Drug Enforcement Administration indict several major cocaine traffickers, Seal was assassinated by the Colombian drug mafia in 1986. Among those accused of having ordered his murder is Ochoa. Drug bosses have said as many as 300 cocaine smugglers are willing to surrender in return for more legal guarantees. Thousands of Colombians have died since August 1989 in drug-related violence ranging from gunfights to bombings to political assassinations. The killing that August of anti-drug crusader Luis Galan, a leading presidential contender, prompted the government's war on drug traffickers. The Extraditables also criticized Gaviria's new drug strategy as ``part of a policy of repression against drug trafficking'' because it requires smugglers to confess crimes. The drug barons say requiring citizens to incriminate themselves in court is unconstitutional. Gaviria, in comments published Saturday, said his drug policy was not a deal with traffickers, but an attempt to solve the drug problem within the framework of Colombian justice. ``We are as committed as we ever were to the fight against drug trafficking,'' the Washington Post quoted Gaviria as saying.

DOC.HEAD: Seven Arrested as Ku Klux Klan Jeered
LaserPhoto CS2
DOC.TEXT: About 1,500 people jeered and threw things at six robed Ku Klux Klan members who staged a rally downtown Saturday, resulting in one injury and seven arrests. Hecklers at Fountain Square shouted obscenities, waved ``Smash the Klan'' signs and hurled bottles that shattered on the square's stage as helmeted police formed a barrier to hold back the crowd. ``It's a damn shame the city's protecting them,'' one protester said. Police Chief Lawrence Whalen said at least one fistfight broke out among people in the angry crowd that had gathered in the plaza, where two months ago thousands had gathered to honor the World Series champion Cincinnati Reds. One fire captain was slightly injured by an object hurled from the crowd, Whalen said. No other injuries were reported. ``I think you've seen an exhibition here of one of the most difficult jobs that public safety has, of maintaining strict neutrality between two or three or four factions that have some very significant points of view,'' he said. ``It's one of the more serious demonstrations that we've had.'' The Klansmen, wearing white, purple and black robes, erected a 10-foot cross in the square which was decorated with Christmas trees. One Klan member held up a Bible and yelled ``Life, life through Jesus.'' But when he grabbed a bullhorn to make a speech, jeers and taunts drowned out his words. One heckler in the crowd screamed: ``Your mama should see you. She ain't never bought you no clothes like that.'' The jeering intensified when one Klan member held up a sign reading: ``Fight Racism - Abolish Affirmative Action.'' ``It was getting ugly real quick,'' said Edward Ammann, the assistant police chief. Those who were arrested were charged with disorderly conduct. Other protesters, angry over the arrests, went to the Hamilton County Justice Center and chanted while the seven were booked. Ammann said police recovered 40 to 50 objects the protesters threw during the rally, including rocks, ball bearings, pieces of machinery and a two-pound can of sliced pineapples. The Klansmen, members of the U.S. Knights of the Ku Klux Klan based in nearby Hamilton, had obtained a city permit to hold a one-hour raly, but left 15 minutes early. Police escorted them to a nearby building after they ended their event and used chemical Mace to repel some protesters who had charged toward the Klansmen. One protester was arrested as he threw an object and hit a Klansman's car as it sped away. Imperial Wizard Ron Lee said he did not want any violence during the rally. The Klansmen observed a resolution the City Council had passed Wednesday barring them from wearing hoods to conceal their identities on public property. The Council citing the fear of violence in passing it. The Klan obtained the rally permit after U.S. District Judge Carl Rubin allowed a Jewish congregation to put a menorah on the square for the eight days of Hanukkah. The city opposes religious symbols on the square and the the Klan removed the cross after the event. City officials cited safety concerns in denying the Klan permission to burn the cross.

DOC.HEAD: Families Await Word, Question Timing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs the 1st graf to recast and delete double use of `accident.'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Gulf-Capsize Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Myrt Yarbrough and Peter A.C. Long are cq
DOC.TEXT: Families of sailors aboard the aircraft carrier Saratoga nervously awaited information Saturday about the deaths of 19 sailors in a boat accident along the coast of Israel. Families were asking ``Why didn't this happen some other time?'' not as close to Christmas, said Cmdr. Jerry O'Connor, senior chaplain at Mayport Naval Station, the Saratoga's home port. ``We don't have answers for that. We just don't.'' O'Connor said a memorial service will be held Sunday aboard the Saratoga and another service would be held in Mayport, probably after Christmas. At least 19 sailors from the Saratoga died when a ferry taking them back to the ship from shore leave capsized early Saturday off the Israeli coast. This community suffered a similar tragedy in May 1987 when 37 sailors aboard the Mayport-based USS Stark were killed when the guided missile frigate was blasted by two missiles fired by an Iraqi warplane in the Persian Gulf. The Saratoga, in the Mediterranean Sea and the Red Sea since mid-August as part of the Operation Desert Shield forces, has been alternating duty with the carrier Kennedy, based at Norfolk, Va. ``We're expecting some other kind of casualty and everyone gears up for something militarily speaking in the Desert Shield operation - we don't expect something like a ferry boat capsizing,'' O'Connor said. Names of the victims were not immediately released. Three were from Florida - two had home addresses in Mayport and a third in the Panhandle, said Capt. Peter A.C. Long, commander of Mayport Naval Station. One of the injured was stationed at nearby Cecil Field Naval Air Station. At Mayport, the gymnasium was opened up for families wanting counseling or just needing to talk. About 50 families used those services Saturday, said Lt. Myrt Yarbrough, director of the Family Services Center. ``They want to know: Is it my husband? Is it my brother? Is it my son?'' she said. The hard thing about dealing with the families, she said, is ``You can't make it go away - the reality that this is happening. ``We want to be honest with the people, but we don't want to raise their fears - maybe unnecessarily.'' Long said community support had been the brighter side of the accident, with food and services flowing into the base from nearby Jacksonville. Long said it was too early to determine the cause of the accident, but said it is common for the Navy to hire ferries in foreign ports. He said the boats are inspected and sailors are required to wear life vests. ``We go to great pains to try to protect our sailors' safety,'' he said. ``I think the circumstances were catastrophic and extremely quick. There is a great concern about the people on the Saratoga,'' he said. A base ombudsman, who asked to be identified only as Christie, said Navy families and wives are tough, but need help at such times. ``They're scared. They're hopeful. They need a friend. They need a shoulder,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Figure In Catholic Scandal Hospitalized Following Pill Overdose
DOC.TEXT: The woman whose affair with Atlanta's Roman Catholic archbishop prompted his resignation remained hospitalized Saturday, one day after she took a drug overdose, police said. Vicki Long was admitted to the mental health unit at Doctors Hospital about 6 p.m. Friday after swallowing a large number of prescription pills at her mother's home, police said. Police refused to identify the drug. Ms. Long, 28, locked herself in a bathroom and left a lengthy note, said Police Lt. Bill Rawn. The episode was being investigated as an ``intentional overdose,'' Rawn said. The note's contents were not disclosed. Although arriving emergency workers found Ms. Long was not in immediate physical danger, they took her to the hospital for further examination. Police reported that Ms. Long's mother, Vera Long, said her daughter had been ``under a lot of stress.'' Ms. Long was ``feeling fine'' later Friday evening, her mother said. Hospital officials would not confirm Saturday whether Ms. Long was a patient. Archbishop Eugene Marino resigned last summer, originally citing health concerns. Church officials later confirmed his two-year ``intimate'' relationship with Ms. Long. Ms. Long also has been linked to two other priests. A paternity suit she filed against one is pending, although blood tests have indicated he is not the father of her 4-year-old daughter. The overdose came one day after the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Atlanta released an audit showing Ms. Long had indirectly or directly received more than $20,000 in church funds. The audit showed $5,835 from individual churches went to either Ms. Long or her creditors for rent, utilities or credit card payments. It also showed the archdiocese paid $14,556 of Ms. Long's medical expenses. Ms. Long moved back to Columbus from the Atlanta area after her affair with Marino became public.

DOC.HEAD: France Claiming War Reparations from Germany
DOC.TEXT: France is asking unified Germany for reparations from World War II that the former East Germany had balked at paying, an official said Saturday. The official, confirming a newspaper report, said the move was in line with October unification of the two Germanys, which gives the united country the burden of various debts of the former East Germany. In Paris, an authorized source speaking on condition of anonymity also confirmed discussions were under way, but stressed they involved claims from private citizens, not French governmental claims. Die Welt newspaper quoted reliable sources saying French diplomats had spoken several times with the Foreign Ministry in Bonn about the issue and the French Embassy in Bonn had sent two written notes to the ministry. A ministry spokesman, who refused to be identified by name, said the issue was a ``normal occurrence after unification, about which there must be negotiations.'' France had previously been in contact with East Germany about reparations, he said. The Die Welt report said France had put its claim in the currencies of 1945: 37.6 billion French francs and 261 billion reichsmarks, the currency of Nazi Germany. Asked how the claims would be converted into today's money, the spokesman said it was a technical question for negotiators. In the West German currency reform of 1948, 10 reichsmarks were converted to 1 mark. At that rate, the German currency part of the French claim would be set at 26.1 billion marks, today worth about $17 billion. The French currency also has been reformed since the war; data on its conversion were not available. According to one estimate, the final claim could rise over $65 billion. The spokesman said there would be talks early next year about the issue. When the two Germanys united in October, the federal government assumed the debts and treaty obligations of East Germany, which unlike West Germany had not paid reparations to the Western allies. After the war the Big Four allies - the United States, France, Britain and the Soviet Union - assessed reparations against Germany to be paid in assets and capital goods. But Germany was economically prostrate and collection of reparations was uneven. At the same time, the United States was pouring billions into West Germany and other European countries in the Marshall Plan, which helped revive war-damaged economies. The London Agreement of 1953 among West Germany and the four allies permitted the reparations question to remain open until a final settlement of wartime issues, which has finally happened in the past year with the unification of Germany and the Paris summit in November of 34 countries that sought to draw the final curtain over World War II. Die Welt said some of the damages France was claiming had occurred when French-owned property was seized in the Soviet occupation zone, which became East Germany. Other claims were related to forced labor by prisoners of war, restitutions for seized jewelry and valuable objects, Die Welt said. In the mid-1980s, West Germany agreed to pay damages to some French people who did forced labor or were drafted into the Germany military. Germany is paying reparations to Israel and individual Jews for the Holocaust. That sum so far has totaled about 80 billion marks, about $53 billion at today's exchange rates. Jewish organizations were unsuccessful over the years in pressing East Germany for reparations, as the Communist government refused to accept any war guilt from the Nazi era. In another bill from postwar days, Germany is paying the Soviets about 29 billion marks, or $19.5 billion in grants and credits to cover the costs of withdrawing 360,000 Soviets troops from former East Germany - the old Soviet occupation zone - over the next four years.

DOC.HEAD: Series Of Quakes Shake Costa Rica
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to ADD quotes, details of landslide and damage, conflicting epicenter report. Picks up 5 grafs pvs, `The first ...'
DOC.TEXT: A series of earthquakes shook Costa Rica on Saturday, shattering windows and sending panicked Christmas shoppers into the streets. There were no reports of injuries. At least six temblors struck, the strongest crumbling the wall of an empty prison and loosening chunks from the facade of a bank building. A 1,000-foot-wide landslide block a road west from San Jose. That temblor measured 5.7 on the Richter scale and was centered near the Panamanian border about 125 miles south of San Jose, said Bruce Presgrave, a geophysicist at the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. But Victor Gonzalez, a spokesman for Costa Rica's National University Volcanic Service, put the epicenter at 27 miles west of San Jose near the city of Santiago Puriscal. The quakes damaged businesses and shattered windows at several points across San Jose. Christmas shoppers rushed into the streets, some of them crying. Five homes were considerably damaged in the city of Escazu on the outskirts of San Jose, radio reports said. President Rafael Calderon called on citizens to remain calm. ``It was really a major scare, because it was the first time I've felt an earthquake of this magnitude,'' said Julian Becerra. ``The movement was impressive, even though I don't have much fear of temblors,'' taxi driver Edwin Otarola said. The first temblor occurred at 11:20 a.m. local time (12:20 p.m. EST), but was barely felt. The stongest quake hit the capital eight minutes later, briefly cutting off telephone and electric service. Another shock followed immediately. After a fourth quake, about an hour later, people continued their shopping. Two more aftershocks were recorded. The Red Cross reported that several cities within 100 miles of San Jose felt the quake, but experienced no substantial damage or injuries. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake measuring 5 on the Richter scale is capable of considerable damage, and a quake measuring 6 is capable of severe damage.

DOC.HEAD: Guam Picks Up After Typhoon Russ
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Russ damaged or destroyed more than 2,000 homes and injured 88 people in this U.S. territory in the Western Pacific, but no one was killed, officials said. The storm, packing wind that gusted up to 150 mph, swept over the island of 145,000 residents on Friday. Gov. Joseph Ada on Saturday sent a letter to President Bush, requesting a disaster declaration to release federal funds to help in the recovery. A disaster declaration from Bush is unlikely for several days, said Bart Stinson, a Civil Defense spokesman. There was no immediate estimate of total damage, he said. Electricity and water service had been restored to about 20 percent of Guam by Sunday morning, Stinson said. Telephone service, however, remained intact because most of the cables are buried, he said. Stinson said damage to Guam Community College, which is adjacent to Guam University, was extensive. ``It looks more like a tornado hit it than a typhoon,'' he said. The wooden buildings were splintered and desks strewn around the campus, where trees were twisted and not just blown down, he said. Ada said a preliminary survey by Federal Emergency Management Agency teams found 341 homes destroyed, 460 with major damage and 1,210 with minor damage to the point they were uninhabitable. Hospitals reported treating 88 people, mostly for punctures, cuts and scratches from wind-blown debris. The FEMA teams were already on Guam when Typhoon Russ hit. They had come to coordinate recovery operations on islands in the Federated States of Micronesia that were hit by Typhoon Owen three weeks ago.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Navy Intercepts Lebanese Ferry; Detains Six
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli gunboat intercepted a Lebanese ferry off Sidon and seized four Palestinians and two Lebanese who were on board, police reported Saturday. They said the ferryboat Ibrahim was approaching the Sidon port from Larnaca, Cyprus, when it was intercepted Friday evening. The six detainees were taken to Israel, apparently for questioning on suspicion of involvement in guerrilla activities, a police spokesman said. The Ibrahim was allowed to sail into Sidon after two hours, said the spokesman. He spoke on condition of anonymity. Sidon, 25 miles south of Beirut, is the main base of Yasser Arafat's Palestine Liberation Organization guerrillas in Lebanon. Western military sources and Lebanese police estimate about 6,000 PLO guerrillas are based in Sidon's Ein el-Hilweh and Mieh Mieh refugee camps. A PLO statement issued in Ein el-Hilweh confirmed the interception and said the four Palestinians were all students coming to spend the Christmas and New Year holidays with their families. No immediate comment was available from Israeli authorities.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Seeks International Help in Fight Against Hepatitis
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with higher Iraqi death toll claim, CLARIFY hepatitis virus afflicated many, but not necessarily all who died, ADDS details of medical shipments to Iraq. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq asked the World Health Organization on Saturday to help free medicine and equipment to combat hepatitis, which Iraq claims contributed to the deaths of some children since U.N. trade sanctions began. The official Iraqi News Agency said a national committee against hepatitis sent a telegram saying the sanctions halted imports of ``the equipment and special tools to discover the hepatitis B virus and also the vaccine against it.'' The report, monitored in Nicosia, did not refer to a specific outbreak or epidemic, but said the sickness ``is considered a big health problem in Iraq, especially among children.'' Without providing figures on hepatitis cases, the report said the committee told officials at the Geneva-based U.N. agency that 2,042 children under 5 years old have died since the embargo began in August. Iraq blamed the deaths on shortages of baby food and medicine, and claimed many of those who died suffered from hepatitis. The embargo is meant to retaliate for Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Hepatitis B is one of five strains of the blood virus that can be prevented by vaccine.
