Serious cases of hepatitis can lead to liver problems. ``The committee called in the telegram on the World Health Organization to interfere immediately to release the food and medicine seige and release imported medicine, vaccine, equipment and tools to control the hepititis virus in Iraq,'' the news agency said. Western diplomats in Baghdad say Iraq has received 120 tons of medicine from humanitarian groups worldwide since mid-October. Most of the shipments were in exchange for Western hostages trapped by the Persian Gulf crisis. President Saddam Hussein decided Dec. 6 to free all foreigners. Iraq's Red Crescent, the Islamic equivalent of the Red Cross, announced recently it had received 22 tons of medical supplies from Italy and another 28 tons from the U.N. Children's Fund. But Irqai officials have said acute shortages exist in some areas, such as for polio vaccine and drugs to treat heart ailments.

DOC.HEAD: United Nations Halts Aid to Angola After Government Cuts Off Rebels
DOC.TEXT: The United Nations halted deliveries of humanitarian aid in Angola after its leftist government blocked food convoys headed to rebel-held areas, a Portuguese report said. The cutoff jeopardizes aid for some of the estimated two million people facing starvation in the southern African nation. A severe drought this year destroyed many crops. ``We suspended all activities in the country because (otherwise) there would be violation of the principles of neutrality and equality,'' the Lusa news agency quoted U.N. representative in Angola, Otto Essian, as saying. Its report was carried late Friday night. The United Nations started aid shipments to Angola seven weeks ago. It aimed to distribute 130 million tons of food over six months to hungry Angolans who have suffered during 15 years of civil war. According to Lusa, Angola's minister of planning told Essian that food deliveries in rebel-controlled territories must stop immediately. The minister justified the decision saying military action by U.S.-backed UNITA rebels had slowed down food convoys in areas under government control. He said the rebels had blown up an important bridge that linked the towns of Lubango and Caconda in the southern province of Huila. UNITA, the National Union for the Total Liberation of Angola, has been fighting to force the Soviet-backed government to share control since independence from Portugal in 1975. The two sides agreed to open peace corridors to allow international organizations to deliver food, medicine and clothes to half of Angola's 18 provinces. But they have continued fighting. The civil war has devastated Angola's mineral-rich economy and killed over 350,000 people, according to government figures. After talks in Washington Dec. 13, the warring sides agreed to set a date for free elections and then sign a cease-fire. However, the rebels accused the government Saturday of undermining the next round of talks scheduled for early next year by making unreasonable demands, Lusa reported, citing a UNITA statement monitored in Lisbon.

DOC.HEAD: Inquirer Recants Controversial Editorial
DOC.TEXT: The Philadelphia Inquirer apologized publicly Saturday for an editorial that had been attacked as racist because it linked a new contraceptive to efforts to reverse poverty. The editorial appeared in the newspaper's early Sunday edition, which went on sale Saturday morning. The newspaper took the unusual step in response to criticism of a Dec. 12 editorial that suggested the contraceptive Norplant, recently approved by the federal government, could help solve the problem of poverty among blacks. ``The earlier Norplant editorial undercut our credibility and our efforts to be a thoughtful, responsible and compassionate voice on the complex issues of poverty,'' the newspaper said in its lead editorial in Sunday editions. ``We apologize to those we hurt and offended.'' The apology noted the newspaper's own reporters, editors and editorial board members were among those incensed by the original editorial. It was printed alongside five letters to the editor, containing both praise and criticism. The original editorial discussed two stories in the previous day's newspaper. One was about Norplant, which prevents pregnancy through implants of tiny rods under the skin and stays effective for years, the other about a research finding that nearly half of black children live in poverty and the situation is growing worse. ``As we read those two stories, we asked ourselves: Dare we mention them in the same breath? To do so might be considered deplorably insensitive, perhaps raising the specter of eugenics. But it would be worse to avoid drawing the logical conclusion that foolproof contraception could be invaluable in breaking the cycle of inner city poverty - one of America's greatest challenges,'' the original editorial said. The editorial, written by deputy editorial page editor Donald Kimelman, acknowledged better prenatal care and better schools as possible solutions to the problem. But it also said ``it's very tough to undo the damage of being born into a dysfunctional family. So why not make a major effort to reduce the number of children, of any race, born into such circumstances?'' The newspaper said reliable birth control should be a matter of personal choice and should be as available to poor women who want to use it as to middle-class women. ``In linking the issues of race and contraception, we left too many people with the impression that our cure for poverty was to reduce the number of black people,'' the apology said. That conclusion ``certainly was not what we meant to suggest,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistan, India Agree to Reduce Troops Along Border
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan and India have agreed to cut back troops along their tense border, this country's state-run television announced Saturday. No numbers were immediately given for the cutbacks, but the announcement was one of the first signs of reduced tensions between the two countries. The announcement seemed to catch both military and foreign ministry spokesmen by surprise. They had no immediate details. Indian officials had no immediate comment. Relations between the two nations, often at odds in the past, again nosedived in January when Moslem militants launched a secessionist uprising in Indian-held Kashmir. India and Pakistan have gone to war twice over Kashmir, in 1948 and 1965. The independence uprising has left more than 1,300 people dead. Thousands more have fled to Pakistan-held Kashmir. The former princely state of Kashmir was divided between Islamic Pakistan and majority Hindu India in 1947 when British rule of the subcontinent ended. India accuses Pakistan of arming militant secessionists, a charge Pakistan vehemently denies.

DOC.HEAD: Homeless Rights Group Settles With Sculptor Over `Nativity' Scene
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 7th graf to insert 4 grafs with reaction from Reid; pick up 8th graf pvs: The statue ...
DOC.TEXT: A homeless rights group said Saturday it has settled a copyright dispute with the creator of a contemporary ``nativity'' scene depicting a family huddled over a streetside steam grate. The Community for Creative Non-Violence, which was founded by the late Mitch Snyder, said U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson approved an agreement last week giving joint copyright interests to both CCNV and sculptor James Earl Reid. The agreement gives CCNV the right to make two-dimensional copies such as Christmas cards and posters of the statue entitled ``Third World America.'' Reid retains the right to make both two- and three-dimensional copies of the sculpture, the CCNV said. The settlement requires the Baltimore sculptor to advise people who buy his copies that the sales will not benefit CCNV. ``We're pleased that this chapter of litigation has finally come to a conclusion and are happy with the settlement,'' CCNV spokeswoman Carol Fennelly said in a prepared statement. Reid said he is pleased with the settlement, but remains concerned because he wants access to his original sculpture in the CCNV shelter. Another case is pending in which Reid is trying to remove that sculpture from the shelter for several months while a master mold is made. The master mold would allow Reid to reproduce the work and protect it. Reid said that the sculpture in the CCNV shelter is a synthetic cement-like substance that is brittle. Reid wants to reproduce it in bronze. ``Being against my having access to my work is contrary to the spirit of public art,'' said Reid. ``The work is for the public good. It's not just to lay in their shelter.'' The statue, unveiled on the Ellipse near the Washington Monument on Christmas Eve 1985, was commissioned by CCNV, which was headed by Snyder, a nationally known advocate for the homeless who earlier this year committed suicide. Reid donated his time to complete the statue but the group paid him $15,000 for expenses incurred in creating it. As a result, CCNV owned the statue itself and that was never questioned. However, Reid registered the copyright for the statue under his name after CCNV planned a multi-city tour to raise money for the homeless. CCNV then filed suit claiming exclusive copyright ownership. In March 1989, the Supreme Court ruled that CCNV didn't own the copyright and returned the case to Jackson.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Continues With Snow & Storms Along Its Edges
DOC.TEXT: The cold wave broke more low temperature records in the West on Saturday, and thunderstorms developing ahead of the cold front in the South spawned at least one tornado. Temperatures plunged below zero late Friday and early Saturday from the Great Basin through the northern and central Rockies to the upper Mississippi Valley. Temperatures of 20 degrees below zero or colder were reported in Idaho, Nevada, Utah, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, Nebraska, South Dakota, North Dakota and Minnesota. Wyoming was again the coldest state with lows ranging from 27 below at Sheridan to 45 degrees below zero at Worland, the coldest spot in the nation Saturday morning. Seven cities in the West tied or surpassed previous all-time record lows. Winnemucca, Nev., reported an all-time record low of 37 below zero. About 40 cities in the West, including more than a dozen in California and 14 in Utah, reported record lows for the date. The low of 25 below zero at Denver tied the city's record for the whole month of December. Temperatures were still below zero at midday across the northern and central Plains and the upper half of the Mississippi Valley. Readings were still 20 below zero or colder in North Dakota, Montana and Wyoming. Worland, Wyo., was still 27 degrees below zero at midday. Behind the cold front marking the leading edge of the cold air, snow, sleet and freezing rain prevailed from southern Indiana to south-central Texas. Strong thunderstorms developing along and ahead of the cold front extended from southern Louisiana to northern Alabama during the afternoon. Thunderstorms over central Mississippi spawned a tornado which damaged a house and took the roof off a building at Pinola, the National Weather Service said. The thunderstorms also produced high wind which unroofed a house near Brookhaven, downed trees near Mendenhall, and downed a tractor shed and numerous trees near Philadelphia. Showers extended across western and middle Tennessee into the upper Ohio Valley. Clouds and drizzle and fog prevailed across much of the rest of the East. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hours up to 1 p.m. EST included 2.21 inches at Huntsville, Ala., 1.58 inches at Columbus, Miss., 1.30 inches at Jackson, Miss., and 1.24 inches at Crossville, Tenn. Heavier rainfall totals for the 24 hours up to 7 a.m. EST included 4.63 inches at Huntsville, Ala., 4.13 inches at Muscle Shoals, Ala., and 3.52 inches at Dyersburg, Tenn. Unseasonably warm weather continued in the East. Temperatures remained above 50 degrees last night as far north as the lower Great Lakes, southern New York and southern New England. Record highs were 53 at Albany, N.Y.; 52 at Binghamton, N.Y.; 62 at Boston; 54 at Bridgeport, Conn.; 67 at Elkins, W.Va.; 58 at Hartfort, Conn.; and 61 at Providence, R.I. Overnight lows across the state of Texas ranged from 67 at Brownsville to 6 below zero at Dalhart. Brisk winds and subzero temperatures in the north central United States continued to produced wind chill readings as cold as 60 degrees below zero at Duluth, Minn., Livingston, Mont., and Casper, Wyo. An upper level weather disturbance brought clouds and snow to parts of Washington and Oregon, while low pressure continued to bring snow to parts of New Mexico and Arizona.

DOC.HEAD: Janet Chusmir, Miami Herald Executive Editor, Dies at 60
Ed: INSERTS 1 graf after 8th graf, `In 1982...' to UPDATE with reaction from Daily Camera publisher. Pickup at 9th graf, `Chusmir returned...'
DOC.TEXT: Miami Herald Executive Editor Janet Chusmir, a pioneering journalist who guided the newspaper to two Pulitzer Prizes, died Saturday of a brain aneurism at age 60. She collapsed Friday night at her home in Miami Beach and was rushed to St. Francis Hospital in a coma. She died Saturday morning without regaining consciousness, the Herald said. The collapse came only about an hour after she left the Herald's evening news meeting and stopped at desks to extend holiday wishes to reporters and editors. ``We have lost a great friend and a great editor,'' said Herald Publisher David Lawrence. ``What zest she had for good newspapers, what energy she had for caring, for worrying about what was right and fair for everyone. She set a wonderful example.'' Born in Boston, she graduated from Boston University in 1949 with a journalism degree. After graduation, she married Leonard Chusmir, the college paper's editor, and raised a family. Then in 1963, the family moved to Miami Beach, and she began working for $2.50 a story with the now-defunct Miami Beach Daily Sun. She was hired by the Herald in 1968 and soon had a regular column and a collection of awards for feature writing. By 1977 she worked her way up to assistant managing editor for features. In 1982 the Herald's parent company, Knight-Ridder Newspapers, named her publisher and president of the Boulder, Colo., Daily Camera, making her the organization's first female chief executive. ``Janet left an imprint on everything she touched,'' said John L. Dotson Jr., publisher of the Daily Camera. ``The Camera today is one legacy of her creativity and energy. Many of the innovations she instituted continue to be featured and many of the staffers are here today because of her.'' Chusmir returned to the Herald in 1987 as executive editor, the senior newsroom position. In 1988, the paper won two Pulitzers, one for commentary to Dave Barry for his humor columns, and one for feature photography to Michel DuCille for a photo essay on a Miami crack neighborhood. In a ``View From the Newsroom'' column last year, she wrote that the newspaper business is ``a sacred trust. We are our readers' eyes and ears; we must be fair, accurate, sensitive and courageous. Courageous because we help to set the agenda and sometimes that is painful for all of us who live in this community.'' Last month, the National Press Foundation unanimously selected her as Editor of the Year for ``transforming the Herald to serve the unique multicultural population of greater Miami.'' She is survived by her husband, Leonard; son Steven; daughter Marsha Chusmir-Shapiro; and grandchild Matthew Shapiro.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Seek Clues In Sinking; At Least 19 Sailors Dead
LaserPhotos TLV6-9
DOC.TEXT: Investigators searched Saturday for clues as to why a chartered ferry capsized in choppy seas, killing at least 19 American sailors who were in the Middle East as part of Operation Desert Shield. Survivors said the Israeli ferry went under almost instantly after it was swamped early Saturday while ferrying about 100 crewmen back to the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga from shore leave in Haifa. ``All of a sudden I saw water just come flying in. It was maybe two seconds and the boat rolled right over,'' said Chief Petty Officer Lance Vickery, 33, of Jacksonville, Fla. Israeli divers retrieved six bodies from the sunken craft in 65 feet of water. The others were found dead on the surface or died of injuries after being rescued alive, officials said. Three dozen sailors were taken to hospitals, but most were released. By Saturday afternoon, two men were still reported unaccounted for, but Navy officials said they believed they would be located as crewmen reported back to their ships. The Saratoga and its three escort ships were in the Red Sea as part of the naval buildup in the Persian Gulf region in the wake of Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The accident was the deadliest involving U.S servicemen in Operation Desert Shield, and it raised the number of Americans who have died to at least 73. Haifa is a frequent port of call for American sailors. Last year, more than 45,000 sailors attached to the Sixth Fleet visited the northern port city. Several sailors rescued from the Tuvia said the craft may have been overloaded. One of the two Israeli crewmen, Yossi Shochat, said he believed too many sailors were crowded into the boat's stern. But Gen. Micha Ram, the commander of Israel's navy, said on Israel radio that the Tuvia had been licensed to carry 130 passengers but took only about 100 because the seas were running high. ``Until the boat is retrieved and can be examined ... we cannot point to any negligence,'' he said. He said the craft went down in 15 or 20 seconds and added: ``I have never known a vessel to sink so fast.'' Survivors told of harrowing moments in the water, clinging to life jackets and debris from the 57-foot-long, double-deck ferry. At least some of the injured were struck by a rescue boat. Six of the injured remained in Haifa's Rambam Hospital on Saturday night. Matty Ilnach, head duty nurse at Rambam, said all were listed as slightly wounded, and could be released Sunday. Cmdr. Craig Quigley, a U.S. Navy spokesman, said 36 sailors were admitted to Haifa hospitals but that most were released immediately after a checkup. Col. Ranaan Gissen, the Israeli army's deputy spokesman, said more than 30 others were plucked from the waters unharmed in a rescue operation by both U.S. and Israeli forces. Flares lit the sky over the harbor of the northern city for much of the night, and ambulances rushed victims to three Haifa-area hospitals. Some sailors rescued from the capsized ferry said they had spent their shore leave having dinner, drinking beer or visiting discotheques. Israel army radio reported that some of the sailors had been drunk and at least one of the dead victims was handcuffed, apparently after being arrested by U.S. military police for drunkenness. However, Pentagon spokesman Lt. Commander Alan Dooley said no one aboard the boat was in handcuffs. The Tuvia capsized shortly after midnight about 200 yards from the Saratoga, which was anchored outside the harbor's breakwater about a mile offshore. The waves were reported at three to four feet and winds at 35 mph when the craft heeled over. Quigley said, ``I would point out that the operation of the boat was completely separate (from Navy operations.) There was an Israeli master and crewman. ... The sailors were passengers.'' Quigley said all 1,920 sailors who began liberty Friday were ordered to return to the carrier and three escort ships to try to account for all sailors. The Saratoga task force, based at Mayport Naval Air Station in Jacksonville, Fla., includes the destroyer Sampson, cruiser South Carolina and combat stores ship Sirius. It has 6,200 men, including about 4,500 aboard the Saratoga. The Saratoga naval task force arrived in Haifa on Thursday night from the Red Sea. Quigley said bodies of the victims would probably be flown back to the United States starting Sunday. Gissen said police and port officials were conducting two separate investigations into the cause of the sinking. The Navy also ordered a probe of the accident. Seaman Michael Benjamin, 19, of San Antonio, Texas, said he was standing in the ferry's aft when he saw water pouring in as the craft bounced over the waves. ``We were going on the waves, and I just noticed one that was bigger than normal and then we noticed another one that was bigger than normal. The next thing I know, all I saw coming in was water. I was tilted forward, I heard a lot of yelling, `She's going down.''' Benjamin suffered a neck injury when he was hit in the water by one of the rescue boats.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Bans New Republic Drives; Bombings Reported
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Saturday outlawed attempts by two Moldavian ethnic groups to form new republics. Two bombings were reported in other troubled areas. Ethnic tension and struggles against the Kremlin have dominated recent events in the 15 Soviet republics, which have all declared some form of independence or autonomy. Gorbachev gave Moldavia 10 days to dissolve a new national guard and guarantee equal rights for all ethnic groups. Four people were killed in the southern republic last month when government troops clashed with activists seeking independence from the Soviet Union. Gorbachev also asked Moldavia to reconsider a law making Moldavian the republic's official language. Language is among issues cited by the two ethnic groups seeking their own republics. The Gagauz, comprising about 150,000 Turkish Christians, declared a new republic in southern Moldavia. In eastern Moldavia, more than 300,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have joined to declare a new republic along the Dneister River. They all resent the Moldavian-language law and requirements that people in dozens of jobs pass Moldavian language tests by 1995. Moldavian, spoken by about two-thirds of the republic's people, is identical to Romanian except for the Cyrillic script. Gorbachev said the declaration of the new republics was illegal under the Soviet and Moldavian constitutions. The Moldavian legislature has clamped a two-month state of emergency on the Gagauz region, restricting movement in and out of the area and banning public rallies. In Latvia, a bomb exploded in a military school in the capital of Riga late Saturday, breaking 200 windows and causing $80,000 damage, the official news agency Tass reported. No injuries were reported. Three explosions struck the Baltic republic's capital earlier in the week, smashing windows in the Latvian Communist Party building, the Soviet army prosecutor's office and the Latvian prime minister's office. No suspects or motives have been identified in any of the blasts. However, Latvia has been seeking independence from the Soviet Union. In the southern Nagorno-Karabakh region, a powerful explosion left a 12-foot-wide crater in the road, narrowly missing a bus carrying Interior Ministry troops, Tass said. One officer was wounded by fragments of broken glass and the bus was seriously damaged, it said. In the past two years, more than 200 people have died in ethnic clashes in Nagorno-Karabakh, a largely Armenian enclave inside the border of the neighboring Azerbaijan republic. A limited form of martial law has been imposed and is enforced by Interior Ministry troops.

DOC.HEAD: Arrest Made in Random Nighttime House Shootings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3 grafs with 5 grafs after 5th graf, `Police said...' to UPDATE with telephone calls threatening lives of police chief and deputy police chief; suspect earlier turned down for Manchester police job; other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police following up a tip arrested a man early Saturday in connection with a series of nighttime house shootings that frightened a section of the city. No one was injured in the shootings, although there were some near misses as shotgun blasts shattered windows and penetrated walls. Some residents began sleeping and watching television on the floor and took down Christmas lights as police cautioned them to keep houses as dark as possible. Gary LeClerc, 27, who lived in the area of the shootings, was arrested at his apartment without incident and charged with felony criminal mischief, felonious use of a firearm and harassment. Bail was set at $51,000. Deputy Police Chief Paul Brodeur said other charges will be filed. Police said no motive had been determined in the apparently random shootings. LeClerc was arrested after he allegedly made three harassing telephone calls on Wednesday to Manchester police, officers said. During two calls, a man threatened to kill Police Chief Thomas King, police told a Saturday news conference. In a third call, the man threatened the life of Deputy Chief Louis Craig, who will replace the retiring King next month. Ten homes were hit in 11 shootings - King's house was hit twice - since the first in adjacent Litchfield on Oct. 7. There was one more shooting in Litchfield and the rest were in the south end of Manchester, all since Nov. 25. LeClerc, a former Auburn humane officer, was turned down for a job with the Manchester Police Department within the last two years, officers said. He is separated from his wife and lives alone. A $2,000 reward was offered for help in an arrest and conviction. Brodeur said police received a telephone tip that LeClerc might be the sniper, and began investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Turkey Sends Reinforcements to Iraqi Border
DOC.TEXT: Turkey is sending 12,500 more soldiers to its border with Iraq in a continuing buildup as the U.N. deadline approaches for Iraq to leave Kuwait, a newspaper reported Saturday. The Istanbul daily Cumhuriyet also quoted unidentified military sources as saying Iraq has increased its forces in the area. A total of 8,000 more Turkish paratroopers were sent to the border area in the past 10 days, the paper said. It said 4,500 infantry soldiers will be transferred there from Thrace in northwestern Turkey. Not counting the latest reported deployment, Turkey has about 100,000 troops along the border with Iraq. Most were sent there shortly after Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. No officials were available to confirm the Cumhuriyet report. Premier Yildirim Akbulut said Thursday that the government had asked the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to send air units to Iraq to bolster the country's defense. Turkish newspapers criticized the request Saturday, arguing it would commit Turkey militarily in the event of a Persian Gulf war. The newspapers said Iraq would see the NATO units as a provocation, not as an increased defense measure. NATO confirmed Friday it was considering the request to have the squadrons in place by Jan. 15, the U.N. deadline. Belgium said it was preparing a squadron of Mirage jetfighters. The U.N. Security Council has passed a resolution authorizing the use of force if Iraq does not pull out of Kuwait by Jan. 15. A Turkish parliamentary delegation arrived in Baghdad on Saturday on a peace mission. The head of the delegation, opposition leader Erdal Inonu, told the official Iraqi News Agency upon arrival that the delegation sought ``means of achieving peace and averting war over the gulf crisis.'' The group planned meetings with senior officials, including President Saddam Hussein, the Iraqi news agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Leaders Talk of New Gulf Force; Denounce Iraq
LaserPhoto LON15
DOC.TEXT: The exiled emir of Kuwait and five Arab allies opened a summit Saturday seeking a common strategy to free Kuwait and strengthen their forces to guard against further Iraqi aggression. ``This is the summit of liberation and transformation,'' said Abdullah Bishara, secretary-general of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council. The emir of Qatar, Sheik Khalifa bin Hamad Al Thani, in opening remarks denounced Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. He said he hoped Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ``would listen to reason and spare the region he perils of war.'' ``Iraq upset all balances and disturbed the rules of Arab bonds as well as the essence of gulf security,'' he said. Besides Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah of Kuwait, others at the opening of the annual summit were: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia, United Arab Emirates President Sheik Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan, Sultan Qaboos of Oman, and Prime Minister Sheik Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa of Bahrain. Kuwaiti Defense Minister Sheik Nawaf al-Sabah predicted the summit would discuss the possibility of asking the United States and some Arab nations to station troops in Kuwait if Iraq withdraws or is forced out. Summit sources also said leaders are expected to study plans for transforming the council's 10,000-member rapid deployment force into a full-fledged ``joint gulf army.'' ``The aggression that we face and the threat to peace and security of our member states will be added incentive for ... our determination to move with firm steps toward the future capable of confronting all circumstances and dealing with them from a position of strength,'' Fahd said. Shortly before the summit got under way, a Kuwaiti official urged a peaceful solution to the gulf crisis ``to spare bloodshed and avert destruction.'' In a statement released in Taif, Saudi Arabia, the minister of state for foreign affairs, Sheik Nasser Mohammed al-Ahmed, said he was responding to ``statements by some Arab officials'' about Saddam being ready for face-saving concessions. The statement, however, reiterated that no settlement would be acceptable unless it involved unconditional, total Iraqi withdrawal and restoration of the al-Sabah rule. He also stressed the need for Iraqi reparations for the destruction by Iraqi forces in Kuwait. The council was created in the summer of 1981 as a framework for collective defense and economic integration. The summit was scheduled to resume Sunday and last through Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Decision About Philadelphia Bailout Plan May Wait Until New Year
DOC.TEXT: The Christmas tree in the lobby of the city Board of Pensions and Retirement had just one gift-wrapped box under it last week. It had an opening like a coin slot in the top and it was empty. Retired and current employees fear that's what their pension fund will look like if the fund loans money to aid the cash-starved city. The administration of Mayor W. Wilson Goode has tried since August to borrow enough money to meet expenses through winter. Payless paydays for city workers are likely next month without a cash infusion. A $375 million offering of short-term notes failed in September. The city is negotiating with banks, the city pension board and the state Public School Employees' Retirement Board over the terms of a $150 million note issue. The decision on the note issue was put off last week until after Christmas or possibly the New Year. The money would allow the city to pay its workers and meet debt-service payment, but not to pay suppliers already owed millions of dollars. Goode said Friday night, ``$150 million is better than zero.'' Potential investors and city officials reported progress on loan terms after five hours of closed-door negotiations Friday. Banks have demanded an array of guarantees aimed at ensuring repayment to investors and a cure to city deficits projected to exceed $500 million over the next 18 months. A bank proposal for an outside authority with line-item veto power over the city budget was scuttled, Goode said. But a financial control element remains in the package, City Controller Jonathan A. Saidel said. Its makeup would be determined by the state Legislature, he said, declining to give further details. Goode, Saidel and other Democratic leaders in a fiscal recovery plan announced Nov. 9 suggested an independent control board be created. The board'w authority would be triggered if the city passed an unrealistically balanced budget. In the loan package being negotiated, each of the two pension boards would buy up to 25 percent of the total amount, or $37.5 million of a $150 million deal. The other $75 million would be purchased by the banks. The notes are expected to pay about 10.5 percent tax-exempt interest, nearly twice the going rate on notes offered by governments with solid credit ratings. Philadelphia's rating has sunk this year to junk-bond level, the lowest among major U.S. cities. The city pension board's investment is far from certain. No vote will be taken until a consultant advises board members on the prudence of such an investment. The consultant's report is not expected until negotiations produce a final loan package, possibly late this week. The consultant's report will be weighed against the sentiments of those who depend on the pension fund for retirement income. ``My members, both active and pension, don't want us to do it, period,'' said John A. Reilly, a firefighters' union representative on the board. But Joseph Herkness, a white-collar union leader on the board, said it may be necessary to find a way that's palatable to pension fund members. If payrolls are missed, so are payments to the pension plan, he said. ``We will consider all options when we're talking about a public bankruptcy, especially when our contributions to this fund are in danger,'' Herkness said. The state teachers pension board recessed a Dec. 14 meeting so it could reconvene on short notice to consider an investment.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Inmates Donate Their Pay to the Homeless
DOC.TEXT: A group of federal prison inmates has donated $525.50 to help the less fortunate - the city's homeless. The Los Angeles Mission accepted the check, representing money earned by 58 Terminal Island inmates at the rate of 12 to 40 cents per hour. ``The mission is touched,'' mission spokesman Michael McKee said Friday. ``A lot of the problems that drive the men into prison, drive them to the streets. The inmates had tremendous empathy for these people on the streets.'' Helping the homeless was the idea of inmate John Barton Bastian, who wrote to the mission, said Harvey Trott, the prison warden's executive assistant. ``It puts them (the inmates) in a Christmas spirit because it gives them an opportunity to help people who are more disadvantaged than themselves,'' Trott said. The medium-security Terminal Island prison is in the harbor area, 20 miles south of downtown. It houses 1,085 inmates.

DOC.HEAD: Brothers-in-Law Exchange Same Card For 42 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT typo, brothers-in-law sted brother-in-laws; Picks up 2nd graf, `The tradition ...'
DOC.TEXT: For one pair of brothers-in-law, it isn't really Christmas until one sends the other ``Ivan'' - the same greeting card they have exchanged every Yule season for 42 years. The tradition began in 1948, when Irving Willis mailed the unsigned card to his wife's brother, Delbert Gibson. Although the two men were living in the same house in Washington, D.C., ``I knew who it was that sent it right away,'' said Gibson, now 83. ``It was his kind of humor. ``So I kept the card, and the next year, sent it back to him with a Russian Christmas greeting,'' said Gibson, a professional linguist who now lives in Fort Lauderdale. ``Because the guy on the cover is riding a Russian sled, I picked Russian and we named the card Ivan. Then he sent it back to me the following year and it soon became a tradition.'' Every year since, the greeting has been written in a different language, except for two years the men unwittingly wrote in dialects of two languages that already had been used. When Gibson received the card this year, he found the greeting ``Krismasi Njema'' - ``Merry Christmas'' in Luo, an African language. ``I live in a retirement home, and one of the men that works here is from Kenya,'' said Willis, 79, a retired Navy captain now making his home in Washington. Now, the men are beginning to run out of languages for their annual holiday greeting. The two used up more common languages such as French, Dutch and Italian the first few years. The card also is running out of blank space for future greetings. ``We would have to write on the front,'' said Gibson, ``and I don't think we want to do that.''

DOC.HEAD: Cambodian Factions Agree on Key Points in Peace Plan
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia's four warring factions said Sunday they have agreed on most key elements of a U.N. peace plan, but they ended their round of talks without a final accord. The outcome of the two-day Paris talks fell short of the objective set by France and Indonesia, co-chairmen of the conference, to secure total agreement to the proposal. However, the participants said the Paris Peace Conference would reconvene ``at an early date.'' A final communique by the Supreme National Council, made up of the warring groups, said early Sunday there was agreement on ``most of the fundamental points'' of the U.N.-sponsored plan. But it added there were outstanding questions. These questions should be discussed within the 12-member council and by the Coordinating Committee of the Paris Conference, which is the framework for signing an overall peace settlement to end more than a decade of civil war in the Southeast Asian country. The U.N. plan was agreed to Nov. 26 by the United States and the four other permanent members of the Security Council. It calls for the United Nations to administer Cambodia during an interim period leading to free elections, while the Supreme National Council acts as titular head. It also calls for a cease-fire and disarming of all four parties. The heads of all the resistance factions voiced their acceptance ``without reserve'' of the plan and called on the Phnom Penh government to accept it. The resistance representatives were Prince Norodom Ranariddh, heading the delegation of rebel coalition leader Prince Norodom; Son Sann; and Khieu Samphan, leader of the Communist Khmer Rouge. The government of Prime Minister Hun Sen was the only one of the four Cambodian factions to object to key aspects of the U.N. proposal, according to informed sources speaking on condition of anonymity. A senior Western official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Phnom Penh is concerned about the extent to which its government could be dismantled by the plan and about the extent of disarmament. Hun Sen said on his arrival here that ``serious measures must be taken to suppress the foundations'' of the Khmer Rouge, the strongest member of the three-party resistance coalition. The Khmer Rouge's three-year reign as Cambodia's government, which ended in 1979 with a Vietnamese invasion, left hundreds of thousands of Cambodians dead from executions, famine and civil unrest.

DOC.HEAD: Official: German Firms May Have Tried to Skirt Iraq Boycott
DOC.TEXT: A government official said Saturday that evidence indicates some German firms planned to ship goods to Iraq in violation of a U.N. trade embargo. Volker Franzen, spokesman for the Economics Ministry, said the evidence suggests ``a few'' firms were involved, but no proof has been found that German goods illegally landed in Iraq. He did not name the companies or give other details. The United Nations placed the embargo on Iraq following the Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Franzen said German officials have been studying a list compiled by U.S. officials of 50 German firms suspected of breaking the embargo. Der Spiegel magazine has reported two German companies may have helped Iraq in the production of nerve gas. The magazine also alleged Interatom gave Iraq sensitive nuclear training and equipment. Interatom and its owner, the giant electronics conglomerate Siemens, denied the magazine's report. Interatom specializes in atomic energy plant construction and uranium enrichment, but is also involved in non-nuclear engineering. Franzen said the information from the U.S. list is of ``varying quality,'' and some firms are included which are completely above suspicion. But he said in other cases further investigation is needed. If German firms are found to have violated the embargo, they could face charges in Germany of breaking the country's export laws. Der Spiegel magazine said the list of alleged German embargo-busters resulted from U.S. monitoring of Iraqi telephone and Telefax communications. ``U.S. officials are informed of Iraq's supply plans because American intelligence listens in on Iraq's overall telephone traffic and intercepts Telefax messages,'' the magazine said, without identifying its sources. In another export scandal in 1988, U.S. intelligence said German companies helped Libya build a factory allegedly for making chemical weapons. The German government at first rejected the allegations, but later acknowledged they were true. As a result of that scandal, the head of a German chemical firm was convicted of breaking the country's export laws.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Companies Get Approval for Limited Imports from Iran
DOC.TEXT: U.S. oil companies have been authorized to import limited amounts of oil from Iran and send their payments to an escrow fund established to pay claims won against the Iranian government by Americans. The imports, to be handled on a case-by-case basis, were authorized by President Bush in early November, according to State Department officials. They are covered by 1987 Treasury regulations setting up a mechanism for commercial deals with Iran. The payments go into an escrow account overseen by the Iran-U.S. Claims Tribunal, an organization set up in The Hague in 1981 to arbitrate commercial disputes between U.S. claimants and the Iranian government. ``Last month we decided to license the import of Iranian oil into the United States on a case-by-case basis where the proceeds of the transaction are to be deposited in the security account,'' State Department spokeswoman Sondra McCarty confirmed Saturday night. ``If such transactions occur, this will help ensure that there are adequate funds available to pay tribunal awards to U.S. claimants. To date, over $2 billion has been transferred from the security account in satisfaction of tribunal awards to U.S. claimants.'' Addition of oil to items that can be imported from Iran on a case-by-case basis was reported initially by Platt's Week, an oil industry newsletter, and subsequently by The New York Times. State Department officials said the main reason for allowing oil imports was to help keep the escrow account funded. But they acknowledged that the move creates an additional oil supply in the event that a war in the Middle East results in a shortage.

DOC.HEAD: Bangladesh University Closed Following Student Clashes
DOC.TEXT: A university in the port city of Chittagong was closed indefinitely Saturday after a clash between rival student groups, police said. More than 130 people were reportedly injured. The clashes broke out when the university reopened after a recess and supporters of the Islamic Students' Organization attacked students attending classes, said Anupan Sen, a former president of the university teachers association. The Islamic students had called for an indefinite strike at the school. The group has demanded the removal of the university's vice chancellor. It members say he has not been sympathetic to them in university affairs. More than 100 students and at least 30 teachers were injured in the two-hour confrontation between the Islamic Students' Organization and the All Party Students Action Committee, said Sen. Bricks and homemade bombs were used in the clash, police and witnesses said. The Islamic group claimed three members were wounded by bullets. The organization is the students' wing of the Jamaat-e-Islami, a pro-Pakistan fundamentalist group opposed to the liberation of Bangladesh from Pakistan in 1971. A large contingent of police was deployed inside the Chittagong University, about 135 miles southeast of Dhaka.

DOC.HEAD: Condo Board Orders Gulf Soldier's Mom To Remove U.S. Flag
DOC.TEXT: To Lucille Consoli, the U.S. flag flying outside her home is a tribute to one son stationed in Saudi Arabia and another who may be on his way. To her condominium association, it's a foreign object that protrudes more than a foot from her unit and must be taken down. ``When I heard this, I wanted to go over to Saudi Arabia, pack his bags and bring him home,'' Mrs. Consoli said of her son, Air Force Airman Kevin Moreau. ``This is anti-American.'' Her other son, Air Force Staff Sgt. Mike Moreau, is in Shreveport, La., awaiting orders to ship out. Grady Morgan Sr., a Rosetree Village Community Association board member, said he empathizes with Mrs. Consoli. But the flag hung outside the eaves is against association rules. ``We have no objections to the American flag,'' he said. ``But you have to get permission. We have quite a few restrictions.''

DOC.HEAD: Stanford Agrees To Temporary Cut in Rate It Charges Government For Research
DOC.TEXT: Stanford University, under fire for claiming faculty discounts on game tickets are research-related expenses, has agreed to temporarily cut its billing rate to the government by 2 percent. The decrease is part of a ``provisional agreement'' drafted during talks last week between Stanford administrators and a team of contract experts and administrators from the Office of Naval Research - one of three federal agencies investigating Stanford's billing of research overhead costs. The Navy is looking into claims that the school may have overbilled the government as much as $200 million in the past decade. The interim agreement ``permits business relationships to be put on an orderly basis'' while the investigations continue, said Stanford spokesman Larry Horton. Stanford was charging the government 74 percent above the cost of a research contract to pay for overhead costs. Overhead costs include electricity bills, building depreciation, administrative expenses and the use of campus libraries and other facilities by researchers under government contract. The government allows those expenses. But Stanford also contends that fringe benefits for its faculty, such as discounts on football and basketball tickets, swimming pools, tennis courts and gyms, are ordinary costs of doing business and includes them in research overhead charges. Under the temporary contract, the university will be reimbursed at 72 percent until June 1991, when the Navy investigation is expected to be completed. Based on what the probes find, the billing rate may change. In exchange for Stanford's temporary billing rate pullback, the head of the five-member Navy team approved payment of $3.8 million in research bills that the Office of Naval Research had refused to release since October. Stanford also agreed to reopen talks on ``memorandums of understanding'' that have guided its billing practices for government research during the past 30 years. Some government officials say the rates set in the documents may have unduly benefited Stanford at the expense of taxpayers.

DOC.HEAD: Security Council Ends Trusteeship of Pacific Islands
DOC.TEXT: The Security Council voted Saturday to dissolve a 43-year-old U.N. trusteeship over several Pacific island chains that were once a stage for Cold War rivalries. The end of U.N. authority over the Northern Marianas, Marshall Islands and Federated States of Micronesia in the Western Pacific leaves Palau as the only remaining part of the Trust Territory. Palau continues under U.S. administration. The vote followed U.S. assurances it would not expand military bases or presence in the region, which had once been considered crucial for the ``Star Wars'' missile defense program. Cuba, one of the 15 Security Council members, cast the only vote in opposition to ending the trusteeship. Cuban diplomats cited objections by some island residents who complained about U.S. administration and alleged military objectives in the region. The Soviet Union had for years criticized the United States as the islands administering authority, claiming it bullied the island residents and sought to establish a military-strategic beachhead in the Pacific. But dramatically improved U.S.-Soviet relations appear to have resolved the differences. Former President Reagan had said the U.S. army's Kwajalein missile testing range in the Marshall Islands was ``vital to our Strategic Defense Initiative,'' also known as ``Star Wars.'' However, U.S. Ambassador Thomas R. Pickering said the U.S. government had no intention of expanding the size or number of military installations on the islands. The Marshall Islands and the Federated States had argued that elimination of the U.N. trusteeship would make it easier for them to establish diplomatic and economic relations with other states, especially Britain and European nations. But the Northern Mariana Islands governor wrote the Security Council asking that the islands remain under the trusteeship. The Northern Marianas are a U.S. commonwealth. The Marshalls and Federated States of Micronesia are semi-independent republics. The Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands was established in 1947, one of 11 trusteeships established by the United Nations. The region includes about 200,000 people scattered among more than 2,100 islands and atolls. It covers nearly 3 million square miles of the Pacific Ocean, slightly larger than the continental United States. The islands represent a land area only half the size of Rhode Island.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Wave Spreads, Crops Threatened
LaserPhoto MI1
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `Including those...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with state of emergency in Mississippi; woman freezing to death in Texas; heavy snow in Kansas City, Mo., sleet in St. Louis, Ohio River expected to crest. Pickup at 7th graf, `Denver hit...'
DOC.TEXT: The record cold wave pressed southward and eastward Saturday, threatening crops in southern Texas and California and covering highways with deadly sheets of ice across the Plains and Midwest. Temperatures fell to more than 40 degrees below zero in places, the National Weather Service said. Utilities fought to restore electricity and gas service to thousands of shivering customers. In sharp contrast to the cold and snow, the East still had mild weather. Boston hit a record 62 during the morning. Heavy rain and flooding forced the evacuations of more than 90 people across Tennessee on Saturday, state emergency officials said. Tornadoes swirled around Mississippi for the third straight day Saturday as crews tried to assess damage and start cleanup from Friday's twisters, which killed two people and injured many more. Gov. Ray Mabus on Saturday declared a state of emergency for all of Mississippi, allowing those affected by the tornadoes to seek state government aid. Including the Mississippi fatalities, at least 24 deaths had been blamed on the weather since Tuesday. Most of the fatalities were the result of traffic accidents on slippery roads. But an 80-year-old woman apparenlty froze to death in her yard in Childress, Texas, where she had accidentally fallen. Heavy snowfall inundated Kansas City, Mo., and sleet was reported in the St. Louis area. Denver hit a record low Saturday of 25 below zero; the city had been below zero since Wednesday evening. In northern Nevada, Winnemucca dropped to 37 below, the coldest ever registered there in more than 100 years of records. Los Angeles hit a record 33. The Idaho mountain town of Stanley hit a low of 46 below zero. The coldest spot in Utah was Randolph, with a low of 40 below. In South Dakota, there were unofficial overnight lows of 45 below at Deerfield in the Black Hills and at Porcupine on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. Cheyenne, Wyo., tied its record low of 28 below, then by noon warmed to 2 below, warmest point in the state. In southern Arizona, the desert city of Tucson had snow flurries. The arctic air hit the Chicago area during the night, sending temperatures tumbling from the mild 40s Friday evening to the teens Saturday morning, and highways throughout the state were icy. An Amtrak passenger train carrying 300 people was stuck in Devils Lake, N.D., for three hours Saturday morning when the fuel in the engines froze, a Burlington-Northern Railroad spokesman said. Welders were called in to help thaw out the engines. The temperature was 20 below and the wind chill factor was 50 below. Charities dealt with standing-room-only crowds in homeless shelters and with calls from families freezing in their own homes. ``We're way over capacity here,'' said Ruth Wynne at Oklahoma City's Jesus House. ``We are expecting a full house. If we have to we can line the halls with cots,'' said a Salvation Army official in Longview, Texas. Utilities in northwest Washington and the Puget Sound area reported repairs were still being made Saturday to power lines damaged during Tuesday's snow and wind storm. Puget Sound Power & Light spokeswoman Betty Werblun said 2,000 customers would not have service restored until Sunday night. Utility crews also worked to restore natural gas service to thousands of homes in frigid southern Oregon. ``I tried to buy an electric heater and started calling all over town and they said they were sold out hours ago,'' said Trudy Bache of Grants Pass. The cold also contributed to utility breakdowns in the San Francisco area and in the Texas Panhandle. Bitter cold was reported in southern Texas, with up to a half-inch of ice on Kerrville streets. In the Rio Grande Valley, citrus growers still reeling from a late winter freeze a year ago were braced for another damaging frost. In California, the heavily farmed San Joaquin Valley had record lows ranging from 19 at Fresno to the teens in the Bakersfield area, the weather service said. ``It's as bad as it's been in probably 20 years,'' said Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual association after checking growers in the San Joaquin Valley. ``Growers are still optimistic, but there is fruit loss. The temperatures were low enough to cause damage.'' The Amtrak passengers in North Dakota weren't the only travelers delayed by the weather. AAA Auto Club in Denver reported its response time for dead batteries and other problems had lengthened to about 48 hours Saturday. Thick fog delayed flights at Chicago and Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News

DOC.TEXT: French filmmaker Roger Vadim, Brigitte Bardot's ex-husband who launched her career in ``And God Created Woman,'' has married for the fourth time - this time, to yet another famous actress, Marie-Christine Barrault. Vadim, 62, once known as the talented playboy who took beautiful women and turned them into stars, was also married previously to Jane Fonda and Annette Stroyberg. He is the father of Miss Fonda's daughter, Vanessa, and actress Catherine Deneuve's son, Christian. He and Miss Barrault, 42, exchanged vows Friday. Miss Barrault earned international fame for her role in the 1975 film ``Cousin, Cousine,'' in which she flees a stuffy, bourgeois family wedding to pursue a love affair with a relative. Vadim and Miss Barrault met while serving on the jury at the Cognac Film Festival two years ago. They were married in a private ceremony outside Paris. ``Marie-Christine represents the exact, delicious synthesis of everything I've been looking for until now,'' Vadim told the magazine Le Figaro.

DOC.HEAD: Military Claims to Foil Air Base Attack Linked to Coup Plot
DOC.TEXT: Troops warned of a coup plot seized a jeep carrying weapons and dynamite at an air base and arrested a fugitive rebel officer, the military said Saturday. Former army Capt. Reynaldo Ordonez had been sought since a failed coup in August 1987. Three others were arrested. Maj. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon said an informant told the military the sabotage team would try to destroy fighter jets, fuel storage tanks and other equipment at the Basa air base, about 40 miles north of Manila. ``Further information states that the bombing operations in Basa would serve as the signal for the next coup attempt,'' said Biazon. Weapons and nine bundles of dynamite were found on a jeep that entered the air base Friday. Biazon, who was nominated Friday to become chief of staff, said at least two other vehicles with rebels soldiers failed to enter the base and escaped. Military rebels have staged at least seven uprisings against President Corazon Aquino since she took office in February 1986. Officials said they secretly moved most of the jets at the base to Palawan island after the warning of a sabotage plot. They said special counter-intelligence teams were deployed around the base. Only 12 aging planes were left at the base, said camp commander Col. Santiago Pitpitan. Most of the country's jet fighters had been at the camp. Others arrested with Ordonez include an enlisted man and two civilian sympathizers, Biazon said. There had been rumors that dissidents would stage another coup attempt during the weekend before Christmas. In December 1989, rebels staged a nine-day uprising in Manila in which more than 100 people were killed. In October, mutineers seized two garrisons in Mindanao and surrendered about two days later.

DOC.HEAD: Government Claims 83 Tamil Rebels Killed in Offensive
DOC.TEXT: At least 83 Tamil rebels were killed in a three-day government offensive in northern and eastern Sri Lanka, military officials said Saturday. Government forces on Wednesday began sweeps to locate rebels in Batticaloa, about 140 miles east of Colombo, after the area's top military commander was killed in a landmine blast. Military officials have refused to say how many soldiers were involved in the search for rebels, who have been fighting since 1983 for an independent nation for Sri Lanka's ethnic Tamil minority. More than 14,000 people have been killed in the civil war. The rebels claim the Tamils are discriminated against by the majority Sinhalese in jobs and education. Tamils make up 18 percent of the island's 16 million people and the Sinhalese, who control the government and the military, comprise 75 percent.

DOC.TEXT: A bus plunged over a cliff along a mountain road in the central state of Guanajuato, killing at least 48 people and injuring five, police said Saturday. The daily newspaper El Universal reported that 60 people were aboard the Green Arrow line bus when it overshot a turn and fell 36 feet Friday afternoon. A spokesman for judicial police in San Jose Iturbide, about 150 miles northwest of Mexico City, said all of those who died appeared to be Mexican citizens. Police said at least 48 people were killed and five hurt. El Universal had said seven were injured.

DOC.HEAD: Increase in AIDS Predicted in Thailand
DOC.TEXT: More than 2 million people in Thailand may carry the AIDS-causing virus by the end of the decade, and the figure could grow further without changes in the country's huge sex industry, an official said. ``Thailand must also deal with its massive commercial sex empire and change male sexual behavior,'' said Mechai Viravaidya, one of the nation's top development experts. ``AIDS has unfortunately become a permanent part of life in Thailand, and we must learn to live with AIDS in a humane manner.'' Mechai's speech Friday was given on the last day of a five-day international AIDS conference, which was boycotted by the U.N. World Health Organization because victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome from abroad were barred by Thai government. Mechai estimated about 300,000 Thais now carry the HIV virus, which leads to AIDS. Even with efforts to combat the disease, Thailand could have anywhere from 2.1 million to 6.7 million cases of AIDS by the year 2000, said Mechai, head of the Population and Community Development Association, a non-governmental organization. Thailand's current population is more than 55 million. Prostitution is widespread in Thailand, catering to both local residents and foreign tourists, some of whom arrive on special ``sex tours.'' Mechai said the various estimates were preliminary and based on models developed by his development association, the World Health Organization and Dr. Charles Myers of the Harvard Institute of International Development.

Jews are fleeing the Soviet Union and flooding into European transit points in trains, buses and even bicycles as they swell the biggest influx of immigrants to Israel in about 40 years. Israel on Friday ordered the national carrier to use every available plane to ferry the Jews from Europe. The government waived the prohibition against flights on the weekly Jewish Sabbath, from Friday evening through tonight. Three El Al planes left Friday night for Warsaw, Bucharest and Budapest and were to return today with 750 Soviet immigrants. Four more planes were flying today to pick up more immigrants, El Al spokesman Nachum Kleinman said. He said El Al had promised the Israeli government it would operate as many flights as necessary to airlift the immigrants. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - Pan Am and TWA, two of the oldest - and weakest - airlines, neared agreement on a business marriage that would end their longtime rivalry and change the cast of characters in a deeply troubled industry. But Pan Am may have to seek bankruptcy protection anyway. Carl C. Icahn, chairman of Trans World Airways, had proposed a buyout of Pan Am Corp. last weekend in a deal worth about $375 million. Pan Am Chairman Thomas G. Plaskett responded with a letter Friday saying the deal could be ``advantageous to our shareholders, employees and other constituencies.'' But in a frank admission of Pan Am's critical money shortage, Plaskett said Pan Am would need an infusion of cash before the purchase could be completed. Icahn said he would consider it, but only if Pan Am sought bankruptcy protection first. ---= MOUNT VERNON, Mo. (AP) - Nancy Cruzan's father and anti-euthanasia demonstrators exchanged sympathetic words on the steps of a hospital where the brain-injured woman lies dying. Meanwhile, a federal judge Friday criticized activists who want state health officials to restore a feeding tube removed from Nancy Cruzan last week. The action was the latest in a series of petitions denied since food and water were withdrawn Dec. 14 from Ms. Cruzan, who has been in a persistent vegetative state for nearly eight years. Joe and Joyce Cruzan obtained court permission to have the tube removed after providing testimony that their daughter would not want to live in her present condition. Doctors have said Ms. Cruzan could be expected to live two weeks after the feeding tube was removed. Her condition was deteriorating today. --- NEWARK, N.J. (AP) - Jerry Winters built a candy empire, door by door. In the mid-1980s, teens were selling his chocolate in 33 states. He was making over $30 million a year. A business magazine named him ``Entrepreneur of the Year.'' But reality was a long way from sugar and spice for the ``Candyman,'' convicted Friday on five counts of racketeering, extortion and interstate fraud. Two associates were also convicted of racketeering and extortion. Six others were acquitted. Prosecutors portrayed Winters as a hot-tempered tyrant whose secrets to success included baseball bat beatings and torched delivery vans. U.S. District Court Judge Maryanne Trump Barry, noting his penchant for violence and use of aliases, denied a request for house arrest. The millionaire will spend the holidays in jail.
